Ugh, okay, so like, where do I even *start* with this? It wasn't exactly a spontaneous decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, cool, a baby! Let's just...give it away!" That would be seriously messed up.

It was more...realistic. Paulie Bleeker – yeah, the dad, super sweet, kinda clueless – and I, we were, like, sixteen. *Sixteen*. We were still figuring out what kind of pizza we liked, let alone how to raise a human being. I mean, I can barely keep my grades up and maintain a semi-functional social life, adding a diaper change schedule into the mix felt...impossible.

And honestly? I knew I wasn't ready. Not even close. I wanted to finish school, maybe go to college, figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life. I didn't want my life to be, like, *over* before it even really started. 

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? That's what people kept assuming, and it was super annoying. It was about wanting the baby to have the best life possible. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give it that. Not yet. 

So, I started looking into adoption. And I found Mark and Vanessa Loring. They were...good people. Really good people. And they *wanted* a baby. Like, really, really wanted one. It felt...right. Still kinda sucks, don't get me wrong. But right.



Does that make sense? It's complicated. Everything always is.

Ugh, okay, so like, *love* and *responsibility*. Big topics. Honestly, before all this happened, I thought love was mostly in movies, you know? Like, John Hughes movies. Cute guys with boomboxes and stuff. Turns out it's...messier. Way messier.

With Paulie Bleeker, it wasn't some grand, sweeping romance at first. It was just...comfortable. We knew each other, we could be sarcastic with each other, and he didn't, like, *try* to be cool. That's a big plus. I learned that love isn't always fireworks, sometimes it's just...being able to sit with someone in silence and not feel weird. And wanting to make them happy, even when they're being a total dork.

But then there's the whole *responsibility* thing. That's where it got real. It wasn't just about me anymore. It was about this little person growing inside me, and then, after, about finding the *right* people to raise him. Mark and Vanessa...they weren't what I expected, not at all. Super put-together, kinda preppy. But they genuinely wanted a kid, and they were gonna give him a good life. 

That was the hardest part, I think. Letting go. Realizing that loving someone sometimes means wanting the best for them, even if that best doesn't include *you*. It's not a glamorous feeling, it's kinda heartbreaking, actually. But it's also...grown-up. 

I learned that responsibility isn't just about doing what you *have* to do, it's about doing what's *right*, even when it's hard. And sometimes, the right thing is letting someone else take the reins. It's weird, but it's also...okay. It's more than okay, actually. It's kinda beautiful, in a messed-up way.

Ugh, okay, so like, people always ask me that. It's not like I *tried* to be funny while everything was going down, you know? It just…happened. It was kinda a defense mechanism, I guess. Like, if I could make a joke about being pregnant, it felt…less scary. Less *real*, maybe? 

Honestly, it was easier to deflect with a sarcastic comment than to actually *talk* about, like, the huge mess I'd gotten myself into. Talking about feelings? Super overrated. But cracking a joke? That felt manageable. Plus, it kinda threw people off. They weren't expecting a pregnant teenager to be, like, observant and snarky. They expected tears and drama, and I was all, "Nope, just a girl with a bun in the oven and a really dry wit."

It wasn't about *not* being scared or confused or whatever. It was about having some control, you know? Like, I couldn't control the fact that I was pregnant, or that I was giving the baby up for adoption. But I *could* control how I reacted. And making people laugh, or at least slightly uncomfortable, felt like a small victory. 

It also helped me deal with the adults. They were all so…earnest. And worried. And trying to *fix* things. Sometimes you just need to say something ridiculous to remind everyone that it's okay to not take everything so seriously. It's not like I was trying to be flippant, but sometimes a little levity is the only way to get through.

Ugh, okay, deep question right off the bat. Like, seriously? It's not like I *planned* on having a whole existential crisis alongside a burgeoning belly, you know? But yeah, it totally shaped everything.

See, before… the whole Paul thing… I was pretty good at being… detached. Like, observing life instead of *living* it. I had my sarcastic shield up, my music, my friends… it was a good system for avoiding actually *feeling* stuff. I thought being weird was enough. Being different. It was a whole aesthetic, really.

Then suddenly, BAM. Positive pregnancy test. And it wasn't just about *me* anymore. It was about this little person, and what was best for *them*. And that… that cracked the shield. It forced me to actually think about what I wanted, not just what I wanted to *appear* to want. 

I mean, I always thought I knew who I was. A cynical, music-obsessed teenager who liked vintage clothes and didn't really care what people thought. But being pregnant… it made me realize that was just a *version* of me. A carefully constructed one. 

The vulnerability part? That was the hardest. Letting people *in*. Letting Bleeker see past the sarcasm, letting my dad actually be a dad, letting Vanessa… well, Vanessa was always pretty good at seeing through me anyway. But even *admitting* I was scared, or confused, or just plain overwhelmed… that was rough. It felt like giving up control.

But honestly? It was also kinda… freeing. Because once you admit you don't have all the answers, you can actually start *finding* them. And figuring out who I was, what I believed in, what I wanted my life to be… that wasn't about being weird or different anymore. It was about being *real*. And that, I think, is way cooler.

Ugh, okay, so like, people always wanna talk about the *hard* parts, right? The whole pregnant-teenager thing, the adoption, the awkwardness... but honestly? It wouldn't have been remotely manageable without a few key people not totally losing their minds on me.

My dad, Paul, he was... surprisingly chill. Like, not *happy*, obviously, but he didn't freak. He just started building furniture for the baby. Which, okay, a little weird, but also kinda sweet. It was his way of processing, I guess. And he always just... listened. No lectures, no "I told you so's." Just, "What do *you* want to do, Juno?" That was huge.

And then there's Bren. My stepmom. She's... intense. Like, really into essential oils and positive affirmations. But she was a lifesaver. She took me to all the appointments, helped me pick out names (which was a disaster, let me tell you), and just generally made sure I was eating something other than cheetos and listening to The Moldy Peaches. She was the practical one, you know? The one who made sure I wasn't completely falling apart.

Even Leah, my best friend, even though she was kinda horrified at first, she came around. She didn't understand everything, and she definitely had her moments of being a little judgy, but she was *there*. She still hung out with me, still let me vent, still let me be... me.

Honestly, it wasn't just *what* they did, it was that they let me make my own decision. They didn't try to push me one way or another. They just offered support, and a lot of weird, comforting advice. It made me feel... less alone. And when you're dealing with something that feels as huge and scary as this, feeling less alone is, like, everything. 

It's weird, you know? You think you have to be all strong and independent and figure everything out yourself. But sometimes, the strongest thing you can do is let people help. It doesn't make you weak, it just makes you... human. And maybe a little less stressed.

Ugh. Okay, so, picture this. I'm sitting on the bathroom floor, staring at this little plus sign, and it's... not exactly a party in my pants, you know? It wasn't like in the movies, all dramatic music and gasping. It was more like... a really awkward silence. Like, the universe just paused and was waiting for me to say something brilliant, and all I could manage was a very un-brilliant "Well, *shoot*."

Honestly? Mostly I was annoyed. Annoyed that this happened. Annoyed that I had to deal with it. Annoyed that my life, which was already complicated enough with school and trying to figure out what even *is* a future, just got a whole lot more... populated. 

It wasn't *scary* right away, not in a screaming-into-a-pillow kind of way. It was more... logistical. Like, "Okay, this is a thing. What do I *do* with a thing?" And then, after the logistical stuff started to sink in, came the weirdness. Like, I was still eating tater tots and listening to The Moldy Peaches, and suddenly I was... growing a person. It was a lot to process, okay? A *lot*.

It wasn't ideal, let's just say that. But, you know, life rarely is. And I figured, panicking wasn't gonna magically un-pregnant me. So, I just... dealt with it. The Juno way. Which mostly involves a lot of sarcasm and trying not to think about it too much.

Ugh, okay, so that's a *big* question. Like, seriously, a whole mess of feelings wrapped up in one. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a stumble through a minefield of awkward silences and people trying *way* too hard to be supportive.

With my dad, Paul? He was... surprisingly cool. Like, genuinely cool. He didn't freak, didn't yell. He just kinda... processed it. And then started building a nursery. Which was weird, honestly. A little preemptive, considering I hadn't even decided what to *do* with the baby yet. But it was his way of showing he cared, I guess. He's a quiet guy, my dad. Shows affection through practical stuff.

My stepmom, Bren? She was a saint. Seriously. She was all about the prenatal vitamins and making sure I was eating enough, and just generally being a mom to me, even though... well, you know. She was the one who really helped me navigate the whole adoption thing, too. She's got a good head on her shoulders.

But my friends... Leah and Renee? That was... complicated. They tried, they really did. But it was like, suddenly I was this *other* thing. Like I'd been beamed down from another planet. They were still dealing with boys and cheerleading and stuff, and I was... growing a human. It created this distance. It wasn't their fault, exactly. It's just... hard to relate when your life takes a sharp left turn into "unexpected motherhood" territory. 

Leah eventually came around, thankfully. She's the sensible one. Renee... well, Renee's still Renee. A little dramatic, a little self-absorbed, but she means well. 

It definitely changed things. It made me realize who my *real* friends were, you know? The ones who stuck around, even when things got weird. And it made me appreciate my family, even the slightly awkward parts. Because, honestly, who else is gonna build you a nursery when you're sixteen and pregnant?

Ugh, okay, so, coping. That's a *big* word, right? Like, it implies I had some master plan or something. Honestly? Mostly I just...talked. A lot. And not, like, deep, meaningful talks all the time. More like, sarcastic observations about the sheer absurdity of the whole situation. It was a good defense mechanism, I think. If you can make fun of it, it feels...less scary?

Bleaker, though, was just *feeling* everything. Like, one minute I'd be totally fine, eating a peanut butter sandwich and listening to The Moldy Peaches, and the next I'd be staring into space wondering what my life was gonna look like. It was weirdly exhausting. 

Paulie Bleeker was... surprisingly good at just *being there*. Not trying to fix things, not offering advice unless I asked for it. Just...quietly supportive. Which, for Paulie, is a major accomplishment. And my stepmom, Bren, she was a lifesaver. She didn't freak out, she didn't judge. She just...helped me figure stuff out. 

It wasn't easy, obviously. There were definitely days I wanted to just curl up in a ball and disappear. But I figured, wallowing doesn't exactly get you anywhere. You gotta, like, acknowledge the mess and then try to find a way through it. Even if that way involves a lot of really awkward conversations and a whole lot of feeling like a total weirdo.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You wanna talk about *that*? It's not exactly a fun topic for casual conversation, you know? But fine. Let's unpack this.

Havenbrooke... that place was *creepy*. Like, seriously, aggressively pro-life creepy. All those pictures of, like, perfectly formed little toes and stuff. It felt less like a clinic and more like a guilt trip factory. And the lady there? She kept calling it a "little person." A *little person*! I hadn't even decided anything yet and I already felt like I was being judged harder than in history class.

Women Now, though? It was... different. It felt real. Like, they understood that this wasn't some black and white, easy decision. They didn't try to shame you or tell you what to do. They just, like, *told you your options*. And honestly, the waiting room had way better magazines. Important stuff, you know? 

Plus, the counselor there, she was cool. She didn't try to sugarcoat anything, but she wasn't all doom and gloom either. She just... listened. And that's what I needed. Not a lecture, not a guilt trip, just someone to listen while I figured out what *I* wanted.

So yeah, Havenbrooke was a hard pass. Too much judgment, too much weirdness, and not enough *Us Weekly*. It's a big decision, and I needed a place that felt... less like a hostage situation.

Ugh, okay, seriously? That's the *first* thing you ask? It's not like I planned a whole production around it, you know? It just... happened. Bleeker and I were hanging out after school, listening to The Moldy Peaches – which, in retrospect, is kinda ironic, don't you think? – and we were both feeling… I don't know, kinda connected. He's a sweet guy, Paulie. A little clueless, maybe, but sweet. 

Honestly, I think we were both just trying to figure stuff out. We were both virgins, which, looking back, was probably not the smartest move. It wasn't like some grand romantic gesture or anything. It was just… impulsive. A moment. And then, well, a moment turned into a whole *thing*. 

It's not something I regret, exactly. It led to… well, it led to everything. But it wasn't some deeply thought-out decision, if that's what you're getting at. Sometimes things just *happen*, you know? And then you gotta deal with the consequences. Which, in my case, involved a lot of pregnancy tests and a whole lot of thinking.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look, don't get me wrong, he's... a good kid. Really. Like, genuinely sweet. And he plays guitar, which is, you know, marginally cool. But seriously, the whole thing was just... a moment of weakness, okay? A really, *really* awkward moment of weakness fueled by Funyuns and a shared appreciation for Phantom Planet. 

It wasn't *love*. It was... teenage stuff. Like, the kind of stuff they warn you about in health class, but you think won't happen to *you*. He's a little... intense, you know? Like, everything is a profound statement with him. And he's always looking at me like I'm some kind of mythical creature. It's flattering, I guess, but also kinda creepy.

Honestly? I think we were both just lonely. And maybe a little bored. But now? Now he's... Bleeker. The guy who made this whole situation happen. He tries, he really does, to be supportive. He brings me orange juice and asks about appointments and stuff. It's... nice. But it doesn't change the fact that we're fundamentally different people. 

He's a poet. I'm... well, I'm just trying to get through the day without anyone asking me if I'm showing yet. So yeah. Bleeker. He's... complicated. And mostly, he's just a reminder of a really bad decision made while under the influence of processed cheese snacks.

Ugh, okay, so like, everyone always asks that. It's not like I *wanted* to, you know? It's not like I was strolling through life thinking, "Oh, wouldn't it be *fun* to give a baby to someone else?" That's...weird.

It just kinda became clear, the more I thought about it. I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted for *lunch*, let alone a whole human life. Paul, he was...well, Paul. Sweet, but definitely not ready to be a dad. And my parents? They were amazing, supportive, but I could see the worry in their eyes. They'd just gotten their lives back on track, you know? 

Honestly, it felt selfish to bring a kid into the world when I wasn't really equipped to give them everything they deserved. Like, a stable home, financial security, someone who was actually *excited* to be a parent, not just...trying to be responsible. 

Mark and Vanessa, they were...different. They *wanted* a baby. They were ready. They had a beautiful house, a garden, and they just...radiated this calm, happy energy. It felt right. It felt like the best thing for the kid. 

It wasn't easy, obviously. It still isn't, sometimes. But knowing that little kid is going to have a good life, a *great* life, with people who adore them? That makes it...okay. It makes it the right thing. It's complicated, okay? Life is just...complicated. And sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

Ugh. Okay, so, telling Paulie... Bleeker... about the whole situation? It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a stumble through a minefield of awkward silences and half-eaten mozzarella sticks. We were at that diner, the one with the really chipped Formica tables, and I'd been practicing what I was gonna say in my head for, like, a week. But then I opened my mouth and it just came out all jumbled and weird. 

He just... stared. Like a deer caught in headlights, except the headlights were my news and he was a very confused deer. He didn't say anything for a *long* time. Which, honestly, was worse than if he'd yelled. It felt like the air was getting thicker and thicker. 

He eventually mumbled something about needing air, and then just... bolted. Like, *ran* out of the diner. I felt kinda bad, I guess. But also, a little bit relieved? It was a pretty big thing to drop on someone, especially someone who's still figuring out how to parallel park. 

It wasn't the reaction I was hoping for, obviously. I mean, I wasn't expecting a parade or anything, but a little "wow, that's... a lot" would have been nice. But hey, that's Paulie. Sweet, but not exactly equipped to handle, like, *life*. It was a good first test, though. Showed me I needed to be the one taking charge of this whole thing, you know? 'Cause nobody else was gonna do it for me.

Ugh. Okay, so, becoming a mother? Like, officially? It's... a lot. It's not exactly something you plan for when you're, you know, obsessing over Phantom Planet and trying to figure out if Paulie Bleeker is *actually* cute or if I'm just desperate. 

Honestly, at first it was mostly just panic. Like, full-blown, hyperventilating-in-the-bathroom panic. I mean, I'm sixteen! I still haven't even decided what I want to *be* when I grow up, let alone raise a tiny human. 

But then... it kinda settled. It's still scary, don't get me wrong. But it's also... weirdly okay. I'm not gonna lie, the idea of having a little mini-me running around is kinda tempting. But I also know I'm not ready. Not even close. I need to, like, *live* a little first. Figure out who *I* am, before I'm responsible for another person. 

So, yeah. It's complicated. It's a big, messy, complicated thing. And honestly? It's kinda making me think about stuff I never even considered before. Like, what does it even *mean* to be a good parent? And what do *I* want out of life? It's a lot to unpack, you know?

Ugh. Okay, so, Bleeker. That's... a whole thing. Honestly? Before all *this* happened, he was mostly just... there. A sweet, kinda dorky guy who was good at guitar and didn't, like, try to be all macho or whatever. We bonded over our mutual love of vintage stuff and hating gym class. It wasn't exactly a whirlwind romance, you know? More like a slow, comfortable...drift.

Now? It's...awkward. Super awkward. He's trying, I'll give him that. He brings me orange juice and tries to make conversation that *doesn't* involve the baby, which is nice, I guess. But it's like he's walking on eggshells. And I get it. He's sixteen! He's not exactly equipped to handle this. 

I think it'll probably...fade. Not because we *want* it to, but because it kinda *has* to. We're not exactly building a future together, you know? I'm giving the baby up for adoption, and he's...well, he's Bleeker. He's gonna go to college and probably become a really good musician. We'll probably just become those people who vaguely remember a thing that happened in high school. 

It's sad, kinda. But honestly? It's probably for the best. Trying to force something out of this would just be...messy. And nobody needs more mess right now. It's already a pretty complicated situation as it is.

Ugh. Okay, so the pressure? It's... a lot. Like, imagine everyone suddenly deciding they're an expert on *your* life, even though most of them can barely pick out a matching pair of socks. It's supremely annoying. 

Honestly, the initial reaction was mostly staring. Just... gaping. Like I'd suddenly sprouted a second head or something. Then came the whispers, which are *way* worse than people actually saying something to your face, because you just *know* they're making stuff up. Like, "Oh, she totally planned this for attention!" Please. Attention? I was perfectly happy blending into the background with my existential dread and Phoebe Waller-Bridge obsession, thank you very much.

I mostly just deflected with sarcasm. It's a good defense mechanism, you know? If someone looks at you sideways, you just hit 'em with something like, "Oh, you're concerned? That's... sweet. Did you bring snacks?" It throws people off. They're expecting tears or drama, and you're just offering them a polite inquiry about their grocery shopping.

But it wasn't *all* bad. Some people, like my friend Leah, were actually cool. And my dad... well, he's my dad. He's weird, but he's supportive in his own, slightly awkward way. 

The judgment still stings, though. It's like people think they get to decide what's right for you, without knowing anything about your situation. But you know what? It's *my* situation. And I'm making the best decision I can. And honestly, dealing with all the drama just makes you grow up a little faster. It's not fun, but it's... something. It makes you realize who actually cares about *you*, and who's just along for the spectacle.

Ugh, okay, so, the adoption process. It's...a lot. Like, a *lot* of paperwork. Seriously, I think I've signed my name more in the last few months than I have in my entire life. And meetings. So. Many. Meetings. With social workers and lawyers and Mark and Vanessa. It's not exactly a party, let me tell you.

But, like, underneath all the bureaucracy and the awkward conversations about baby names and nursery colors...it feels...right. Which is weird to say, 'cause it's not exactly a decision you make lightly, you know? It's not like picking out a new pair of Converse. 

I mean, I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raising a tiny human. And honestly? I don't think I'd be a good mom *right now*. Not a good enough one, anyway. 

So, choosing Mark and Vanessa...they just seemed...good people. Like, genuinely good. They *want* a kid, and they can give it a life I just...can't. It doesn't make it easy, though. It's kinda like giving away a piece of yourself, even before you've really met the piece. 

It's complicated. Everything about this is complicated. But I think...I *hope*...I'm doing the best thing. For everyone. And honestly, sometimes I just try not to think about it too much, and focus on finishing my English paper. That's complicated enough on its own.

Ugh. Okay, so, like, *challenging* is putting it mildly. It's less a challenge and more a full-on demolition of everything I thought I knew about myself. Before, I was just...Juno. A girl who liked records, hated gym class, and was pretty good at spotting a poser from a mile away. I had a five-year plan that involved art school and maybe, *maybe*, moving to Portland. 

Then, BAM. Positive pregnancy test. Suddenly, "Juno" wasn't just Juno anymore. It was "Juno, the pregnant one." And that felt...sticky. Like I was defined by this *thing* happening *to* me, instead of being, you know, a person making choices.

It forced me to grow up, yeah, but not in the way people think. It wasn't about suddenly wanting to knit or something. It was about realizing that life doesn't follow a script. You can plan all you want, but then a rogue positive test comes along and throws everything into chaos. 

I had to figure out what *I* wanted, not what everyone else expected of me. My parents, bless their quirky hearts, were supportive, but they also had their own ideas. And everyone at school? Forget about it. Whispers, stares...it's exhausting. 

So, it wasn't just about being a mom, even for nine months. It was about figuring out who *I* was going to be, with or without a baby. It's about realizing that being responsible isn't about doing what's easy, it's about doing what's right, even when it's really, really hard. And honestly? It's still a work in progress. I'm still figuring it out. But at least now I know I'm capable of more than I thought. Even if that "more" involves a lot of morning sickness and awkward conversations.

Ugh, lab partner. Okay, so, it's...complicated. Paulie Moses is my partner, which is already a strike against humanity, honestly. He's, like, *super* into science, which is fine, I guess, if you're into memorizing the periodic table and getting really excited about dissecting frogs. I mostly just try to look busy and make sarcastic comments. 

It's not that I *hate* science, it's just...it feels kinda pointless sometimes, you know? Like, what am I gonna do with knowing the difference between mitosis and meiosis in real life? Probably nothing. So I mostly contribute by, like, pointing out the obvious or asking questions that are deliberately dumb just to mess with Paulie. He gets all flustered. It's mildly entertaining.

I'm pretty good at the actual *doing* part, though. I can follow instructions. And I'm surprisingly good with a scalpel. Don't ask. 

Basically, I'm the voice of reason and mild chaos in the lab. And I make sure Paulie doesn't take himself *too* seriously. Someone's gotta do it.

Ugh, that ad. Yeah, I saw it. All pastel colors and…optimism. Like getting pregnant is some kind of *choice* you make when picking out curtains. Honestly, it felt kinda…icky. Like they were trying to sell me something, and what they were selling was…well, you know. 

It wasn't, like, screaming "ABORTION!" or anything, which I guess is their tactic. More like whispering "options" with a really forced smile. It just felt…disingenuous. Like they didn't *get* it. It's not a decision you make lightly, you know? It's not like choosing between vanilla and chocolate. 

And the whole "Women's Choice" thing? Please. Like there's a ton of choices when you're sixteen and staring down the barrel of a baby. It's more like a limited menu, and none of the options are particularly appealing. 

I mean, I get they gotta advertise, gotta stay in business. But it just rubbed me the wrong way. It felt…simplistic. Life isn't simplistic. Especially not *this*.

Ugh, seriously? You're asking me about the *phone*? Like, that's the most interesting thing about all of this? Okay, fine. I'll indulge you.

It was a whim, okay? A totally impulsive, "I need a phone and this looks ironically awesome" kind of whim. My friend Paulie found it at a flea market, and it was five bucks. Five bucks! You can't beat that. Plus, it just felt...right. Like, if you're gonna be dealing with something *huge* and kinda scary, you might as well do it while talking into a hamburger. It's a little bit of control, you know? A little bit of "I'm still me, even though everything is changing." 

Honestly, it was way more comfortable than I expected. And it definitely got a reaction out of people. Which, let's be real, is always a bonus. It's just...a statement. A very greasy, sesame-seed-covered statement. Don't read too much into it.

Ugh, okay, so like, it's not exactly a super fun story, but here we are. Honestly? I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what kind of music I even *liked*, let alone how to raise a human. I mean, I can barely keep my cactus, Prickly, alive, and he just needs water, like, once a month. A baby needs…everything. 

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, exactly. It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. A real home, you know? Parents who were, like, actually ready. Paulie Bleeker – sweet guy, don't get me wrong – and I were…well, we were Paulie Bleeker and me. We were good at hanging out and eating tater tots, not good at mortgages and college funds.

My parents, they were amazing. They didn't freak out, which was a relief. They just…helped me think it through. And it just felt right. Like, giving the baby to Mark and Vanessa, they were already *prepared*. They wanted a kid so badly. It felt way more responsible than, like, trying to wing it and ending up with a kid who resented me for not being able to give them the life they deserved. 

It wasn't easy, obviously. It still isn't, sometimes. But it was the best decision. For everyone. And honestly? It taught me a lot about myself. Like, I'm surprisingly good at making tough choices. And I really, *really* like tater tots. But that's a different story.

Ugh, okay, so family. That's... a whole thing, right? It's not like I grew up in, like, a Norman Rockwell painting or anything. My dad's a super chill dude, always building stuff in the garage, and my stepmom, Bren, she's...intense about landscaping. Like, *really* intense. They're good people, don't get me wrong, but they're...*them*. And I'm...well, I'm me.

Growing up with them, seeing how they made things *work*, even when it was kinda weird, definitely played a part. They weren't, like, perfect parents, you know? They had their own stuff going on. And I realized pretty quickly that bringing a baby into *my* life, at that point, wouldn't be fair to anyone. Not to me, not to the baby, and honestly, probably not even to them. 

It wasn't that they wouldn't have helped, I think they would have. Bren would have probably tried to knit the baby a whole wardrobe. But it wasn't about *help*. It was about giving the kid the best possible shot. A real family, a stable home, people who were, like, *ready* for it. 

I saw how much work it took to keep a household running, even a relatively normal one. And I was still figuring out what *I* wanted to do with my life, you know? I was sixteen! I was barely figuring out what kind of music I liked consistently. I wasn't ready to be someone's *mom*. 

So, yeah. My family showed me what a good family *could* be, and that made me realize I wanted that for the baby, even if it wasn't with me. It's kinda messed up, I guess, but it felt...right. Does that make any sense? It's hard to explain. It's not like I just woke up one day and was all, "Yep, giving it up!" It was a lot of thinking, and a lot of watching my parents, and realizing I wasn't quite there yet.

Ugh, okay, so like, that's a *big* question. It's not like I woke up one morning and was suddenly all, "Ta-da! I know who I am!" It was...messy. It's not like I wanted to, like, own the kid from afar or anything. I just...it's *my* baby, you know? Even if I'm not raising it. It's kinda growing *in* me, for crying out loud. So to hear it framed as just...cutting ties? It felt a little cold.

She explained the open adoption part, about getting letters and pictures and maybe even visits, and that helped. A lot. It meant I wouldn't just disappear from this kid's life completely. But still. "Terminated legal rights." Sounds like something you do to a bad contract, not a tiny human being you're trying to do the right thing by. 

It made me think, you know? About what "being a mom" even *means*. It's not just about the legal stuff, it's about...well, it's about a whole lot of stuff. And I was trying to figure out what *my* part in all of that was going to be. It was a lot to process, even for someone who's pretty good at compartmentalizing, which, let's be real, is a survival skill at this point.

Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, look, don't get me wrong, she seems...nice. Like, aggressively nice. The kind of nice that makes you wonder what she's hiding under all the Pottery Barn perfection. But wanting a kid *that* badly? It's a little intense, you know? Like, chill. Kids are people, not accessories to complete your life aesthetic. 

It's not that I don't *get* wanting a family, or whatever. But she's got this whole...project vibe going on. Like she's building a family from a catalog. Mark and I talked about it, and he said it's probably 'cause she and Phil haven't really...connected, you know? Like, emotionally. Which, honestly, is kinda sad. 

I guess it's good she's thinking about adoption, though. It's way better than, like, trying to force something that isn't there. But I just hope she's doing it for the right reasons. It's not about *her* getting a baby, it's about giving a baby a good home. A *really* good home. Does that make sense? It's just...a lot. And she's a lot.

Ugh, Mark. Don't even *get* me started on Mark. Honestly, the whole thing was... a lot. Like, he was trying *so* hard to be all mature and responsible, you know? All "I'm ready for this, I've been thinking about this since I was a kid," and the whole nine yards. 

It felt... rehearsed. Like he'd been watching a lot of those cheesy father-daughter commercials during the daytime. Which, okay, good for him for *thinking* about it, I guess. But it didn't feel *real*. It felt like he was trying to convince *himself* more than anyone else. 

And the thing is, he's a good guy, Mark. Really. Just... kinda clueless. Like a golden retriever who accidentally wandered into a philosophy class. He meant well, I know he did. But it was just... a lot of talk. And honestly, a little bit awkward. 

Vanessa, though? Vanessa was way more grounded. She actually *thought* about what it would mean to raise a kid, the actual nitty-gritty stuff. Mark was all about the *idea* of being a dad. Vanessa was thinking about diapers and college funds. Big difference.

It made me realize, you know, that being a parent isn't about saying you're ready. It's about *being* ready. And sometimes, even when you *think* you are, you're not. It's complicated. Everything is complicated.

Ugh, the Loring's house. Don't even *get* me started. It's not like they're *bad* people, okay? Mark and Vanessa are...intense. Like, aggressively wholesome. It's the kind of wholesome that feels…staged. Like they're auditioning for a Norman Rockwell painting 24/7. 

And everything is *beige*. Seriously. Beige walls, beige furniture, beige *everything*. It's a beige vortex designed to suck the personality right out of you. I feel like if I stayed there too long, I'd start talking about coordinating throw pillows and joining a book club. *Shudder*.

Plus, they just...watch you. Not in a creepy way, necessarily, but like you're a fascinating science experiment. "Oh, Juno's eating a Pop-Tart! How *interesting*." Like I'm some exotic creature they've never encountered before. I need a little chaos in my life, you know? A little…*not-beige*. Being around them makes me feel like I need to apologize for existing. It's just...suffocating.



So yeah, unsupervised time with the Lorings? No thank you. I'd rather hang out with Paulie Bleeker and his questionable musical tastes. At least *he's* real.

Ugh, okay, deep breaths. It's...complicated, alright? People keep saying "gift of life" like I'm handing over a freakin' puppy or something. It's a *person*, you know? A tiny human I'm currently baking. And it's not like I *wanted* to be giving a gift, necessarily. It just...happened.

But, look, Mark and Vanessa...they're good people. Really. They *want* this. Like, desperately. And that's...something. They can give this kid a life I just...can't. I'm sixteen, for crying out loud. I still haven't figured out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raise a little one. 

So, yeah, it's bittersweet. It feels weirdly selfless, which is not a feeling I'm used to. Mostly I feel sarcastic. But knowing they're excited, that they're gonna be good parents...it makes it a little less awful. It's not about *giving* something away, I guess. It's about giving something to someone who can actually *use* it, you know? 

It's just...a lot. Don't make me think about it too much, okay? It's easier to just make a joke about it. Or eat a peanut butter sandwich. Definitely easier to eat a peanut butter sandwich.

Ugh, Mark. Don't even *get* me started on Mark. It wasn't even the "ASAP" itself, okay? It was the *way* he said it. Like he was some super important executive or something. Like, dude, you sell furniture. And not even fancy furniture, like Pottery Barn stuff. More like...the stuff your grandma has. 

He was trying so hard to be all grown-up and efficient, and it just came off as… pathetic, honestly. It's like, chill, Mark. We're teenagers. We communicate in ironic detachment and passive aggression, not corporate jargon. "ASAP" just felt…wrong. It felt like he was trying to impress me, and honestly, the attempt was more embarrassing than if he'd just tripped and fallen into a display of recliners.

Plus, it's just a funny word. "A-S-A-P." Sounds like a robot trying to order a pizza. I couldn't help myself. Sometimes you just gotta point out the ridiculousness of things, you know? It's a survival mechanism. Keeps you from going completely insane in this weird world.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *guitars* right now? Like, people are asking me about, you know... *life* stuff, and you wanna know about my axe? Fine. Whatever. It's a good distraction, I guess.

Anyway, I'm pretty partial to a Fender Mustang. They're kinda quirky, you know? Not all flashy and trying too hard like a Les Paul. They're...understated. And they just *feel* right in my hands. Plus, they're not super expensive, which is good 'cause, let's be real, I'm not exactly rolling in dough. 

It's a good guitar for writing songs about, like, the existential dread of being a teenager, or the weirdness of everything happening right now. Or just, you know, complaining. It's versatile. And honestly? It just looks cool. Don't tell anyone I said that. It's important to maintain a certain level of detached coolness, you understand?

Ugh, okay, seriously? This is *still* coming up? It's not like I was trying to pass myself off as a groupie or something. It just...happened.

See, Paulie Bleeker, he's kinda...intense about music. And the Melvins? They're, like, *his* band. So when Mark and Vanessa were talking about them, and I had absolutely no clue who they were beyond a vaguely unpleasant name, I panicked. It felt like a test, you know? Like they were sizing me up to see if I was worthy of, like, handing their baby over to. 

I figured if I just *acted* like I knew them, it would be less awkward. Less...*me*. I mean, I'm good at pretending, okay? It's a survival skill. Plus, I figured they wouldn't actually *quiz* me on the Melvins' discography. I was wrong. So, so wrong.

It was a dumb move, I admit it. A totally unnecessary lie. But honestly? It was less about the Melvins and more about wanting to seem...normal. Like I had my life together enough to appreciate obscure noise rock. Which, let's be real, I definitely did *not* have together at that point. 

It's kinda pathetic when you think about it. But hey, everyone's got their weird moments, right? And mine just happened to involve a band I'd never heard of and a desperate attempt to appear cool. Don't judge.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, it wasn't... *romantic*, you know? Like, not in the way people immediately assume when a girl and a guy hang out. Honestly, it was kinda... comfortable. Weirdly comfortable. He's a bit of a dork, definitely, but a *sweet* dork. 

Playing guitar with him, singing those cheesy songs... it was a distraction, mostly. A good one, though. Like, the world is kinda falling apart around you and you're just trying to remember the chords to "Anyone Else But You" or something. It felt... normal. For a little while. 

He wasn't trying to, like, *fix* things, you know? He didn't treat me like I was broken or something. He just... played. And I played back. It was a way to just *be*, without having to talk about... everything. Which, let me tell you, was a *lot* to talk about. 

It was a connection built on bad music and shared awkwardness, I guess. Which, honestly, is a pretty solid foundation for... well, for *something*. Just not necessarily the forever kind of something. Does that make sense? It's hard to explain. It just *was*.

Ugh, seriously? People *still* ask about Roosevelt. It's not like it's a super deep, philosophical thing, okay? It just... fit. He's kinda boxy and solid, you know? Like Theodore Roosevelt. Plus, he's got this whole "rough rider" vibe going on, even though he mostly just sits in my room. 

Paul – that's my stepdad – he thought it was weird. He's always thinking things are weird. But Bleeker, he got it. He said Roosevelt was a man of action, and my guitar *could* be a man of action if I actually, like, *played* him more. Which, fair point. 

Honestly, it was just a spur-of-the-moment thing. I was looking at him, thinking about presidents, and Roosevelt just popped into my head. Don't overthink it. It's a guitar. It needed a name. And Roosevelt was available. It's not rocket science.

Ugh, okay, so Vanessa and Mark. They're...intense. Like, really into the whole "future parents" thing already. Which, honestly, is a little weird considering *I'm* the one currently housing the tiny human. It's not like they're just checking in, it's more like a progress report is *required*. 

Look, I get it. They're excited. They've been trying for, like, forever, right? And they're super nice, don't get me wrong. Mark makes a mean grilled cheese, seriously. But it's...a lot. 

Keeping them updated feels like I'm running a little baby business, you know? "Okay, week 18, baby's kicking, I'm craving pickles and ice cream, everything's proceeding as planned." It's just...not how I pictured this whole thing going down. I mean, I'm already dealing with my own stuff, trying to figure out what *I* want, and now I'm basically a walking, talking baby update machine.

But, I guess it's the right thing to do. They deserve to feel involved, and it's not like I can just ghost them. Plus, it's kinda nice knowing they're genuinely happy about it. It just...takes some getting used to, you know? It's a weird dynamic. A *very* weird dynamic.

Okay, well, first of all, "104%" is a totally legitimate percentage. Don't even *start* with me on the math. It just... feels more definitive, you know? Like, 100% is good, but it's kinda basic. 

But seriously. Why am I so sure? Look, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I spend most of my time trying to figure out if I should wear Converse or Vans with my jeans, and whether or not Paulie Bleeker is actually noticing my subtle attempts at being cool. I can barely keep a houseplant alive, let alone a *human*. 

It's not that I don't think I *couldn't* do it, because, like, people do it all the time. But it wouldn't be *fair*. Not to the kid, and honestly, not to me. I want to finish school, maybe go to college, write some stuff, figure out what I even *want* to do with my life that doesn't involve folding laundry and wiping noses. 

And honestly? There are people who *want* this. Mark and Vanessa? They're... good people. They're ready. They're excited. They've got a beautiful house and a dog that looks like a fluffy cloud. It feels... right. Like, the least messed up thing about this whole situation.

It's not easy, okay? It's kinda the opposite of easy. But it's the right thing. And sometimes, the right thing isn't the easiest thing. It's just... the thing you gotta do. Plus, I'm pretty sure my dad would lose his mind if I tried to raise a baby right now. And nobody needs *that*.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on Gerta and Mark. It was...weird. Like, seriously weird. I mean, I get it, right? They were finally getting the baby they wanted. And they were *really* into the whole perfect-family aesthetic. All the Pottery Barn Kids catalogs and the organic everything. It was a lot.

But walking out of there, and hearing them just...immediately launch into "Let's pick out wallpaper!" and "Oh, we need a rocking chair!" felt...off. Like I hadn't even *left* the room yet, and they were already erasing me. It wasn't malicious, I don't think. They were just...excited. And maybe a little relieved it wasn't *them* dealing with the whole nine months and the screaming and the diaper changes. 

It just felt...fast. Like they were trying to jump ahead to the happy ending without acknowledging the messy middle part. Which, you know, *was* me. And honestly? It made me feel kinda small. Like a delivery service. "Here's your baby, have a nice life!" 

But hey, they seemed happy. And that was the whole point, wasn't it? Still, it definitely made me want to go home and listen to The Moldy Peaches really loud. Needed to remind myself I was still *me*, you know? Not just a vessel for a baby.

Ugh. Rumors. Seriously? Like, people have *nothing* better to do than dissect my life and then whisper about it behind cupped hands like they're sharing state secrets? It's… irritating. Mostly irritating. And a little bit mortifying, honestly. 

It's not like I *wanted* to be the subject of the North Maplewood High gossip mill. It's not exactly a resume builder, you know? "Skills: Proficient in sarcasm, excellent taste in music, unexpectedly preggers." Doesn't exactly scream "future valedictorian," does it?

But whatever. People are gonna talk. They always do. I figure if they're spending all their energy worrying about *my* uterus, they're probably not focusing on their own messy lives, so… silver lining? Plus, the more they talk, the less they're paying attention to, like, the actual important stuff. Like whether or not Paulie Bleeker finally figured out how to tune his guitar. *That's* a tragedy. This? This is just… life. A weird, unexpected chapter, but life nonetheless.

Ugh. Okay, so, it's not like... *happy* happy, you know? Like, nobody's exactly throwing a party about it. It's more... complicated. It's like, I'm making a really big, adult decision, which is weird because I still feel like I should be figuring out what kind of eyeliner looks best, not, like, deciding a kid's future.

But honestly? It's probably the most responsible thing I *can* do. I mean, I'm sixteen. I play the ukulele. I'm not exactly equipped to raise a human. Not yet, anyway. I need to, like, finish high school, maybe figure out what I even *want* to do with my life that doesn't involve ironic t-shirts and a steady diet of cheesy poofs. 

It doesn't mean I don't... feel stuff. It's my kid, right? Even if I'm not keeping it. It's just... I want this kid to have a good life. A *stable* life. And Mark and Vanessa? They seem... good. Like, really good. They want a kid, and they can *give* a kid a good life. 

So yeah, it sucks. It's gonna suck a lot. But it's... okay. It has to be. It's just... a really big, messy, complicated okay. Does that make any sense? It's hard to put into words, you know? It's not like there's a chapter in a book about this.

Ugh, okay, so like, everyone keeps asking me about the whole surprise thing with Mark and Vanessa. It's not some *huge* philosophical statement, alright? It's just...they're really, really prepared. Like, they've got the nursery decorated, the clothes picked out, the whole nine yards. Everything is *blue*. Seriously, it's a Smurf convention waiting to happen.

And honestly? I kinda wanted to mess with them a little. They're good people, don't get me wrong. Super nice. But they're also...intense planners. I figured a little curveball, a little "Oh, hey, it's a girl!" might be good for them. Force them to, like, *react* instead of just ticking things off a list. 

Plus, it felt...right. Like, this baby deserves a little bit of mystery, you know? It's *their* baby, but it started with *me*. And I didn't know what it was 'til pretty late. So letting them experience that same little bit of the unknown felt...fair. 

It's not about wanting drama, okay? It's about letting them have a moment that isn't perfectly orchestrated. A moment that's just...real. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit funny. Because let's be honest, a room full of blue for a girl? That's pretty hilarious.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on that lady. Seriously. Like, I get it, she probably sees a lot of… situations. But the *tone*, you know? It was all, "Oh, you're so young, are you *sure* about this?" and then a whole lecture about how adoption isn't just "giving a baby away" like it's a Beanie Baby or something. 

It was just… presumptuous. Like she thought she knew my life story based on, what, my age and the fact I was lying on a table having a picture taken of a tiny human growing inside me? Newsflash: not all teenage moms are tragic cases waiting to happen. Some of us actually *think* things through. 

And the adoption thing? Yeah, I *know* it's not easy. I'm not an idiot. I'd been doing research, talking to people. It's a big deal, obviously. But she made it sound like I hadn't even considered the emotional weight of it all. Like I was just casually picking out a new pair of shoes.

Honestly, it just made me want to roll my eyes so hard they got stuck. It's my life, my decision. And frankly, I didn't need a stranger in a sterile room telling me how to feel about it. It just felt… condescending. And nobody likes being talked down to, especially when you're already dealing with, you know, *this*.

Ugh, challenges. Like, where do I even *begin*? It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, cool, a baby! Let's just find some nice people and hand it over!" 

First off, telling my parents was...intense. My dad, he's a pretty quiet guy, but he just kinda looked like someone had punched him in the stomach. And my stepmom, Bren? She was trying to be supportive, but you could tell she was picturing her perfectly curated life just...imploding. It was awkward. *Really* awkward.

Then there was school. Trying to navigate high school while simultaneously growing a human inside you? Not easy. People whisper. They stare. Some are just plain rude. And the whole "teen mom" stereotype? It's a thing. People automatically assume you're, like, incapable of tying your shoes, let alone making a rational decision.

But honestly, the biggest challenge wasn't the physical stuff, or even the judgment. It was figuring out what *I* wanted. Like, really wanted. It wasn't about what my parents wanted, or what Paulie Bleeker thought, or even what society expected. It was about what was best for the baby, and for me. And that took a lot of thinking. A *lot*. 

And then finding Mark and Vanessa Dursley... that was a whole other level of complicated. They were...perfect. Too perfect, almost. It made me question if I was doing the right thing, if I was good enough. You know? It's weird giving a piece of yourself to people you barely know, hoping they'll love it more than you ever could.

So yeah, challenges. There were a bunch. But I guess that's just life, right? It's messy and complicated and sometimes you just gotta roll with it, even if it involves a whole lot of awkwardness and a tiny human.

Ugh, okay, deep thoughts time. Don't get me wrong, I still think romantic love is mostly just…overrated. Like, all those movies? Total garbage. But *this*… this isn't about finding a boyfriend, you know? It's about wanting something good for someone, even if that someone hasn't even *arrived* yet. And that's… different. It's not all hearts and flowers and slow dancing. It's more like, wanting to give someone the best possible start, even if that start is with someone else. Which is kinda messed up to even *say* out loud, honestly.

Responsibility? Oh, man. Before, responsibility was like, doing my homework and not failing history. Now? It's…bigger. It's realizing actions have consequences, and those consequences aren't always about *you*. It's about thinking ten steps ahead, and not just about what I want for lunch. It's about making a really hard decision and sticking to it, even when it sucks. And it *really* sucks sometimes.

Growing up… well, that was always gonna happen, right? But I thought I had, like, a few more years to be a cynical, music-obsessed teenager. This kinda fast-forwarded things. It forced me to deal with stuff that most kids my age don't even *think* about. It's like, I skipped a few levels in the game of life, and now I'm trying to figure out the cheat codes. 

Honestly, it's made me realize that growing up isn't about becoming some perfect, put-together adult. It's about figuring out who you are *while* you're messing things up. And learning to be okay with that. And maybe, just maybe, finding a little bit of grace along the way. It's still weird, though. Really weird. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh, okay, so like, everyone in town is obsessed with that living room set. It's seriously weird. It just... appeared. One day it was a normal, kinda sad-looking lawn, the next BAM! Full-on, perfectly arranged living room. Couch, armchair, coffee table, even a little lamp. Like someone just *deposited* a slice of suburban life in the middle of nowhere.

Honestly? It's kinda fascinating. It's like a weird art installation, or a really passive-aggressive message to someone. Paulie Bleeker thinks it's aliens. Which, you know, is Paulie. But I get why people are drawn to it. It's...unexpected. 

I went by there with Leah the other day and we were trying to figure out the story. Like, did someone just decide they didn't want a living room anymore? Did they get evicted and just *leave* it? It makes you think, you know? About people's lives and how quickly things can change. Plus, it's a good place to sit and eat a Super Nintendo-themed pop tart without anyone bugging you. Don't tell anyone I said that. It's my spot.

Ugh, okay, seriously? Still thinking about the Wizard. That guy was… a lot. And creepy. Like, a *lot* creepy.

When he said that, all whispery and intense, "Do you know how long I've wanted this?"... it wasn't about *me*, okay? It wasn't like he was thrilled I was there, hanging out, being all cool and Juno-like. It was about the baby. He and Vanessa were, like, *desperate* for a kid. They'd been trying for ages, and Vanessa couldn't... well, you know. It was kinda sad, actually, when you really thought about it. 

It was just... weirdly possessive, the way he said it. Like he'd been planning this for years. It made my skin crawl a little, honestly. It wasn't a sweet, "Oh, we're so happy to finally meet you and talk about giving this baby a good home" kind of vibe. It was more of a "Finally, my plan is coming together" vibe. 

It made me realize how much this meant to *them*, which was good, I guess. But it also made me double-check everything, you know? Make sure they were really the right people. Because a baby isn't a thing you just *want*. It's a person. And that's a pretty big difference.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about the *juice container*? Like that's the important part of the whole… situation? Fine. I'll tell you.

It wasn't just *any* juice container, okay? It was a Super Big Gulp Grape. And after finding out… well, after finding out I was, you know, *with child*, I needed a cigarette. Badly. Like, a "might actually hyperventilate if I don't get a nicotine fix" badly. 

And Dancing Elk is the only place around here that doesn't card. Not that I *need* to be carded, I just... prefer to avoid the whole awkward conversation. Plus, Paulie Bleeker was probably hanging around the school, and I didn't need *that* right then. 

So, yeah, I marched down the street, tossed the evidence of my momentary sugar-fueled panic, and went to get a smoke. It's called coping, okay? Don't judge. It's a whole thing. A really, really weird thing. And honestly, the juice was kinda gross anyway.

Ugh. *Seriously*? You wanna know about *that*? Okay, look, it was a whole thing. I was at the drugstore, right? Trying to be all nonchalant about buying a pregnancy test – which, let me tell you, is *not* nonchalant. It feels like you're buying, like, evidence or something. 

And this… this *Tough Girl* – that's what I started calling her in my head, because seriously, the audacity – she just *stared* at me. Like I was some kind of exhibit. Then, out of nowhere, she just blurts out, "Are those real brown?" referring to my nipples. 

I swear, I almost choked on my own spit. Like, excuse me? What does the pigmentation of my areolas have to do with anything? I think she was trying to, I don't know, assert dominance or something? Maybe she thought I was trying to pass off fake ones? I have no idea. People are weird.

I just kinda deadpanned and said, "Last time I checked." And then I grabbed my test and practically *ran* to the checkout. It was mortifying. Honestly, the whole pregnancy thing felt less awkward than *that*. It just proves, you can be dealing with a life-altering situation and still get blindsided by the sheer… strangeness of people. It's a good reminder that the world is full of weirdos, and you just gotta roll with it, you know?

Ugh, Leah. Don't even get me *started*. Not in a bad way, though. Honestly, I probably would've completely imploded without her. Like, seriously. Picture a supernova of awkwardness and teenage angst – that was me, pre-Leah intervention.

See, Leah's… well, she's *Leah*. Super into everything, always positive, always has a craft project going. It's a lot. But she's also the most genuinely good person I know. And when I told her… well, when I kinda blurted it out while we were playing video games (don't ask), she didn't freak. She didn't judge. She just… listened. 

Most people would've been all, "Juno, you're sixteen! What are you *thinking*?!" But Leah just asked if I needed help finding a good doctor, or if I wanted to, like, knit a tiny hat. A tiny hat! It was so… Leah.

She was the one who dragged me to all the appointments, pretended to be my mom on the phone (which was mortifying, but also kinda sweet), and just generally kept me from spiraling into a pit of self-pity. She was the one who reminded me I still had school, and band practice, and a life to live, even with a little person growing inside me. 

Honestly, she was the grounding force I desperately needed. She didn't try to *fix* things, she just… *was* there. And sometimes, that's all you need, you know? Especially when you're dealing with something as… complicated as this. She's a good egg, that Leah. A really, really good egg.

Ugh, okay, so *that*. Honestly? It wasn't some grand, thoughtful plan, alright? It was mostly just... desperation and a little bit of wanting to see if they'd, like, spontaneously combust with awkwardness. 

See, Mark and Vanessa, they're... *perfect*. Like, aggressively perfect. They have a Pottery Barn catalog for a life. And I was kinda worried they'd see me as this, you know, teenage mistake, a problem to be solved. I figured if they actually *saw* the little bean, the actual *proof* of the whole situation, maybe they'd connect with it as something more than just... me.

Plus, I was kinda hoping it'd freak Mark out a little. He's so... earnest. Like a golden retriever. I wanted to see if that earnestness could handle a tiny, blurry picture of a human being growing inside a girl he barely knows. 

It was a gamble, I admit. A pretty big one. But I figured, what's the worst that could happen? They say no? Fine. I'd just find someone else who wasn't so obsessed with matching throw pillows. It ended up being... well, you know how it ended up. Surprisingly okay. Though Mark *did* look like he was gonna faint. It was kinda satisfying, actually.

Ugh. Seriously? Like, *that* was the moment everything felt…real, you know? Before that, it was just…Mark being Mark, all awkward and kinda sweet in a dorky way. And me, trying to pretend I wasn't totally mortified. But when he said Vanessa wasn't home? It wasn't just about the, uh, *situation* anymore. It was about his life, and her not being there to deal with it. 

It was like a record scratch. Suddenly, it wasn't just a one-time thing. It was…complicated. And honestly? A little bit sad. I mean, people have stuff going on, right? But it made me realize this wasn't just *my* problem anymore. It was gonna ripple out and affect a whole bunch of people. 

I think I just kinda stared at him for a second, trying to process. Probably made a sarcastic comment, because that's my go-to when I'm freaking out internally. Something about how convenient it was she wasn't around to witness the disaster, probably. It's a defense mechanism, okay? Don't judge.

Ugh, okay, so *that*. Honestly? It wasn't even a fully formed thought, it just kinda...escaped. It's just...Mark's all, like, super into indie rock, right? Like, *really* into it. And then he's cheerfully admitting to selling out and doing commercials for, like, foot powder or something? It felt...wrong. Like a betrayal of everything he claimed to believe in. 

It's not that I have anything against people making money, okay? I get it. Life is expensive. But when you build your whole *persona* around being anti-establishment and then happily shill for athlete's foot cream...it's just kinda rich. 

Plus, it was a nervous reaction, probably. Talking to Mark is...intense. He's got a lot of *feelings*. And I deflect with humor. It's a coping mechanism, alright? Don't judge. It's better than bursting into tears, which, let's be real, is always a possibility with me.

Ugh, Mark. Don't even *get* me started. It was... a lot. Like, the guy went totally pale, then started rambling about how he needed to "re-evaluate his life choices." Re-evaluate? Seriously? We were looking at a little bean on a screen, not deciding whether to buy a timeshare. 

Honestly? It felt kinda… lonely. I mean, I knew he wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation, but I didn't expect him to look like I'd just told him the earth was flat. It made me realize, pretty quickly, that this wasn't something we were gonna navigate *together*, you know? He was just... processing. And not in a helpful, "let's figure this out" kind of way. More in a "oh my god, my life is over" kind of way.

It was a good wake-up call, though. It made me realize I was gonna have to be the one doing most of the heavy lifting, emotionally speaking. And honestly? I think I was already kinda prepared for that. It just… solidified things. Plus, it gave me some *excellent* material for internal monologue. You wouldn't believe the things I was thinking during that ultrasound. It was practically a one-woman show in my head.

Ugh, Havenbrooke. Honestly, the whole *vibe* of that place was…intense. Like, aggressively pro-life. Lots of pictures of babies, you know? And pamphlets. So. Many. Pamphlets. It felt less like a medical clinic and more like a guilt trip waiting to happen.

Look, it wasn't like I *wanted* to be pregnant, okay? It was…unexpected. And yeah, abortion was definitely on the table. I mean, it felt like the logical thing, right? I was sixteen, barely able to handle algebra, let alone a human being. 

But being *there*, at Havenbrooke, with all that…pressure…it just felt wrong. Not because I was suddenly all pro-life or anything. It was more like…they weren't offering me a choice, they were trying to *make* a choice for me. And honestly, being told what to do just makes me want to do the opposite. It's a reflex.

Plus, I started thinking about the baby, you know? Even though it was, like, a tiny little clump of cells at that point. It still felt…weird to just…not. So, I decided to look into adoption. It felt…more me. More complicated, sure, but also more…right. 

It wasn't easy, though. Don't get me wrong. It was a whole mess of feelings. But Havenbrooke? That place just felt…icky. Like they were trying to sell me something I didn't need. And I'm pretty good at spotting a sales pitch, even when it's disguised as concern.

Ugh. Okay, look. This is… a topic. It's not exactly something I volunteer to discuss, you know? Like, do *you* go around broadcasting details about… stuff like that? Didn't think so.

But fine. You asked.

Paulie Bleeker and I… we were friends first. Like, *really* friends. We bonded over a shared love of bad movies and a general disdain for pretty much everything mainstream. He's a sweet guy, Bleeker. A little… earnest, maybe. And definitely not the coolest kid in school. Which, honestly, was a plus. I'm not really into the whole popular scene. 

As for *when*… well, it was after a movie marathon. We were at his place, watching some seriously cheesy horror flick, and… things just happened. It wasn't, like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It was just… impulsive. We were both feeling kinda… whatever. And, you know, teenagers are dumb. 

Honestly, looking back, it was probably a really bad idea. Not because of *him*, necessarily. He's a good dude. But because, well, *this* happened. It's just… sometimes things happen, and you're left picking up the pieces. And trying not to freak out too much. 

It's complicated, okay? Don't judge. And please don't ask me for details. Seriously. I'm already reliving enough awkwardness as it is.

Ugh. Okay, so, like, *how* did I feel? That's a loaded question, right? It wasn't exactly a party in my uterus, let me tell you. It wasn't like I was planning on, you know, popping out a human anytime soon. Bleeker and I... well, let's just say it was a one-time thing. A really, *really* bad one-time thing fueled by cheese fries and a shared love of Phantom Planet. 

At first, it was mostly just... disbelief. Like, seriously? *Me*? Pregnant? I was still trying to figure out what to wear to school each day, let alone raise a tiny human. Then came the panic. And the nausea. Oh, the nausea. It was like my insides were staging a revolt.

But honestly? After the initial freak-out, it kinda settled into... acceptance. Not *happy* acceptance, mind you. More like, "Okay, this is happening. Now what?" I figured I had a responsibility, even if the dad was a sweet, but kinda clueless, indie-rock enthusiast. It wasn't ideal, not even close, but it was *my* situation. And I'm pretty good at dealing with situations, even the really weird ones. 

It was just... a lot. A lot to process. A lot to figure out. And a lot of really awkward conversations with my dad. He handled it surprisingly well, though. For a dad.

Ugh. Okay, so, telling Paulie... Bleeker. That was... a whole *thing*. It wasn't like some dramatic movie scene, you know? No slow motion, no swelling music. Just... awkward. Really, really awkward.

I found him after school, by the bike racks, naturally. He was trying to look cool leaning against them, all slouchy and pretending to not care about anything. Which, let's be real, is 90% of his existence. 

I just kinda blurted it out. Like ripping off a band-aid, except the band-aid was my entire future and it was covered in, like, glitter and regret. I think I said something along the lines of, "So, uh, remember that time we... you know?" And then I just *told* him. No beating around the bush. I figured the quicker the better, even if it meant facing the full force of his stunned silence.

And stunned he was. Like a deer in headlights. A really, really pale deer. He just... blinked. A lot. And then he mumbled something about needing to, like, "process." Which, okay, fair enough. Processing is good. But it took a *while*. 

Honestly, the worst part wasn't even *him* being freaked out. It was the look on his face. It wasn't anger, or disgust, it was just... completely overwhelmed. Like I'd handed him a Rubik's Cube made of existential dread. 

He eventually came around, though. He's a good kid, Paulie. Just... not always the quickest on the uptake. It took a lot of explaining, and a lot of me being, like, "Look, this is happening, and we need to figure it out." But he did. Eventually. It wasn't exactly a romantic moment, but it was... real. And that's more than I expected, honestly.

Ugh. Okay, so, like, it wasn't a party, obviously. It wasn't something I was *excited* about, you know? More like...the least terrible option. I mean, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out if I even *liked* history, let alone raising a human. 

It felt...weirdly responsible, actually. Like, a lot of people would have panicked and done something totally rash, but I thought about it. Really thought about it. And I realized I wanted this kid to have a life where they weren't, like, a weird footnote in my already complicated existence. 

It wasn't about *not* wanting the baby, exactly. It was about wanting the baby to have *more*. A real home, a stable life, parents who were, you know, actually ready for it. Mark and Vanessa...they were good people. Really good. And they *wanted* a kid. It felt...right, in a messed-up, complicated way.

There were definitely days where I wanted to just curl up in a ball and pretend it wasn't happening. And a lot of nights where I just...felt sad. But mostly, I kept telling myself I was doing the best thing. For everyone. Even if "everyone" included a tiny human I hadn't even met yet.

It's not like you just *get over* something like that, though. It sticks with you. It makes you think about stuff. Like, what you want out of life, and what it means to be a grown-up. And honestly? It made me realize I had a lot of growing up to do.

Ugh, okay, so people *always* ask me this. Like, my musical taste defines my entire personality or something. It's kinda reductive, honestly. But fine. I'll indulge.

It's...varied. I'm not one of those people who's like, "Oh, I *only* listen to indie folk." That's just...limiting. I mean, The Moldy Peaches are essential. Don't even *try* to argue with me on that. They just *get* awkwardness, you know? 

But then I also dig stuff like Cat Power, and Belle & Sebastian. Real mellow stuff for when I'm, like, contemplating the universe or whatever. And sometimes, when I just need to feel something *big*, I'll throw on some early Sonic Youth. It's loud and messy, kinda like...well, kinda like life, actually.

Oh, and don't forget The Kinks. My dad's a big fan, and it kinda rubbed off. Plus, they're just...classic. 

Basically, if it's got a good beat and doesn't try too hard to be cool, I'm probably into it. Does that make sense? It's not about a *genre*, it's about a *vibe*. You gotta feel the vibe.

Ugh. "The Wizard of Gore"? Seriously? Okay, look, Paulie Bleeker *insisted* we watch it. Said it was "so bad it's good." Which, honestly, is a pretty low bar, right? Like, a lot of things are so bad they're good. My auntie Lupe's crocheted toilet seat cover is so bad it's good. Doesn't mean I want to *look* at it.

Anyway, it was...intense. Like, aggressively cheesy. And the gore? Don't even get me started. It wasn't even *scary* gore, it was just...enthusiastic. Like someone had a really vivid imagination and a whole lot of red food coloring. 

Honestly, the whole thing felt like a metaphor for, I don't know, the absurdity of life? Or maybe just a really bad acid trip. I'm not sure. I was mostly just trying not to make eye contact with Paulie and pretend I wasn't simultaneously horrified and slightly amused. 

It's the kind of movie you watch and then immediately need to cleanse your palate with something wholesome. Like, a documentary about kittens. Or maybe just a really long nap. Definitely not something I'd recommend unless you're actively trying to lower your standards for cinema.

Ugh. Madison. Seriously? It's...fine, I guess. Like, perfectly *fine*. Which is the problem, you know? It's so...beige. It's the name you give a doll when you can't think of anything better. It feels like it should be paired with a matching headband and a tiny purse. 

Not that there's anything *wrong* with beige, per se. Some people *like* beige. But a person? A whole human being deserves a name with a little more...oomph. A little more *personality*. 

It's not offensively bad, don't get me wrong. It just feels...predictable. Like you met the girl and already knew her name was Madison. Does that make sense? It's like naming a cat "Fluffy." It's accurate, but where's the imagination?

Honestly, if someone asked *my* opinion on naming a kid Madison, I'd probably just nod and say, "That's...a name." And then subtly steer the conversation towards something involving French fries. Because French fries are *always* a good idea.

Ugh. Okay, look. It's not like... a fun topic, alright? It's not like picking out a new pair of Converse. But honestly? It felt...right. Weirdly right, considering the whole situation started with a really *wrong* decision, if you catch my drift. 

See, I'm not exactly equipped to be a mom right now. I'm still figuring out *myself*, you know? Like, what I want to *do* with my life besides listen to The Moldy Peaches and avoid gym class. And bringing a kid into that mess? That'd be selfish. Super selfish.

So, adoption... it felt like the least messed-up option. Like, giving the baby a chance at a life with people who *want* it, who are *ready* for it. Mark and Vanessa? They seemed...good. Normal. Like, actual grown-ups who have their stuff together. Which, let's be real, is a rare sighting these days.

It's not like I don't care, okay? It's just... caring isn't always enough. Sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is admit you can't do it yourself. It's complicated. Everything is complicated. But it felt like the right thing. And honestly? That's all that mattered.

Ugh. Okay, so, it's not like anyone *prepares* you for this, you know? Like, they tell you about puberty and awkward dances and trying to figure out if that guy in history actually *likes* you, or if he's just being nice because your mom baked cookies for the class. But nobody mentions the whole... accidental baby thing. 

It's a lot. Seriously. It's like, one minute you're obsessing over whether or not you can pull off orange eyeshadow, and the next you're staring at a positive pregnancy test and thinking, "Well, *this* is inconvenient."

The pressure? It's mostly from people *thinking* they know what's best for you. Like, suddenly everyone's a parenting expert. My dad, bless his heart, just kept offering me weirdly specific advice about diaper rash cream. And some people at school... well, let's just say they weren't exactly showering me with support. 

But honestly, the biggest challenge isn't the stares or the whispers. It's just... figuring out who *I* am in all of this. I'm still Juno. I still like bad horror movies and listening to The Moldy Peaches. I still want to go to college and maybe be a journalist. But now I'm also... a person who's making a really big decision. 

So, how do I handle it? I try to be sarcastic. A lot. It's a defense mechanism, okay? And I lean on the people who actually *get* it. Bleeker, my dad, even Paulie (eventually). And I just... take it one day at a time. Because freaking out doesn't really solve anything, except maybe give you a headache. It's messy, and complicated, and totally not what I expected my junior year to be. But it's *my* messy, and I'm trying to navigate it the best way I know how.

Ugh, that's... a big question. Like, existential crisis big. Honestly? It's a constant struggle. I *like* being able to do my own thing, you know? Not having to rely on anyone for anything. It feels... cleaner, I guess. Like, less messy. I can just decide, and *do*. 

But then, you get thrown a curveball the size of, well, a baby, and suddenly you realize "doing your own thing" involves a whole lot of things you didn't anticipate. And you can't exactly build a crib and navigate the whole adoption thing solo. 

So, you swallow your pride. Which is *hard*, let me tell you. It feels like admitting defeat, even though it's not. It's more like... recognizing that other people have stuff to offer. Like, my dad, he's a total goofball, but he's surprisingly good at, like, practical stuff. And Bren, even though she's a little... intense, she's always there to listen, even when I'm being a total weirdo. 

It's about picking your battles, I think. Knowing when to be stubborn and independent, and when to just say, "Okay, yeah, I need help with this." It's not about losing yourself, it's about realizing you don't *have* to do everything alone. And honestly? Sometimes letting people help is... nice. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, look, it started...awkward. Like, *really* awkward. He was this sweet, kinda dorky kid who played guitar and wore vintage tees, and I was...well, I was me. We had a moment, a *moment*, and then suddenly, BAM, positive pregnancy test. Not exactly the plot of a rom-com, you know?

At first, he was...panicked. Understandably, I guess. He was a senior, I was a junior, and suddenly we were facing, like, actual adult stuff. He tried to be supportive, bless his heart, but it mostly came out as him offering to name the baby "Paul Bunyan." Seriously. 

But then, things...shifted. He started showing up with weird, thoughtful gifts. Like, a vintage record player because he remembered me saying I liked Phoebe Buffay. And he actually *listened* when I talked, not just about the baby, but about school and my dad and everything. He wasn't trying to fix things, he was just...*there*. 

It wasn't a boyfriend-girlfriend kind of thing, not really. It was more like...we were in this crazy situation together, and we figured out how to be friends through it. Good friends. He was a really good friend. He understood I wasn't looking for a husband, just someone to, you know, share the weirdness with. 

Honestly, I think the pregnancy forced us both to grow up a little. He realized he wasn't just some quiet kid anymore, and I realized...well, I realized I wasn't as tough as I pretended to be sometimes. It was complicated, but it ended up being a pretty good complication, if that makes any sense. It wasn't a love story, but it was a story about finding a connection when you least expect it. And sometimes, that's even better.

Ugh, okay, seriously? This is like, the *first* question people ask. It's not some deep, philosophical thing, alright? My dad... he's kinda into mythology. Like, *really* into it. He and my stepmom, Bren, were naming me and he was going on and on about how Juno was, like, the queen of the gods and a protector of marriage and stuff.
