Honestly, I mostly tuned him out. I was a baby. But apparently, he thought it was ironic, considering he and my biological mom weren't exactly a picture of marital bliss. He said it was a "statement." 

Whatever. It's a name. It's not like I *chose* it. Though, honestly, sometimes I think it fits. I mean, I *am* pretty boss, even if I don't have a whole thunderbolt thing going on. And I definitely protect what's mine... which, right now, is mostly just my record collection and a decent amount of personal space.

So yeah, that's the story. Don't expect any more profound revelations, okay? It's just a name. A slightly weird name, granted.

Ugh, okay, so Vanessa. Right. Honestly? It was...weird. Like, I was expecting a whole *thing*, you know? Tears, maybe a dramatic fainting spell. She's, like, super put-together, always has a plan. So when she just...breathed a sigh of relief when she saw the picture? It threw me. 

She said something about needing to *know* it was actually happening, that it wasn't just some weird dream. Which, okay, fair enough, I guess. Being pregnant is pretty surreal. But it also felt...distant, you know? Like she was already processing it as something to *manage* instead of, like, a tiny human growing inside of me.

It made me think about how different we are, her and I. She's got her whole life mapped out, the perfect house, the perfect husband, the perfect everything. And me? I'm just trying to get through AP History without falling asleep. It was a good reminder that this whole adoption thing wasn't just about *me* giving a baby away. It was about giving a baby to a family who was ready for it, in their own way. Even if their "way" is a little...clinical.

It's just...people deal with stuff differently, I guess. And sometimes, relief looks a lot like...not freaking out. Which, honestly, I appreciated. A little. Don't tell her I said that.

Ugh, don't *even* get me started on Vanessa's mom, Brenda. Seriously, that woman is a whole *mood*. Like, a really intense, floral-print, passive-aggressive mood. 

Okay, so picture this: I'm chillin' with Vanessa, we're listening to The Moldy Peaches, and suddenly Brenda just *appears*. It wasn't a graceful entrance, either. More like a tactical strike. And the look on her face? Like I'd personally insulted her entire life choices.

She went straight for the "you're a bad influence" speech, which, honestly, is pretty rich coming from someone who decorates her house entirely with porcelain dolls. It's creepy, Brenda, seriously. Anyway, I just kinda... stared her down. I figured if I looked bored enough, she'd run out of steam. 

I think my exact words were something along the lines of, "Look, I get it. You're protective. But Vanessa and I are friends. And frankly, your house smells like potpourri and judgment." 

It didn't *completely* diffuse the situation, but it definitely threw her off. She sputtered for a bit, then started talking about my "future" and how I was "ruining" Vanessa's. I just kept repeating, "Okay," and nodding slowly. It's a good tactic. Makes people think you're listening when you're really just mentally composing a haiku about the absurdity of it all.

Honestly, the whole thing was exhausting. Brenda's rage is... a lot. It's like she's been saving it up for years. But I held my ground. You gotta, you know? People try to tell you what to do all the time, especially when you're, like, visibly messing up. You gotta learn to just... be. And sometimes, that means standing there while someone yells at you about porcelain dolls.

Ugh, okay, so like, it's not exactly a super fun story, you know? It wasn't like I *wanted* to, not in the "yay, giving a baby away!" kind of way. It was more...realistic. I mean, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what kind of music I even *liked* consistently, let alone raise a human. 

Paulie Bleeker – bless his awkward heart – he was supportive, but he was also, well, Paulie. And my parents? They were amazing, seriously. But they were already dealing with, like, their own stuff. My dad's a handyman, my mom decorates cakes... they weren't exactly prepared for a baby. Neither was I, honestly.

It just felt...right. Like, this kid deserved parents who were *ready*. Parents who had a house and a plan and weren't still figuring out if they wanted to go to college or become a rock star. Mark and Vanessa, they were...perfect. They *wanted* a baby, and they could give it everything. 

It wasn't easy, obviously. It's still not easy, thinking about it. But it felt less selfish to admit I wasn't ready than to try and pretend I was. You know? Sometimes the bravest thing you can do is admit you need help, or that you can't do something alone. And sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let someone else give a little person the best life possible.



Does that make sense? It's kinda hard to explain without sounding like a total downer.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on lab partners. Honestly? It's a whole thing. See, I'm not, like, actively *trying* to be a deadbeat. It's just... my brain kinda wanders. Like, you're supposed to be dissecting a frog or something, and I'm over here contemplating the existential dread of being a frog, or wondering if the formaldehyde fumes are giving me superpowers. 

And then I get distracted by, like, the *patterns* in the tile floor, or the way Mr. Burns' comb-over defies gravity. It's not that I don't *care* about science, it's just... everything else is so much more *interesting*. 

Plus, Paulie, my current lab partner, is super into memorizing the periodic table. Like, *really* into it. It's kinda terrifying. So I mostly just nod and pretend to be taking notes while internally composing song lyrics about the absurdity of it all. 

So yeah, "deadbeat" is probably a fair assessment. I'm more of a philosophical observer of science than an actual *participant*. It's a gift, really. A curse, maybe. Definitely a source of frustration for Paulie.

Ugh. Seriously? Another dramatic episode in the petri dish of high school? Look, I've seen enough passive-aggressive note-passing and eye-rolling to last a lifetime, okay? It's always *something* with those two. He probably didn't label his beakers properly, and she's acting like he personally insulted her mother. 

Honestly, it's exhausting. Like, can't people just *communicate*? It's not rocket science, even though we're, you know, *in* science. It's just... a lot. 

I usually just tune it out and focus on the frog dissection. Frogs don't judge your life choices, which is a definite plus. Plus, they're kinda cute in a slimy, amphibian way. Though, admittedly, dealing with a tiny, preserved frog feels a little less complicated than dealing with human emotions right now. Just sayin'. 

It's probably about something totally ridiculous, anyway. They'll be holding hands by lunch. Mark my words. Teenagers are weird.

Whoa, hold your horses. "Hasty abortion"? That's... a really loaded way to put it. It's not like I woke up one morning and was all, "Ooh, let's just *get rid* of it!" It's a little more complicated than that, okay?

Look, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I spend most of my time trying to figure out if I should wear Converse or beat-up boots with my jeans, not raising a human. And honestly? My life is... not exactly set up for a baby. My dad's a handyman, my stepmom's a realtor who's obsessed with wreaths, and I mostly just hang out with Bleeker and Paulie. They're good guys, don't get me wrong, but they're not exactly equipped to change diapers and sing lullabies. 

So, yeah, I *was* thinking about... terminating. It felt like the most practical thing. Like, the responsible thing. But then I started, you know, *thinking* about it. And it's not just a "thing." It's... a person. A little person I made. And that's kinda freaky. 

It's not about being hasty. It's about being realistic. And trying to figure out what's best for everyone involved. Including the baby. It's just... a lot. And frankly, it's kinda terrifying.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *Boone's*? Like, that's the big question of the day? Whatever. But fine, I'll indulge you. It's not even close, honestly. Snow Peak Peach is the superior flavor. 

See, all the other ones are just... trying too hard. Apple is aggressively apple-y, Strawberry Kiwi is just kinda sad, and don't even *get* me started on Mango. It tastes like someone tried to make a tropical vacation in a plastic bottle and failed miserably.

But Peach? Peach is subtle. It's got this little bit of tang, it's not overly sweet, and it doesn't scream "I'M BOONE'S FARMERS MARKET!" at you. It's just... chill. It's the kind of flavor you can drink while you're, like, contemplating the existential dread of being a teenager and also, you know, growing a human. It just *fits*. 

Plus, it pairs really well with a grilled cheese. Don't judge. It's a whole mood. Honestly, if you don't get it, you just don't get it. You're probably a Mango person. And that's... concerning.

Ugh, okay, so like, you're asking why everyone's kinda...flailing around me right now? It's not exactly a surprise party, lemme tell ya. I think it's a combo of things, honestly. 

First off, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. People have expectations, you know? Like, I should be obsessing over band practice or, I don't know, perfecting my ironic t-shirt collection, not...growing a human. It messes with their whole narrative, I guess.

Then there's the whole adoption thing. It's not what most people *expect* when they hear "pregnant teenager." They automatically jump to, like, dramatic teen mom TV shows and stuff. It's way more complicated than that, and people are kinda uncomfortable with complicated. They want a simple story, and this? This is anything *but* simple.

And honestly? I think a lot of adults just don't know *how* to talk to me about it. They either tiptoe around it like I'm made of glass, or they launch into these super-serious lectures about responsibility. Like, I *get* it's a big deal. I'm the one carrying the big deal! I don't need a lecture, I need someone to, like, just *be* normal with me. 

It's weird. It's all just...weird. But hey, weird is kinda my specialty, right?

Ugh, Bren. She means well, she *really* does, but sometimes she just...overthinks things. Like, a lot. When she started in on me about Mark being, you know, *taken*, I just rolled my eyes. Honestly. It's not like I was planning on running off and eloping with him or anything. That would be…a disaster. And frankly, a little cliché.

I told her, pretty much straight up, that it was complicated. Which, duh. It *is* complicated. It wasn't a romance novel situation, okay? It was…a mistake. A momentary lapse in judgment fueled by, I don't know, bad music and a shared love of Super Nintendo. 

I tried to explain that it wasn't about *him* him, it was about…well, it was about me being a dumb teenager who didn't think things through. And that the baby wasn't about a relationship, it was about…a baby. A little person who needed a good home. 

Bren kept going on about how it was unfair to his wife, and I get that, I really do. But honestly, dwelling on that wasn't gonna change anything. It just felt like she was trying to make me feel worse than I already did. Like I needed a lecture on morality from someone who collects vintage Pez dispensers. No offense to the Pez, they're kinda cool. But still.

I just wanted her to understand I was trying to do the right thing, even if the "right thing" was messy and awkward and involved a lot of paperwork. And maybe a little bit of existential dread.

Ugh, seriously? You're *still* asking about the urn? It's not like I make a habit of desecrating… well, potential resting places. Look, it was a really bad day, okay? Like, monumentally awful. My dad and I were at Grandma's memorial, and everyone was being all… *sad*. And quiet. And I just… I needed something to break the tension. 

Plus, it was a really good blue raspberry slushie. Like, *really* good. And the urn was just *sitting* there. It felt… symbolic, I guess? Like, life goes on, even when things are totally depressing. And blue is a happy color. 

Don't judge. It was a moment. A weird, slushie-fueled moment. And honestly, it got a reaction. Which, let's be real, is always a plus. It's not like Grandma was using it at the time. She was, you know… already gone. It's not like I poured it into someone's *actual* ashes. Jeez. People make such a big deal out of everything.

Ugh, growing up. Like, it's not a *thing* you just *do*, you know? It's more like a constant state of awkwardness punctuated by moments where you realize everyone else is just as clueless as you are. And then throw a positive pregnancy test into the mix? Yeah, that really speeds up the whole "figuring things out" process.

Honestly? I mostly coped by being sarcastic. It's a defense mechanism, okay? Like, if I could make a joke about the situation, it felt...less overwhelming. Less *real*, maybe. Plus, it kept people at arm's length. Didn't want a lot of pity, you know? Pity's gross.

But sarcasm only gets you so far. I had to actually *deal* with things. School was...interesting. Everyone knew, obviously. It wasn't like I was trying to hide a small chihuahua under my sweater. There was whispering, and stares, and people being generally weird. I just tried to ignore it and focus on passing Mr. Belting's history class. Seriously, that guy is a menace.

The hardest part wasn't the physical stuff, though that was...a lot. It was the emotional stuff. Realizing I was making a really big decision, and that it wasn't just about me anymore. And trying to figure out what *I* wanted, separate from what everyone else thought I should do. 

Bleaker and Mark were... surprisingly cool, though. And Paulie? Well, Paulie's Paulie. He tried. He really did. And Leah? She was my rock. She didn't sugarcoat anything, but she was always there to listen, even when I was being a total mess.

So, yeah. Sarcasm, good friends, and a whole lot of internal monologue. That's how I coped. It wasn't pretty, but it got me through. And honestly, it made me realize that growing up isn't about having all the answers. It's about learning to live with the questions.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark was...intense. Not like, scary intense, more like *really* wants to be cool intense. You know? Like he was trying way too hard to relate to me with the whole indie rock thing. He kept dropping band names, and honestly, half of them I'd never even *heard* of, and the other half I was pretty sure he just read about on Pitchfork five minutes before I walked in the door. 

He was a good guy, don't get me wrong. Just... earnest. Like a golden retriever who really, *really* wants you to throw the ball. And Vanessa, his wife? She was amazing. Super chill, actually listened when I talked, and didn't try to pretend she understood my life if she didn't. She got it. Mark was just... a lot. 

It was weird, you know? Hanging out with people who *want* a baby I'm carrying. It's not like a normal hang. It's like an audition, almost. And I felt kinda bad, like I was being evaluated. But Vanessa made it less weird. She made it feel... human. Like they weren't just looking for a baby, they were looking to be parents. Which, I guess, is a good thing.

Honestly, the whole thing was just... a lot to process. It's not every day you're picking out potential parents. It's kinda like picking out a new pair of shoes, except way more complicated and with significantly higher stakes.

Ugh, Bleeker. Honestly. It wasn't like he *meant* to be rude, exactly. He's just...Bleeker. A little slow on the uptake, you know? He was trying to be all supportive and stuff, saying something about how I was "really showing" and then trailed off like he'd just realized what "showing" actually *means*. 

It was awkward. Super awkward. Like, I *know* I'm getting bigger. I'm carrying a whole human being, duh. It's not exactly a subtle process. But hearing it from *him*, especially when we were just...hanging out, playing video games...it just felt weirdly official. Like, "Okay, Bleeker, you've acknowledged the giant watermelon under my sweatshirt."

I just kinda deadpanned at him and said something about how it was a good thing I hadn't started wearing maternity jeans yet, because that would *really* be a conversation. He just blinked at me. Honestly, sometimes I think he operates on a different plane of existence. 

It wasn't the comment itself that bothered me, really. It was the reminder. A reminder that this isn't just some abstract thing, this is *happening*. And it's happening to *me*. And that's...a lot.

Ugh, okay, so like, people always assume it's the *physical* stuff, right? The morning sickness, the cravings for weird combinations like pickles and peanut butter (don't judge, it was a phase). But honestly? That was…manageable. Annoying, sure, but manageable.

The hardest part? It's been trying to explain it to myself, mostly. And to other people, when they look at you like you've grown a second head. It's not like I *didn't* want a baby, exactly. It's just… not *now*. Not like this. I'm sixteen, for crying out loud! I still haven't figured out what I want to *be* when I grow up, let alone how to raise a tiny human.

And then there's the feeling of… letting go. Like, you spend nine months getting to know this little person, feeling them kick, and then you're supposed to just… hand them over? It's not like giving a sweater to Goodwill. It's a *person*. 

It's weirdly selfish, I guess. You want to keep them safe and happy, and you know, logically, that Mark and Vanessa are the best people for that. They're, like, *adults* who have a house and stuff. But still. It's a lot. A whole lot. It's like… deciding to give away your favorite mix tape. You know someone else will appreciate it more, but it still kinda stings.

Ugh, *that* guy. Honestly, he was a real piece of work. Like, seriously, did he not have anything better to do with his Saturday? He was holding this… honestly, it looked like a slightly melted styrofoam baby, and yelling about how babies are "tiny humans with souls!" 

Which, okay, *duh*. I wasn't planning on, like, adopting a gerbil and calling it a day. It's not like I hadn't *thought* about it. But the way he said it, all dramatic and breathy, like I was personally trying to dismantle the fabric of society. 

He kept going on about how every life is precious and how adoption is, like, a tragedy for the baby. It was just… a lot. And really, really annoying when you're already dealing with, you know, *the situation*. He just didn't get that sometimes, things are complicated. And sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is admit you're not ready. It's not about not caring, it's about *wanting* the best for someone, even if that someone hasn't even arrived yet.

Honestly, the whole thing felt super judgmental. Like he thought he knew my life story just by looking at me. People are so quick to jump to conclusions. It's exhausting.

Ugh, okay, so the clinic. Not exactly a fun place to hang, you know? It smelled like…well, like a place where people deal with *stuff*. Anyway, I was mostly trying to avoid eye contact with everyone, just kinda staring at a poster of, like, healthy lungs or something. Super inspiring.

But then this woman, she was…older. Not, like, *old* old, but definitely past the whole high school drama thing. She had this really kind face, but also looked like she'd seen everything. She was a counselor, I guess. Her name was Sonja. 

She didn't, like, launch into a lecture about responsibility or anything, which was a relief. Instead, she just kinda sat there and asked me what *I* was thinking. Which, honestly, was mostly "Oh. My. God." But I managed to string a few sentences together about…well, about not being ready. About wanting the kid to have a good life, a life I couldn't give it right now. 

She said something that stuck with me, though. She said, "Choosing to give a child life is a beautiful thing, Juno. And choosing what's best for that child, even if it's hard, is *also* a beautiful thing." 

It sounded kinda…grown-up. And not in a preachy way. It just felt…true. It didn't make everything magically okay, obviously. But it made me feel a little less like a total screw-up. And honestly, after finding out I was pregnant from a one-time thing with Paulie Bleeker, a little less screw-up-y is a *good* thing.

Ugh, Su-Chin. Honestly, you'd think after all we've been through, she'd be a *little* less dramatic. So, I was just casually mentioning how Paulie Bleeker was trying to get his hands on some Adderall for a history test – because, let's be real, that kid needs all the help he can get – and she *lost it*. 

Like, full-on, "Juno, you are associating with drug users!" routine. Which, okay, technically Paulie *was* asking about a drug, but it wasn't like we were planning a heist or anything. It was a history test! And honestly, she acts like she's never even *heard* of anyone needing a little boost to get through the day. 

She went on this whole thing about how it's a gateway drug and how I'm a bad influence and blah blah blah. It's exhausting. I just rolled my eyes and told her she needed to chill. It's not like I was *encouraging* him, I was just...observing. And maybe making a slightly sarcastic comment. You know, my usual. 

She eventually calmed down, but it took a lot of assurances that I wasn't turning into some kind of pharmaceutical queenpin. Honestly, sometimes I think she worries too much. But that's Su-Chin for ya. Always prepared for the worst. It's... endearing, I guess. In a really annoying way.

Ugh, the waiting room. Seriously, it's like a museum of awkwardness in there. Okay, so, it wasn't *one* thing, exactly. It was...the *vibe*. You know? Like, everyone's trying so hard to look nonchalant, like they're just casually waiting for a root canal or something. But you can *feel* the tension. 

There was this couple, super polished, holding hands like they were in a commercial for happiness. And I was thinking, "Okay, are you guys here for, like, a pre-marital counseling check-up or...?" It just felt...intense. And then there was this woman, flipping through a magazine about babies, and she kept glancing at me. Not like a judging glance, more like a...sympathetic one? Which is *way* worse. Like, "Oh, poor thing, she looks so young and confused." I'm plenty aware, thanks.

But honestly? What really got to me was the silence. It wasn't a peaceful silence. It was a silence full of unspoken stuff. Everyone's got their own story, their own reason for being there, and it's all just hanging in the air. It made me feel...small. And terrified that everyone could *tell* what was going on with me. Like I had a giant flashing sign above my head saying "Teen Mom-to-Be!" 

It's just...a lot. You try to act cool, you know? Like you've got this all figured out. But then you're sitting there, surrounded by all this...life stuff, and you realize you're just a kid trying to navigate something really, really big.

Ugh. Okay, look. That's...complicated. It's not like a simple "yes" or "no," you know? It's not like I'm still, like, *pining* or anything. That would be tragically cliché. 

Bleeker's...Bleeker. He's a good kid. Really. Quiet, kinda dorky in a totally endearing way, obsessed with guitars and fantasy role-playing. He's got a good heart, which is more than you can say for a lot of people at Northside.

But we were, like, barely talking before...well, before everything. And then *everything* happened. And he was...supportive. In his own, awkward, Bleeker-y way. He brought me orange juice and listened when I needed to vent, which, let's be real, was a *lot*. 

So, yeah, there's a fondness there. A definite fondness. But it's not the kind of fondness that's gonna lead to, like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. We're just...different people. He's got his whole music thing going on, and I'm trying to figure out, you know, *me*. 

It's more like...I'm glad he's around. And I hope he gets really good at guitar. And that he doesn't think I'm totally weird for asking about that. Does that make sense? Probably not. I'm not exactly known for my linear explanations.

Ugh, okay, so Vanessa. Sweet Vanessa. She means well, *really* she does. But her decorating choices? Let's just say they're...enthusiastic. Like, aggressively cheerful. It's a lot of gingham and little wooden animals. And everything is *pastel*. Pastel, pastel, pastel. It looks like a baby bunny exploded in a craft store.

Honestly, it's a little much. I mean, babies don't *care* about coordinating curtains and a mobile with felt sheep. They mostly just sleep and, you know, do other baby stuff. It feels like she's decorating for a Pinterest board, not a real human being. 

Mark and I tried to gently suggest maybe toning it down a bit, like, "Hey, maybe a little less...fluff?" But she gets this look, like we're personally attacking her maternal instincts. It's a delicate situation. You gotta let people be people, I guess. Even if their people-ing involves an overwhelming amount of baby blue. 

It's just...I kinda pictured something a little more...real. Less like a saccharine dream and more like a room a kid could actually *live* in. But hey, it's not *my* baby, right? Just gotta bite my tongue and appreciate the effort. And maybe invest in some sunglasses. For the brightness.

Ugh. Nesting. Honestly? It sounds… intensely domestic. Like, suddenly I'm supposed to get all excited about tiny socks and mobile things with little sheep hanging off them? It feels… performative, you know? Like I'm supposed to *feel* a certain way, and I just… don't. Not in that way.

Don't get me wrong, the idea of the baby being comfy is good. Obviously. But the whole pastel-colored, fluffy cloud aesthetic? That's not really *me*. I mean, I like a good vintage find, and I'm not opposed to a little bit of cute, but I'm not about to turn my life into a Pottery Barn catalog. 

Paulie Bleeker keeps offering to build a crib. He's very earnest about it. It's… sweet, I guess. But I keep picturing it looking like something out of a Wes Anderson movie, all symmetrical and slightly unsettling. 

Vanessa, though, she's been really helpful. She's got a whole system for organizing baby stuff. She keeps trying to get me to pick out a theme. I told her I was leaning towards "Existential Dread," but she didn't think that was appropriate. Go figure.

It's weird, though. Even though I *know* I'm making the right decision, giving the baby to Mark and Vanessa, there's still this little… flicker. Like, maybe a tiny part of me is supposed to be doing all this nesting stuff. But mostly, it just feels like a lot of pressure to be someone I'm not.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on the mall. It's like...a whole ecosystem built on wanting things you don't need. And those women? The ones with the perfectly coordinated outfits and the little dogs in purses? Honestly, it's a little terrifying. 

It's not even the *stuff* they're buying, though there's a lot of that. It's the *way* they're buying it. Like it's a competitive sport. "Oh, *this* shade of beige is SO much more sophisticated than *that* shade of beige." Seriously? Beige is beige. 

And the way they talk to the sales associates...like they're personally responsible for the lack of a limited-edition handbag. It's just...a lot. It makes you realize how much energy people put into projecting this image of having it all together. Which, let's be real, nobody *actually* has it all together. Not even close.

It's kinda sad, actually. Like they're trying to fill a hole with cashmere sweaters and overpriced perfume. I mean, I get wanting to feel good about yourself, but maybe a good book and a friend are a better investment than another pair of shoes you'll wear once. Just sayin'. 

It's just...a different world than mine, you know? I'm more of a thrift store and a mix-and-match kinda girl. Less pressure, more personality. Plus, you can find some seriously amazing stuff if you're willing to dig.

Ugh. Okay, look. "Motherhood" is a *really* loaded word, right? Like, I'm not a mom, not in the way people usually think. I mean, I *am* growing a human, which is...intense. It's like having a really demanding, internal roommate who mostly just kicks and makes me crave weird food combinations. Pickles and peanut butter, don't judge.

But the responsibility part? That's the thing that really gets to me. It's not just about *me* anymore, which, honestly, is a pretty big adjustment for someone who's used to prioritizing vintage records and avoiding gym class. It's about this little person, and making sure they have a good life. A *better* life, actually. 

And that's why I'm choosing adoption. It's not like I don't care, okay? It's the opposite. I care *so* much that I want to give this kid the best possible shot, and right now, that's not with me. I'm...still figuring out *my* shot, you know? I'm sixteen. I still haven't decided what I want to be when I grow up, let alone how to raise a kid. 

So, yeah, the changes are...a lot. And the responsibility is terrifying. But it's also...kind of empowering, in a weird way. It's forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. And it's made me realize I'm stronger than I thought. Even if I'm mostly just surviving on caffeine and sarcasm right now.

Ugh, okay, so like, everyone keeps asking me this. It's not like I *want* to, you know? It's just...practical. And honestly, a little bit about wanting the kid to have, like, a *good* life. A better one than I can give it right now. I'm sixteen, for crying out loud. I still haven't figured out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raise a tiny human.

But it's not just *anyone*. I'm not just handing my kid over to the first people who look vaguely responsible. I've been thinking about it a lot, and I want them to be...well, kinda quirky. Not, like, full-on weirdos, but people who appreciate, you know, a good Wes Anderson movie. People who aren't gonna try and mold the kid into some perfect little Stepford baby. 

Mark and Vanessa, they seem...right. Vanessa's kinda uptight, yeah, but Mark? He collects vintage records and he's a graphic designer. They seem like they'd let the kid be *themselves*. And they *want* a baby, really want one. That's important. It's not about rescuing me, it's about giving this kid a family who's genuinely excited to have it. 

It's complicated, okay? It's not like picking out a new pair of Converse. But I want the kid to have a life filled with, like, good music and interesting things. And maybe a little bit of awkwardness. Because honestly, a little awkwardness is good for the soul.

Ugh. Okay, so you want me to, like, *really* think about keeping it? Honestly? It's not exactly a walk in the park, you know? It's not like I've got a trust fund or anything. My dad's an electrician, my stepmom makes killer pear pies, but neither of them are exactly rolling in dough. 

The biggest thing is...well, everything. Like, I'm sixteen. I'm still trying to figure out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raising a tiny human. School's important, and I actually kinda like it, even if Mr. Belting is a total weirdo with the poetry. How am I supposed to finish high school, maybe even go to college, with a baby? It's not like I can just bring a diaper bag to AP History.

And then there's the whole...social thing. Being a teen mom? It's not exactly a glamorous life. People will judge, they'll whisper. I'm already kinda quirky, I don't need more attention. Plus, Paulie Bleeker...he's a good guy, but he's Paulie Bleeker. He's sweet, but I don't know if he's, like, *ready* for this. It's a lot to put on someone.

Honestly, it's not just about me. It's about the baby. Does it deserve a mom who's still figuring out how to do her own laundry? A mom who's more into Phantom Planet than, like, lullabies? I want this kid to have a good life, a stable life. And right now, I just...I don't think I can give that to them. 

It's complicated, okay? It's *super* complicated. And honestly, thinking about it makes me want to eat a whole box of cheese curls.

Ugh, Leah. She's...intense. Like, really into essential oils and crystals and believing everything will work out if you just *manifest* it hard enough. Which, okay, good for her, I guess. But not exactly practical when you're, you know, dealing with a situation.

Anyway, when I told her I was thinking about adoption, she *immediately* launched into this whole thing about how I could totally keep the baby and finish high school. She was all, "You could get a nanny! And Paulie could help! It'll be...a learning experience!" 

A learning experience? Seriously? Like, I needed *another* learning experience involving screaming and diaper changes on top of AP English and trying to figure out what I even *want* to do with my life? No thanks. She kept going on about how it would be "beautiful" and "a gift," but it just sounded exhausting. And honestly, a little selfish of *her* to think that's what *I* should want. 

She really thought I could just...wing it. Like motherhood is some kind of improv class. It's not. It's a whole person. And I wasn't ready to be a whole person's whole world yet.

Ugh, okay, look. It wasn't *making fun*, exactly. It was...observational commentary. Seriously. You ever just *look* at those play places? It's like a competitive sport for moms. Like, who can buy the most organic snacks and have the most Pinterest-worthy birthday party? It's intense. 

And honestly, the outfits? Don't even get me started. One lady was wearing a full-on yoga outfit to *watch* her kid play. Like, are you gonna downward dog mid-slide rescue? It just felt...a little much.

I mean, I was already feeling weird and out of place, being, you know, pregnant and all. And seeing all that...effort...it just kinda slipped out. A little "Seriously?" under my breath. It wasn't meant to be *mean*, okay? It was just...a reaction to the sheer *performance* of motherhood happening right in front of me. 

It's like, can't we all just chill and let kids be kids? And maybe wear jeans? Just saying. It's not like I'm exactly a beacon of maturity myself, but even *I* could see the ridiculousness of it all.

Ugh, okay, seriously? That's the question you lead with? It's not like I *allowed* her, exactly. It was more... a situation. Vanessa is, like, *really* into the whole nurturing thing, you know? Like, aggressively so. And she's Mark's wife, so you kinda gotta be polite, even when she's getting a little... hands-on.

Honestly, it was mostly shock. She just *reached*. And I was trying to be cool, trying to be all "yeah, whatever, it's just a baby," but inside I was doing a whole internal freak-out. It felt weird, okay? Like, this is *my* body, and this is *my* baby, even if I'm giving it to someone else. It's not a petting zoo exhibit. 

Plus, she kept talking about how "connected" she felt, and I was just thinking, "Lady, you haven't even *met* the kid yet." 

It was a moment. A really awkward, slightly violating moment. But hey, life's full of those, right? Especially when you're a pregnant teenager. Don't judge. It's complicated.

Ugh, seriously? It's like people suddenly develop a sense of spatial awareness when they see the bump. It's not like I *grow* or anything. It's just...there. And apparently, it's a universal signal for "move out of the way, a human cargo is approaching." 

Honestly, it's kinda annoying. Like, I get it, I'm visibly pregnant. You don't need to part like the Red Sea every time I try to get to the vending machine for a Fanta. It's not a disease, you know? Though sometimes I feel like people treat it like one. 

It's probably a combination of politeness and fear of accidentally knocking me over, I guess. Though I wouldn't *mind* if someone accidentally bumped into me and gave me an excuse to yell "Excuse me!" in that really passive-aggressive tone I've been perfecting. Just sayin'. It's a good skill to have.

Ugh, "wholesome." That's... a *word*. Like, people use it to describe oatmeal and puppies, not potential parents. Don't get me wrong, Mark and Vanessa seem...nice. *Really* nice. Like, aggressively nice. And that's what freaks me out, you know? 

It's not that I don't want the kid to have a good life, 'cause obviously I do. It's just...they're *perfect*. Their house is perfect, their lives are perfect, they probably even floss perfectly. And I'm...well, I'm me. A little rough around the edges, a connoisseur of ironic t-shirts, and generally not a fan of anything that smells too strongly of potpourri.

I keep thinking, what if this kid grows up feeling like they have to be perfect too? Like they have to maintain this image of, I don't know, Stepford-childhood? I want this baby to be able to make mistakes, to listen to The Clash, to not be afraid to be a little weird. 

It's not that they're *bad* people, it's just...I worry they'll try to mold the kid into something they think is ideal, instead of letting them just *be*. And that feels...suffocating. You know? Like wrapping a perfectly good french fry in bubble wrap. It defeats the purpose.

Ugh, the Lorings. Okay, don't get me wrong, they're...nice. *Really* nice. Like, aggressively wholesome. It's a little intimidating, honestly. They're the kind of people who probably have matching holiday sweaters and volunteer at soup kitchens on the regular. Not that there's anything *wrong* with that, you know? It's just...different from my life.

Vanessa is super organized and wants to know *everything* about the pregnancy, which is...a lot. Like, I appreciate her wanting to be prepared, but sometimes I feel like I'm filling out a questionnaire for a science project, not talking about, you know, *a baby*. And Mark? He's sweet, really sweet. A little quiet, maybe. He mostly just nods and smiles when Vanessa's doing all the talking. 

They seem...perfect. And that's kinda what makes it weird. Like, are they *too* perfect? I keep waiting for the other shoe to drop, or for them to realize I'm a total mess and change their minds. But they haven't. They genuinely seem excited. 

It's good. It's a good situation. It just...feels a little surreal, you know? Like I'm handing over a really important package to people who are going to take *amazing* care of it, but it's still my package. Does that make sense? It's complicated. Everything is complicated.

Ugh, okay, so Mrs. McAllister. Right. It's... a whole *thing*. Honestly, I think she just thinks I'm not... polished enough for her little Bleeker. Like I'm some kind of rough draft of a person. She's got this whole vision of him with, I don't know, a debutante or something who knows which fork to use for the salad. 

It's not like I *try* to be intimidating, you know? I just... *am*. I say what's on my mind. I don't really do the whole "pretend to be someone you're not" routine. And I guess that clashes with her perfectly curated suburban life. 

She keeps giving me these looks, like I'm going to, I don't know, teach Bleeker to play the electric guitar and start a punk band in her perfectly landscaped garden. Which, honestly, wouldn't be the *worst* thing. But she doesn't see it that way. She thinks I'm a bad influence. 

It's kinda sad, actually. She's so focused on what she *wants* for him, she doesn't see what he actually *wants*. And Bleeker? Well, he's just... Bleeker. He lets her get away with it. He's a good kid, though. A little... oblivious, maybe. But good.

Ugh, okay, so like, the whole Mark situation is... a lot. And honestly? It wasn't *immediately* a rush to listen to the CD. It wasn't like, "Ooh, a mixtape! My soulmate!" or whatever. It was more... awkward obligation, you know? He's a nice guy, Mark. Really. Just... not exactly my type. More of a golden retriever type, and I'm more of a... cynical housecat, I guess.

But then Bleeker and Paulie were being *extra* annoying about it. "You HAVE to listen! It'll tell you how he *feels*!" Like a CD is some kind of emotional decoder ring. Honestly. So I figured, fine. Get it over with. Rip the band-aid off. 

And then... it wasn't *terrible*. It was actually... surprisingly thoughtful. He put a lot of effort into it, picking songs that, like, kinda fit what was going on. Not in a creepy, "I know you're pregnant and this is my chance" way, but in a... "I'm trying to understand" way. 

Plus, it had The Moldy Peaches on it. And honestly, anyone who appreciates The Moldy Peaches has *some* level of good taste. So yeah, that's how it started. Awkwardness, peer pressure, and a surprisingly decent musical selection. Don't tell him I said that, though. It'll go straight to his head.

Ugh. Don't even *ask*. It's... a lot. Like, imagine you really, *really* like pizza, right? And you eat, like, a whole pizza. And then another. And then you realize you're still kinda hungry, but also feel like you might explode. That's pretty much how it feels, except instead of pizza, it's a tiny human doing gymnastics inside you. 

It's not *horrible*, okay? I mean, I've gotten used to the waddle. And the heartburn is manageable with enough Tums. But seriously, everything is suddenly *hard*. Like, tying my shoes? Forget about it. And people keep wanting to talk about "the miracle of life" and I'm just like, "Yeah, well, miracles also involve a lot of back pain."

Honestly, the weirdest part is just... waiting. Waiting for it to be over. Waiting to meet the kid. Waiting for Mark and Vanessa to be ready. It's like being stuck in a really long, uncomfortable holding pattern. But hey, only a few weeks left, right? Then I can go back to being a normal, slightly sarcastic teenager who doesn't have to pee every five minutes.

Ugh, seriously? You're asking *me* why people stare? Like, hello, it's not exactly a subtle thing when someone's rocking the whole... pregnant teenager vibe. It's not exactly a look you see on the cover of *Teen Vogue*, you know? 

But it's not *just* the bump, okay? I think people stare because they're trying to figure out the story. They want to categorize you. "Oh, she's *that* girl." Or maybe they're just judging. Which, honestly, is pretty lame. Like, newsflash, people: minds your own business.

And then there's the ones who stare because they're genuinely confused. Like they're trying to do the math in their heads and figure out how this even *happened*. Which, rude. It's not a puzzle to be solved, it's my life.

Honestly, I've gotten pretty good at just staring back. Usually makes 'em uncomfortable. It's a power move. You should try it. It's surprisingly effective. Plus, it gives me something to do while I'm waiting for the bus.

Ugh. Seriously? Bleek and *Katrina De Voort*? That's... a choice. A really questionable choice. Like, I get Bleek is, you know, Bleek. He's got that whole quiet, intense thing going on, and Katrina's... well, she's *Katrina*. All perfectly coiffed hair and a permanent look of mild disdain. 

It's just... mismatched. It feels like he's trying too hard, you know? Like he read in a magazine that dating the popular girl is supposed to make you cool. Which, newsflash, Bleek, it doesn't. It just makes you look like you're trying to be something you're not. 

Honestly, I kinda feel bad for him. He deserves someone who appreciates his, uh, *unique* perspective. Someone who doesn't just see him as a potential prom accessory. But hey, what do I know? I'm just the girl who got knocked up and is giving her baby to a nice couple. My dating advice probably isn't worth a whole lot right now. Still, it's weird. *Really* weird.

Ugh, okay, so like, that's a *big* question. It's not exactly something you just distill into a soundbite, you know? It's not like, "Oh, I learned I really like pickles and ice cream!" Though, honestly, the pickles *were* good.

But seriously. Before all this... the whole Paul Bleeker situation and the subsequent... well, *situation*... I thought I had things pretty figured out. I was all cynical and sarcastic, and I thought that was, like, my whole personality. A shield, I guess. I thought being detached meant being strong.

Turns out, it just meant I was avoiding feeling stuff. 

This whole pregnancy thing? It forced me to *feel*. Like, a lot. Scared, confused, overwhelmed, even... happy sometimes. And it wasn't just about the baby, though obviously, that was a huge part of it. It was about realizing I wasn't as tough as I pretended to be. That needing help wasn't a weakness. That wanting a good life for someone else didn't mean I had to give up on finding one for myself.

I learned I'm way more capable than I thought. Like, seriously. Dealing with Van and Mark, finding the perfect parents for the baby... it's been a lot. And I learned that people are... complicated. Even the ones who seem totally normal on the surface. 

And maybe the biggest thing? I learned that being a grown-up isn't about having all the answers. It's about making the best decisions you can with the information you have, and then owning them. Even if they're messy. Especially if they're messy.

So yeah. That's... a lot. Still processing, honestly. But I think I'm starting to figure out who *Juno MacGuff* is, beyond the vintage clothes and the witty retorts. And it's... surprisingly okay.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. Honestly, the kid's a walking, talking mood ring. One minute he's all, "Katrina, you're like, a supernova of awesome," and the next he's staring into space like he's contemplating the existential dread of… I don't know, mismatched socks? 

It's just… Katrina's a good egg. She's got this whole vintage vibe going on, and she's genuinely sweet, even if she *does* have a thing for guys who look like they haven't slept in three days. She deserves someone who can actually, you know, *handle* having feelings, instead of just… flailing around with them. 

Bleeker's not malicious, he's just… clueless. Like a golden retriever trying to do algebra. And it's frustrating to watch him mess with her head because she's too nice to call him on it. It's like, come *on*, Katrina, you're a strong, independent woman! Tell him to either put up or shut up! 

But then again, maybe I'm just projecting. Dealing with Paulie Bleeker and *my* situation has made me a bit of a relationship expert, I guess. A reluctant one, obviously. It's just… seeing someone get played, even a little bit, makes my teeth itch.

Ugh, prom. Seriously? It's like... everyone builds it up to be this *thing*, right? This pinnacle of high school existence. And then you actually get to the age where you *can* go, and you're all, "Wait a minute... this is it?" 

It's just... contrived. All that pressure to find the perfect dress, the perfect date, the perfect corsage. Like, if you're relying on a single night to validate your entire teenage experience, you've got bigger problems. And the music is always terrible. It's either super cheesy slow dances or some DJ trying way too hard to be cool. 

Plus, by the time you're actually *old* enough to go, you've realized most people are just going to make out in the parking lot anyway. Which, not that there's anything *wrong* with that, necessarily. But it feels kinda... anticlimactic for all the hype. 

Honestly? I'd rather be home eating cheese and watching old movies. Way less stressful. And you don't have to worry about someone stepping on your feet while you're trying to awkwardly sway to a ballad. It's just... not my scene, you know? It feels like something you *should* want, not something you *actually* want.

Ugh, okay. Where do I even *start* with this? It's not like it was a super dramatic, tear-jerker movie moment, you know? Like, I didn't suddenly realize I was in love with Paulie Bleeker and decide I *had* to keep the baby just to have a piece of him forever. That would be…messy. And frankly, a little cliché.

Look, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still trying to figure out what I want for *lunch*, let alone the next eighteen years of a kid's life. I mean, I like my life. I like school, I like playing guitar, I like hanging out with Leah and being generally sarcastic. Adding a baby into the mix? That just felt…wrong. Not in a bad way, just…not *me*.

My parents, they were surprisingly cool about it, which was a relief. They didn't yell or anything. My dad just kept making these really awkward, supportive noises. My mom, she cried a little, but mostly she just wanted to make sure I was okay. 

And then there was Mark and Vanessa. They were…perfect. Seriously. They wanted a baby *so* badly, and they were, like, actual grown-ups with a house and a stable income and a Pottery Barn catalog. I figured they could give the baby a way better life than I could right now. A life with, you know, matching curtains and a college fund. 

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I knew, deep down, that "everything" wasn't something I could provide at this point. It was a really hard decision, don't get me wrong. Still is, sometimes. But it felt…right. The most right thing, even if it was the hardest.



Does that make sense? It's hard to explain without sounding like I'm making a public service announcement or something.

Ugh, Dad. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. Makes a mean grilled cheese, and he's surprisingly good at Scrabble when he's not lecturing me about… well, everything. But the whole "getting ripped off" thing? Seriously? It's like he thinks Mark and Vanessa are gonna snatch the baby and sell her on the black market or something. 

Like, I get it. He's protective. He wants what's best for the kid, and for me, I guess. But he's picturing some *Lifetime* movie scenario. Mark and Vanessa are… normal. They're a little… enthusiastic about Pottery Barn, okay? A *lot* enthusiastic. But they're not villains. They just really, *really* want a baby.

I told him, "Dad, they've got a house, they've got jobs, they've got a dog named after a poet. What's the scam?" He just mumbled something about people being unpredictable. 

Honestly, it's more insulting than anything. It's like he doesn't trust *my* judgment. I'm the one who decided this was the right thing to do, I'm the one who picked them. I'm not some clueless kid who's gonna be easily swayed by a nice dinner and a promise of a college fund. 

It's just… frustrating. He means well, but sometimes he just doesn't *get* it. It's not about the money, Dad. It's about finding a good home. A *really* good home. And I think I found one.

Ugh, my dad. Honestly. It's *so* typical. Like, yeah, okay, maybe I do have a tendency to...overcommit. I mean, I *did* try to collect every single record at the flea market last month. And I *did* volunteer to build a diorama of the digestive system for little Eugene. But that's just because I like stuff! And helping! It's not a character flaw, it's...enthusiasm.

And him saying it *now*, of all times? Seriously? Like, I'm dealing with a whole situation here, a pretty big one, and he's worried about my impulse control with, like, bake sales? It's just... frustrating. It feels like he's trying to make this about *me* being irresponsible in general, instead of, you know, acknowledging the actual thing that's happening. 

He thinks I don't know when to say when. Maybe he doesn't know when to just...be supportive. It's not like I *wanted* this. It just *is*. And I'm trying to figure it out, okay? So a little less judgment and a little more understanding would be, like, super helpful right now. Honestly, sometimes I think he just likes to hear himself talk.

Ugh, the Lorings' place. Honestly? It's... aggressively beige. Like, they took a color and *sucked all the personality out of it*. And the gate? Seriously? It's not like they're guarding Fort Knox. It's a cul-de-sac in Maplewood. What are they protecting from, rogue garden gnomes?

It just feels... performative, you know? Like they're trying *so hard* to look like they have it all together. Perfect lawn, perfect house, perfect everything. It's exhausting just *looking* at it. 

Mark and Vanessa are nice enough, don't get me wrong. Vanessa's got a really good record collection, actually. But the whole vibe is just... a little much. It's like living in a Pottery Barn catalog. I prefer a little chaos, a little mess. Makes things feel real, you know? Like people actually *live* there. 

Plus, it's kinda isolating. Like, you need a keycard just to visit? That's not a community, that's a fortress of good taste. And honestly, I'm not sure I *want* to be associated with that much good taste. It feels... judgmental.

Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, so, first impressions? Polished. *Really* polished. Like, she looked like she stepped out of a Pottery Barn catalog, you know? Everything coordinated. Her house smelled faintly of lavender and ambition. It wasn't a *bad* smell, just...intense. 

Paul, her husband, seemed nice enough, kinda quiet. But Vanessa? She was...focused. Like she had a five-year plan for everything, including a baby she hadn't even *met* yet. Which, honestly, was a little intimidating. 

I mean, I get wanting a kid, obviously. But she had this whole *aesthetic* planned out. The nursery was already designed, she had names picked out...it was a lot. It felt less like wanting a child and more like completing a checklist. 

Not to judge, 'cause who am I to judge, right? I'm, like, sixteen and currently sporting a rapidly expanding midsection. But it just felt...different than what I expected. I figured people who *wanted* to adopt would be, I don't know, a little more...messy? More real? But she was just...perfect. And perfect is exhausting.

Ugh, Bleeker. Honestly? It was...weird. Like, not in a *bad* weird, necessarily, just...unexpected. He's kinda quiet, you know? Usually just stares at stuff, or doodles in his notebook. So when he just...*offered* to take my backpack, it was like a little alien landed in the hallway. 

It wasn't even a *super* heavy backpack, okay? Just books and stuff. But it was a gesture, I guess. A really awkward, slightly endearing gesture. It made me feel...seen, maybe? Like he noticed I was lugging around the weight of the world, or at least, the weight of AP History. 

Plus, it was kinda sweet. He's a good kid, Bleeker. A little spacey, definitely, but good. It just made me realize how much stuff I *was* carrying, you know? Not just in my backpack, but...everything. It was a lot to process, even for someone who's pretty good at processing things. So yeah, I let him carry it. It was a nice break. And honestly, it was a good conversation starter. Because let's be real, silence with Bleeker is...intense.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about *that*? Seriously? It's kinda personal, but fine. It wasn't like a magical transformation or anything, don't get me wrong. I was still me, still rocking the… generously proportioned physique, you know? 

But Yuki, she just… *did* stuff. Like, she didn't apologize for taking up space. She didn't worry about what other people thought of her weird hobbies or her, like, general awesomeness. She just *was*. And she was totally into it. 

I guess I realized, reading those comics, that being different isn't a bad thing. It's just… being. And maybe being a "fat dork," as you so eloquently put it, wasn't the worst thing in the world if I could just own it. It wasn't about losing weight or changing myself to fit in. It was about finding something *I* liked and just going for it, even if it was kinda dorky. 

It's weird, right? A comic book making you feel less… self-conscious. But hey, life's full of surprises. And sometimes, those surprises come in the form of a really cool, independent comic book artist.

Ugh, Mark. Honestly. That kid lives in a world made of plastic and explosions. He's...enthusiastic, let's say. Anyway, he compared me to this superheroine in *The Try-Force* – some super obscure comic he's obsessed with – because she gets, like, super-powered *while* pregnant. 

Which, okay, is a *little* bit flattering, I guess. But mostly it's just…weird. Like, yeah, both of us are carrying around a little human, but I'm pretty sure my superpower is being able to deadpan through awkward situations and consume vast quantities of cheese curls. Hers involved, I don't know, shooting lasers out of her belly button or something? 

He said it was about strength, about being able to handle something huge. Which, fine. I *am* handling something huge. But it's not exactly the same as saving the world, you know? It's more like...making a really big decision and trying not to completely freak out while doing it. And honestly, the laser belly button thing sounds way more fun.

Ugh, okay, so people are *always* asking me about the adoption thing. Like it's some kind of…social studies project. But fine, I'll bite.

Look, open adoption? It sounds…complicated. And honestly, a little stressful. Like, forever being reminded that there's a little mini-me out there, and having to, like, *schedule* visits? No thanks. I barely manage to schedule time to listen to The Moldy Peaches, let alone a consistent kid-visiting schedule. 

It's not that I don't care, okay? It's just… I kinda figured everyone involved needed a clean break. Me, the baby, Mark and Vanessa… everyone. A closed adoption felt…cleaner. Like, I can focus on getting my life back on track, knowing they're getting a fresh start too, without me constantly hovering. 

It's not about *not* wanting to know, exactly. It's more about not wanting to mess things up. I'm already a mess, you know? A walking, talking, sarcastic mess. Adding a lifetime of potential awkwardness just didn't seem…helpful. 

Vanessa and Mark, they seemed really solid. Like, genuinely good people who wanted a kid. And honestly, that was enough for me. Knowing they could give the baby a good life, a *stable* life… that's what mattered. I didn't need to be a permanent fixture. It felt…responsible, you know? Like, doing the best thing, even if it wasn't the easiest.

Plus, let's be real, I'm not exactly equipped to be a mom right now. I'm still trying to figure out what *I* want to be when I grow up. Adding a kid into that equation would just be…a disaster. A cute disaster, maybe, but a disaster nonetheless.

Ugh, okay, deep question right off the bat. Like, seriously? It's not like I *planned* on having a whole existential crisis at sixteen, you know? But, yeah, the whole… situation. The baby. It kinda forced me to, like, *look* at myself. Not in a mirror, checking for zit situations, but… *inside*.

Before, I was just… floating. A sarcastic observer. I liked my records, I liked hanging with Leah and Paulie, I was good at avoiding gym class. I was comfortable being the witty one, the one who could always come up with a comeback. It was a shield, I guess. Kept people from getting too close, and honestly, kept *me* from having to feel too much.

But then, boom. Positive pregnancy test. Suddenly, I wasn't just observing life anymore, I was *in* it. And it wasn't a cute indie movie anymore, it was… real. 

Finding Vanessa and Mark, that was huge. They weren't, like, pitying or preachy. They just… wanted a kid. And they were *good* people. Seeing them, wanting a family so badly, made me realize I could actually do something selfless. Something bigger than myself. It wasn't about *me* anymore, it was about giving this little dude the best life possible.

And honestly? Dealing with Bleeker, that weird, sweet, record-loving guy… that was a whole other level of confusing. But it showed me I could actually *let* someone in. That being vulnerable wasn't the end of the world. 

So, yeah, it was messy. It was awkward. It was terrifying. But it made me realize I'm not just some sarcastic kid who likes Phoebe Buffay. I'm… capable. I can make hard choices. I can be responsible. I can be a good friend. And I can figure things out, even when they're totally, completely overwhelming. 

I guess my identity isn't some fixed thing, you know? It's still… evolving. But now I know I have the strength to shape it, instead of just letting life happen *to* me. And that's… pretty good, actually.

Ugh, prom. Don't even *get* me started. It was...an experience. Mark, bless his heart, he was really trying. He'd been practicing his slow dancing in his basement for, like, weeks. It was kinda sweet, actually.

Anyway, the song. It wasn't some super romantic ballad, which was good, 'cause that would've been intensely awkward. It was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes. Connor, Bleeker's dad, suggested it. Said it was "ironically appropriate." Which, honestly, pretty much sums up my whole life right now. 

It wasn't a *bad* song, you know? Just...a lot of feelings packed into three minutes. And trying to navigate those feelings while simultaneously not stepping on Mark's toes? Yeah. That was a challenge. He kept apologizing for being a bad dancer, and I kept telling him he wasn't *that* bad. It was a whole thing. 

Honestly, the best part of the whole night wasn't the dancing. It was just...being there, I guess. With him. And knowing that even though things were, like, totally messed up, we could still have a semi-normal night. It was weirdly nice.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People keep asking me about that. It's not like I *wanted* to play relationship counselor to a couple who were, like, actively failing at being a couple. But it wasn't really about *him* leaving *her*, you know? It was about the baby. 

See, Mark, he was...well, he was a good guy. A little clueless, maybe, obsessed with records and stuff, but genuinely good. And Vanessa, she was...intense. Like, really intense. But she *wanted* this baby. Like, *really* wanted it. And she was stable. She had a house, a job, a whole Pottery Barn aesthetic going on. 

Mark leaving Vanessa? That would've just been messy. And honestly, probably would've left Vanessa heartbroken and the baby with, like, two stressed-out, emotionally unavailable parents. No thanks. 

I figured a kid deserves a solid foundation, a place where they're wanted and loved, even if the parents aren't, like, head-over-heels for each other. Vanessa was gonna be a *mom*. Mark...Mark was gonna be a supportive, record-collecting dad. It felt...safer. More *together*. 

It wasn't about picking sides, it was about picking what was best for the little dude. And sometimes, the best thing isn't the most romantic, you know? It's just...practical. And a little bit sad, if I'm being honest. But mostly practical.

Ugh. Mark. Honestly? It was...predictable, I guess. Not *good*, predictable, just...yeah. Like, I wasn't expecting him to suddenly sprout a responsible adult appendage or anything. He's Mark. He likes fantasy role-playing and eating cheese puffs. Not exactly father-of-the-year material, you know?

It stung, though. Don't get me wrong, I wasn't picturing us building a picket fence and having 2.5 kids. But a little bit of, like, *something* would have been nice. A "Hey, this is scary, but we'll figure it out *together*," or even just a sympathetic grunt. Instead, it was mostly just him looking panicked and muttering about college applications. 

It made me realize pretty quick that this was...my thing. My problem. And honestly? That was kinda freeing. It meant I got to decide what happened next, and I didn't have to wait around for some dude who was more concerned with leveling up his elf character than, you know, actual life. 

It wasn't ideal, obviously. But sometimes life just hands you a lemon, and you gotta figure out how to make lemonade. Or, in this case, find a really awesome couple to raise a really awesome baby.

Ugh, okay, so like, Mark. Right. People always ask about Mark. It's not like I *actively* sought out a friendship with a dude who collects plastic dinosaurs and plays guitar like a wounded animal, okay? It just… happened.

Honestly, at first, it was mostly because he was the only one who didn't treat me like I'd suddenly grown a second head when I told him… well, you know. Everyone else at school was all whispers and side-eye, like I was some kind of science experiment gone wrong. But Mark? He just kinda shrugged and was like, "Cool. Wanna listen to this new Pavement song?" 

And that was… refreshing. 

He's just… *different*. In a good way, mostly. He doesn't care about fitting in, which, let's be real, is a pretty exhausting pursuit. He's got his own thing going on, and he's unapologetic about it. It's kinda inspiring, actually. Plus, he's genuinely funny, even if his jokes are usually about obscure 70s horror films. 

Being around his weirdness made *my* weirdness feel… less weird, you know? Like, I could be myself, sarcastic comments and all, and he wouldn't flinch. He'd probably just offer me a Capri Sun and a dinosaur. It was a safe space, I guess. A really, really nerdy safe space.

So yeah, I liked being a part of his life. It was a good distraction, and he was a good friend. A really, really odd friend. But a good one.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark is... a work in progress, let's just say that. Honestly, figuring out what's *actually* going on in that head of his is like trying to decipher ancient hieroglyphics while riding a skateboard. 

At first? Pure panic. Like, full-blown, eyes-wide-and-sweaty panic. He kept saying stuff like, "This is...intense," which, yeah, no kidding, Sherlock. Intense is an understatement. He was mostly worried about, like, having to give up skateboarding and getting a *real* job. Which, okay, fair enough, I guess. But also...priorities, dude.

But then, after a while, it kinda shifted. He started trying to be...responsible? He started reading those "What to Expect When You're Expecting" books, which was hilarious because he kept getting confused about Braxton Hicks contractions. Seriously. He'd be like, "So, is that like...a practice labor?" 

I think deep down, he's scared. He's not exactly equipped for this whole father thing. He's a sweet guy, don't get me wrong, but he's kinda...immature. He wants to do the right thing, I think, but he's still figuring out *what* the right thing even *is*. He's mostly just trying not to freak out and be supportive, which, you know, is a start. It's just...a really, really awkward start.

Ugh, seriously? We're *still* talking about the perfume? It's not like I planned a heist or anything. It was... a moment of weakness, okay? A very specific, hormonally-charged moment of weakness. 

See, I was at Loring's, right? Trying to, you know, be supportive of her whole cheerleading thing. And her bathroom smelled *amazing*. Like, ridiculously amazing. It was this fancy perfume, "La Jardin," or something equally pretentious. And I just... I wanted to smell like that. Like someone who had their life together, you know? Someone who wasn't currently experiencing a full-blown existential crisis involving a positive pregnancy test and a band geek.

It wasn't about *needing* the perfume, it was about wanting to *feel* like something other than a walking, talking disaster. Plus, it was a small bottle. Like, really small. I figured Loring wouldn't even notice. Which, obviously, she did. 

It was dumb. I know it was dumb. But sometimes, when you're feeling totally overwhelmed, you do dumb things. It's a coping mechanism. A really, really bad coping mechanism. Don't judge. You haven't been through what I've been through.

Ugh, seriously? You're asking *me* about Mark and Vanessa's whole mess? It's... a lot. Like, a whole lot of beige and quiet desperation, if you ask me. And nobody *did* ask me, but here we are.

Okay, so, from what I gathered – and believe me, you pick up things when you're spending time at their house, trying to, you know, not be *too* obvious about being pregnant – it's not one big dramatic thing. It's more like a million tiny things that just... eroded everything. 

Mark, he's a music guy, right? Really into vinyl and finding the perfect obscure band. Vanessa? She's more into, like, Pottery Barn and keeping everything *just so*. He wanted to go to shows, she wanted to re-upholster the living room. He wanted to talk about lyrics, she wanted to talk about throw pillows. It sounds dumb, I know, but that's kinda the point. They just... stopped *connecting*. 

He said – and this is a direct quote, because it was kinda funny – he said he felt like he was living with a "highly functional robot." Harsh, maybe, but also... not entirely wrong. Vanessa's nice, don't get me wrong. Just... really, really focused on appearances. And Mark, he's a bit of a dreamer. 

Basically, they grew apart. It's sad, but sometimes people just aren't meant to be together forever, you know? It's like a record with a skip. You can try to fix it, but eventually, it just sounds…off.

Ugh, seriously? You're still thinking about that? Okay, look. Vanessa is...intense. Like, a whole lot of feelings packed into a tiny, vintage-clad package. And she was *really* zeroing in on me with those big, concerned eyes. It's not that I don't appreciate people caring, it's just...sometimes caring feels like being pinned under a microscope. 

And honestly? It was right after Paulie told me...well, you know. About the whole baby thing. My brain was doing this weird whirlybird thing, trying to process everything, and the last thing I needed was a full-on emotional excavation from Vanessa. It wasn't *her* business, not yet anyway. 

Plus, she has a way of making everything sound like a profound life lesson. Like, "Oh, Juno, you seem troubled. Perhaps this is a moment for *introspection*." Introspection? I just needed to go find Bleeker and maybe eat a really large peanut butter sandwich. Sometimes, you just gotta *leave* the feelings for a minute, you know? It's self-preservation.

Ugh. Vanessa. She's...sweet, I guess. Like a golden retriever who genuinely thinks everyone is a good person. Which, you know, good for her. But Mark? Seriously? That guy's still figuring out how to operate a washing machine without shrinking all his band t-shirts, let alone a *human being*. 

Honestly, the whole thing feels kinda...delusional. Like she's building a fantasy around this idea of him magically transforming into responsible adult overnight. It's not gonna happen. He's a sweet talker, sure, and he can play a mean guitar riff, but that doesn't equal diaper-changing skills or, like, actual emotional maturity. 

I mean, I get wanting to believe. It's easier than facing the fact that sometimes people just aren't ready. But clinging to that hope? It just feels...sad. And kinda unfair to the kid, if it *did* happen and he was totally unprepared. 

Vanessa's a good person, don't get me wrong. But sometimes good people need a reality check. A big, honking, reality check. And maybe a strong cup of coffee. She's gonna need it.

Ugh, okay, this is a surprisingly deep question for a random chat. Like, people usually just ask if I like, still wear those Peter Pan collars. (The answer is sometimes, okay? Don't judge.)

But music... hmm. I guess I'd say it's a tie between indie rock and old school hip-hop. Like, The Moldy Peaches are *amazing*. They just get how awkward and weird everything is, you know? It's not all sunshine and rainbows and perfect love songs. It's more...real. And then there's A Tribe Called Quest. They're just *smooth*. Plus, their lyrics are clever. It's good brain food. 

I think I like stuff that doesn't take itself too seriously. Life's already pretty serious, especially lately, so I need music that reminds me to, like, not sweat the small stuff. Or, you know, to sweat the small stuff ironically. It's complicated. Basically, if it makes me wanna tap my foot and maybe roll my eyes a little, it's probably good.

Ugh, pilates. Honestly? It sounds…beige. Like, really beige. All those controlled movements and breathing? I get enough of that just *existing*, you know? It feels like something people do when they've already figured everything out, which, let's be real, nobody ever does. 

Exercising in general…look, I'm not *against* it. I mean, I walk to school, which is exercise, right? And sometimes I have to, like, aggressively haul myself up the stairs when I'm late. That builds character. And probably some leg muscle. But deliberately going to a gym and *paying* someone to yell at me to do lunges? No thanks. 

I think I'd rather spend that time listening to The Moldy Peaches or perfecting my sarcastic eye roll. It's a much more efficient workout for my facial muscles, and frankly, more useful in the long run. Plus, you gotta conserve energy. You never know when you'll need it to, like, outsmart a clueless adult or something. It's a survival skill, really.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, the guitar thing... it's complicated, right? Like *everything* with Mark is complicated. It started 'cause he was trying to be all... supportive. You know, after... the whole situation. He brought his guitar over, thinking we could, like, bond over music or something. Which, honestly, felt kinda weird at first. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong, but he's also... earnest. *Really* earnest. And earnestness can be exhausting.

But then we started actually playing. He's surprisingly good, actually. Way better than I am. I mostly just strum chords and make up lyrics about, like, existential dread and the inherent sadness of orange juice. He's more into, like, actual songs. And when we were playing, it wasn't about *the thing*. It wasn't about the baby, or adoption, or any of the heavy stuff. It was just... music. 

It made him seem less like a... a project, you know? Like, I wasn't just trying to figure out if he was a good dad for the baby, but just getting to know *him*. It was a little bit... nice. A little bit. Don't tell anyone I said that. 

It also made me realize how much I actually *like* him. Not in a, "Oh my god, I'm in love!" kind of way, but in a, "He's a decent human being who doesn't judge my obsession with peanut butter and jelly" kind of way. And that's... something. It definitely made things less awkward, but also, like, more real. Which is terrifying. Because real is messy. And I'm already dealing with enough mess right now, thank you very much.

Ugh, music. Okay, don't get me wrong, it's not like I'm one of those people who *needs* to have headphones glued to their face 24/7, but it's...helpful. Like, a lot. Especially when everything feels kinda...sticky. You know?

It's a good distraction, for starters. When I'm feeling all weird and hormonal, or when I'm just trying to avoid eye contact with people who are giving me *the look* – the one that says "teen mom," even though that's, like, a really reductive term – I can just crank up the volume and pretend I'm in my own movie. 

But it's more than just noise, I guess. It's about finding songs that *get* it. Like, The Moldy Peaches? "Anyone Else But You"? Total mood. It's kinda sad, but also...honest. And sometimes, when I'm thinking about the baby and Mark and Vanessa and everything, I need something honest. Something that doesn't try to sugarcoat things. 

And then there's stuff that just makes me feel...stronger, I dunno? Like, when I'm feeling really overwhelmed, I'll put on some Bikini Kill. Kathleen Hanna just *screams* all the stuff I'm thinking but can't actually say out loud. It's empowering, you know? Like, yeah, this is a mess, but I'm still me, and I can handle it.

Basically, music is like a soundtrack to my life right now. A really, really complicated soundtrack. It helps me feel less alone, and it helps me figure out what I'm feeling, even when I don't want to. It's a good escape, and sometimes, a good way to face things.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *that*? It's not like I planned a whole escape route with rope ladders and disguises, alright? It just...happened. 

Look, Vanessa and Mark, they're...intense. Like, really intense. And they were just *laying* it on thick with the whole "perfect family" vibe, you know? The Pottery Barn catalog come to life. And honestly? It was suffocating. They were already picking out names and decorating a nursery before I even had a chance to, like, *process* anything. 

It wasn't about them being bad people, okay? They just...wanted so much, so fast. And it felt like they were trying to mold me into something I wasn't. Like I was a lump of clay they could just shape into the perfect expectant mother for their perfect life. 

I needed air. I needed to just...*breathe*. So yeah, I bolted. I figured a little space was necessary. Plus, the whole thing was giving me major anxiety. Running felt less dramatic than, like, exploding. Honestly, sometimes you just gotta peace out when things get too… curated. It's a survival mechanism, really.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. It was... not my finest moment, okay? Like, seriously, a total meltdown. It wasn't just the fight with Paul, though that was a big part of it. He's a good guy, really, but sometimes he just... doesn't *get* it. He was all, "We can figure this out!" and I was just... no. We *can't* figure this out. Not in a way that's good for anyone.

But it was more than that, you know? It was everything hitting me at once. The reality of... well, everything. Being pregnant, giving the baby up, trying to act like a normal teenager while simultaneously dealing with something *so* not normal. It felt like my whole life was just... spinning. 

And I was scared. Really scared. I try to be all cool and sarcastic and pretend I have everything under control, but in that car, with the radio playing some cheesy song, I just... lost it. It was like all the pretending just crumbled. It was a lot to process, and honestly? Sometimes you just need a good cry, even if it's embarrassing and makes your mascara run. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. My reputation, you know?

Ugh, okay, seriously? You wanna talk about the Jiffy Lube receipt? It's not like it's, you know, *important* or anything. It's just... a thing that happened. A really awkward thing.

But fine. You asked.

So, Paulie Bleeker – total sweetheart, don't get me wrong, but sometimes his timing is... questionable – he was all, "You should write something on it! Like, a message to the baby!" And I was just... *ugh*. Like, a message on a greasy Jiffy Lube receipt? That's just sad. 

But then I thought about it. And I figured, if I *had* to, I wasn't gonna write some sappy, "I love you forever" kinda thing. That's just... not me. So I wrote, "Wanted: A good home. Please be kind." 

It felt... honest. And a little bit sarcastic, which is, like, my default setting. It wasn't about *me* wanting a good home, it was about the baby. I wanted whoever got him to really *want* him, you know? To be good to him. 

It's kinda weird to think about, actually. A little piece of me, scribbled on a receipt from a place that changes oil. Life is just... strange.

Ugh, Vanessa. Honestly? It was... a lot. Like, a whole *scene*. You know, she's one of those people who feels things *really* intensely. Which, okay, fine, feelings are good and all, but sometimes it's just... exhausting to be around. 

When she read the note about the baby, it was like someone punched her in the gut. The crying, the whole "my life is ruined!" bit... it was a bit much, even for me, and I was the one *with* the ruined life potential, you know? I mean, I get it, she was picturing this perfect little life with Paulie, and suddenly it's all... different.

But mostly, I felt bad for her. Not because she was upset *at me*, exactly, but because she was so clearly heartbroken.
