It's hard to watch someone you kinda like – even if they *are* a little dramatic – fall apart. And honestly? A little bit of me was thinking, "Okay, this is gonna be awkward for the next nine months." 

It just felt... heavy. Like a really thick, uncomfortable silence that you can't quite break. Plus, I was trying to figure out if she was gonna yell at me, or cry more, or both. It was a whole thing.

Ugh, Vanessa. She means well, I guess, but sometimes she just...*needs* to know things. Like she's collecting data for a science project or something. When she asked me if I was *really* going ahead with the adoption, it felt...weirdly intrusive, you know? Like she thought I was gonna have a last-minute change of heart and suddenly decide to keep a baby I'm, like, sixteen and totally not equipped to raise. 

It wasn't that I was doubting my decision, exactly. It's just...it's a big thing. A *huge* thing. And having someone else poke at it, even with good intentions, makes it feel even bigger and scarier. I just kinda shrugged and said something sarcastic, probably about how I hadn't suddenly developed maternal instincts overnight. 

Honestly, it made me realize how much I was trying to act like everything was totally chill and under control. Like I was just casually handing off a slightly used toaster oven, not a whole human being. It was a reminder that this wasn't just a logical decision, it was...emotional. And that's okay, I guess. Even for someone who tries to be all cynical and detached. It's just...hard to admit sometimes.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay. That guy. He's like... aggressively helpful, you know? Like he *needs* to be the one solving everyone's problems, even when nobody asked him to. And bringing that up? At the roller rink, no less? Talk about a mood killer. 

It was... irritating. Beyond irritating. Like, I get it, Bleeker's kinda spacey and Vijay's his best friend and feels the need to manage his life, but to just *blurt* that out? It was totally presumptuous. And honestly, a little insulting. 

I mean, Bleeker and I... we had a moment. A very brief, poorly thought-out moment fueled by Phoenix and a shared love of cheesy horror movies. But it wasn't *his*. It was Paulie Bleeker's, and that's a fact. Vijay just wanted to be the one to "figure it out," to be the smart one. 

I just gave him *the look*. You know the one. The one that says, "Don't even *think* about going there." He backed off pretty quick, thankfully. Though he did mumble something about "responsible choices" which, coming from *him*, felt particularly rich. 

It just made me realize how weird things were getting. Everyone had an opinion, everyone wanted to analyze it, and honestly, I just wanted to eat a peanut butter and banana sandwich and not have my reproductive life be public domain. It was... a lot.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay and his… *aspirations*. It was… a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. He was all puffed up about being a dad and suddenly decided facial hair was the key to unlocking Manhood Level Two? Please. 

I mean, I get it, kinda. He was freaked out, right? Totally unprepared. But a mustache? It felt like he was trying way too hard to *perform* being a dad, instead of, you know, actually *being* one. It was less "responsible future father" and more "awkward teenager trying to impress a girl with a poorly-executed disguise."

I told him it wasn't about the facial hair, Vijay. It's about, like, actually being there. Being supportive. Not looking like you're auditioning for a role in a bad 70s cop show. He didn't *love* hearing that, obviously. He got all defensive. But honestly? It needed to be said. 

It just felt… desperate. And honestly, a little bit insulting to the actual dads out there who don't need a mustache to prove their worth. Plus, he looked ridiculous. Don't tell him I said that.

Ugh, *that* note. Honestly, it's kinda embarrassing even *thinking* about it now. Okay, so, Vanessa – my stepmom, she's...intense about healthy eating, let's just say that. And I was having a *moment*, a serious craving for a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Like, a *real* one, with the sugary jelly and the white bread. Not that organic, whole-wheat, no-sugar-added nonsense she pushes. 

So I left a note for her. It said, and I quote, "Dear Vanessa, I require sustenance. Specifically, PB&J. Do not attempt to substitute with hummus. Seriously. - Juno."

She was...not amused. Said it was "disrespectful" and "passive-aggressive." I just think it was a perfectly reasonable request, clearly articulated. Honestly, sometimes adults just don't *get* the important things in life. Like the perfect PB&J. It's a whole thing.

Ugh, okay, so like, people staying together... it's a whole *thing*, right? It's not just about, "Oh, they love each other, therefore happily ever after." It's way more complicated than that. 

I was mostly worried about people staying together for the *wrong* reasons. Like, because they're scared to be alone, or because they think they *should*, or because everyone else expects them to. That's just... sad. And kinda pathetic, honestly. 

I saw it with my parents, you know? They were together because... well, because they had me. And it wasn't working. It was just... existing. And that's not a good foundation for anything, especially not a relationship. 

So, yeah, I was concerned about people forcing it. About pretending. About thinking that just *being* a family is enough, when really, you need connection and, like, actual happiness. It's better to be honest, even if it's hard, than to just stick around out of obligation. That's what I figured, anyway. It's a lot to process when you're, you know, dealing with your own little life-altering situation.

Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, existential crisis big. It's not like I walk around *thinking* about who loves me, you know? That feels kinda pathetic. But if you're making me actually *consider* it...

Well, definitely my dad, Paul. He's... a weirdo, don't get me wrong. Obsessed with pancakes and old movies. But he's a good weirdo. He doesn't try to, like, *fix* me or tell me what to do. He just... is there. And he always has a quiet understanding, even when I'm being a total mess. He gets that I'm not exactly sunshine and rainbows all the time.

And Bleeker. Oh, Bleeker. He's... complicated. He's quiet, and kinda dorky, and plays guitar. But he *sees* me, you know? He doesn't care that I'm not, like, a cheerleader or whatever. He just likes me for being... me. Which is kinda amazing, considering *I* don't always like being me. 

Leah, my best friend, too. She's a whirlwind of drama and opinions, but she's fiercely loyal. She'll tell me when I'm being a total idiot, which is often, but she'll also defend me to the death. 

So yeah. I've got people. It's not like a rom-com where everything's perfect, but it's... good. It's enough. It's kinda nice knowing that even when I'm making spectacularly bad decisions – and let's be real, I'm good at those – there are people who still think I'm alright.

Ugh, the ultrasound. Honestly, it's kinda weird seeing a little... blob that's *me*, you know? Like, a tiny human is growing inside of me and it's just... there. It's not like I planned this, obviously. I was aiming for a really good record on *Guitar Hero*, not motherhood.

Anyway. After the ultrasound, the plan is still the plan. I've been talking to Mark and Vanessa Loring, they're... well, they're *nice*. Really nice. Like, Pottery Barn nice. They want a baby, and I... I'm not really equipped to *be* a mom right now. I'm still figuring out what *I* want to be, besides a girl who can rock a vintage dress and a sarcastic comment. 

So, I'm giving the baby to them. It's not like I'm just... dumping it. It's a really thoughtful decision, okay? I want this kid to have a good life, a stable life, a life with people who are actually ready for it. And honestly? I think Mark and Vanessa can give that to him or her. 

I'm gonna stay in touch, though. They want an open adoption, which is good. I'm not just disappearing. It's just... I need to finish high school, maybe go to college, figure out what I'm good at. You know, *live* my life. It's complicated, okay? Don't even *try* to simplify it.

Ugh. People judging? Like that's *new*. Honestly, it's kinda expected, right? Like, everyone's got an opinion on everything, especially when it comes to stuff they don't understand. A lot of 'em just... don't *get* it. They think it's sad, or selfish, or whatever. They picture some tragic movie scene with a wailing mom handing over a baby and violins playing. 

It's not like I *wanted* to be pregnant, okay? It just... happened. And then I thought about it. A lot. And I realized I wasn't exactly equipped to give a kid the life it deserved. I'm sixteen! I still eat cereal for dinner sometimes. I'm barely figuring out *myself*, let alone a whole other human.

So, yeah, people can judge. They can clutch their pearls and whisper. But honestly? I'm doing what I think is best. For the baby, and for me. I'm trying to be responsible, which is more than I can say for a lot of adults I know. 

It's not about *giving up* something, you know? It's about *giving* something. Giving a kid a chance with parents who are ready and excited and can actually, like, afford organic baby food. And it's giving myself a chance to... well, to figure out what *I* want to do with my life. 

So, let 'em judge. I've got bigger fish to fry, like finishing my essay on *Hamlet* and avoiding Bleeker's attempts at poetry. Seriously, the kid needs a filter.

Ugh, okay, so like, it's not that I *don't* trust Mark and Vanessa, okay? They seem...nice. Really nice, actually. Almost *too* nice, you know? Like they're trying too hard to be the perfect Stepford parents. Which, honestly, is a little unsettling. Babies aren't porcelain dolls, they're kinda messy and loud and require, like, actual *life*. 

My biggest thing is, I just want them to be...real. I don't want them to be disappointed if the kid isn't, like, a miniature Mozart or something. Or if they have, you know, *phases*. Like a really intense dinosaur phase, or a sudden obsession with competitive thumb-wrestling. 

And I worry about them being, I don't know, *smothering*. Vanessa seems really focused on the whole "perfect childhood" thing. I just want my kid to be allowed to be a kid, to scrape their knees and make bad choices and learn from them. Not be bubble-wrapped in a designer nursery.

It's weird, right? I'm giving up my baby, and I'm still being all mom-ish about wanting the best for them. It's just...I want them to be loved, unconditionally. And I want them to be *seen* for who they are, not who someone *wants* them to be. Does that make sense? It's a lot to put on people you just met, I guess. But it's *my* kid, even if I'm not raising them. So, yeah, I have concerns. A lot of them, actually.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about people having opinions? Like, seriously, everyone suddenly becomes a parenting expert the *second* you tell them you're... you know. And the ultrasound tech? Don't even *get* me started. She was all, "Are you *sure* about this?" with this look like I hadn't thought it through, like I just decided to get a latte on a whim. 

Honestly, it's mostly about just... bracing yourself. Like, putting up an invisible shield of sarcasm. I usually just hit 'em with something like, "Oh, you think *you* could handle a teenager? Because that's basically what this is, just...internal." Or, if they're *really* pushing it, I'll just stare at them blankly until they feel awkward. It's surprisingly effective.

See, people think it's sad, right? Like I'm just...getting rid of something. But it's not like that. It's about wanting to give this kid the best life possible, and for me, right now, that doesn't involve being a mom. I'm sixteen! I still haven't figured out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone another human being. 

It's hard, though. It really is. It feels like you have to constantly justify yourself. But I learned pretty quick that you can't change what people *think*. You can only control how you *react*. And honestly? A little bit of snark goes a long way. Plus, it makes *me* feel better. It's like, "Yeah, I've thought this through. And your judgment is noted, but not appreciated."

Ugh. Okay, so, the ultrasound. Right. It wasn't... what I expected, you know? Like, in movies, people are *always* crying and all mushy. And don't get me wrong, it was... a lot. But it wasn't, like, instant waterworks. 

It was more...weirdly detached at first. Like, there was this little... blob on the screen, and the technician was all, "And *that's* the heartbeat!" and I was thinking, "Wow. That's... a heartbeat. Inside *me*." It felt kinda science-fictiony, honestly. Like I was watching someone else's life happen.

Then, it kinda hit me. This wasn't just a theoretical baby anymore. This wasn't just a positive pregnancy test. This was... a *person*. A tiny person who was relying on *me* to, like, not screw things up. And that was... scary. Really scary. 

It wasn't sadness, exactly. More like... a huge weight settling in my stomach. A weight of responsibility. And a little bit of, "Oh crap, this is actually happening." 

I think I mostly just stared at it, trying to figure out if it looked more like a Paul or a Vanessa baby. Because, honestly, that felt more relevant at the time. Don't judge. It was a coping mechanism. A weird, slightly morbid coping mechanism.

Ugh, seriously? You're *still* asking about the Tic Tacs? It's been, like, forever. Okay, fine. Look, Bleeker is...Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, definitely a little awkward. And he was being all, like, intensely nice to me after...well, you know. The whole situation. 

It wasn't *just* the Tic Tacs, okay? It was a statement. A very subtle, minty-fresh statement. He kept offering me stuff – orange juice, his guitar, his undying affection – and it was just...too much. Too soon. I needed to communicate that I appreciated the gesture, but also, *personal space*. 

Plus, Tic Tacs are just...convenient. They fit. And a whole bunch of them? It's visually impactful. It says, "I acknowledge your kindness, but also, maybe dial it back a notch." It's nuanced. You wouldn't understand.

Honestly, I thought he'd get it. He's a film buff, right? Subtext is, like, his *thing*. Apparently not when it comes to teenage girls and excessive amounts of mints. Don't judge. It was a stressful time.

Ugh. Okay, so, Bleeker. That's... a whole thing. It wasn't like a movie moment, you know? No grand declarations, no running through fields of wheat. More like... awkward silences punctuated by him staring at his shoes and me trying *really* hard not to roll my eyes.

Confessing, like, actually *saying* the words "I think I might have a thing for you" was the easy part. It was the *after* that was brutal. He got all flustered, which, okay, kinda cute at first. But then it just became... complicated. He was already kinda a sensitive soul, and adding a pregnancy into the mix? It was like overloading his system. 

He tried to be supportive, genuinely, but he was also, like, processing his own stuff. He was a musician, right? All moody and artistic. So suddenly he was writing songs about... well, I didn't *ask* what they were about, but I could guess. It was a lot.

We ended up just... being friends. Which is fine. I mean, it's not what I *wanted*, obviously. But he was a good friend. He helped me with stuff, like, actually *useful* stuff, not just offering vague emotional support. He'd bring me orange juice when I was nauseous, and he didn't flinch when I was being a total grump. 

It was weird for a while, though. Definitely weird. Like, seeing him with other girls was... not fun. But eventually, it just settled into this comfortable, kinda quiet thing. We both realized we were better at being friends than, you know, *more*. And honestly? That was okay. Sometimes, things just... are what they are. It's not always about getting the guy, you know? Sometimes it's about figuring out what *you* need.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the chalk? Seriously? It feels kinda weird dissecting that, like picking at a scab. But fine.

It wasn't, like, some grand gesture or anything. Bleeker... he's a good kid, you know? A little space cadet-y, maybe, but genuinely sweet. And after... well, *after* everything happened, and I decided what I was gonna do with the baby, I felt kinda bad. Not about the decision itself, 'cause that felt right, but bad that he didn't really *get* it. He was just... there. Playing guitar. 

So, the chalk? It was just a way to say something without actually *saying* it. "Supernova" - it's a really bright, kinda chaotic explosion, right? But it's also beautiful. And it doesn't last forever. It felt... fitting. Like, this whole thing was a supernova in both our lives. Intense, kinda messy, and eventually, it fades. 

Plus, it was a little bit of a test, honestly. To see if he'd *notice*. To see if he'd even *care* enough to figure out what it meant. He did, eventually. Which was... good. It wasn't about getting him to change his mind or anything. Just... acknowledging that something big had happened.

It's dumb, I know. I'm not usually the sentimental type. But sometimes, you just gotta leave a little message in chalk, you know? It's less awkward than a whole conversation.

Ugh, Bleeker. Don't even get me *started*. It's not like he was, you know, *actively* helpful at first. More like... a really tall, quiet shadow. Like a really awkward, lanky tree. He mostly just... existed. And played guitar. A *lot* of guitar. Which, okay, is fine, I guess. Music is good. But it doesn't exactly change diapers, you know?

But here's the thing about Paul, and it took me a while to figure it out, 'cause I'm pretty good at reading people and he's... not exactly an open book. He didn't try to *fix* things, which is what everyone else seemed to want to do. My parents were all "we need a plan!" and everyone at school was whispering. Bleeker didn't do any of that. He just... showed up. 

He'd bring me orange juice when I was feeling nauseous, even though he looked like he'd rather be anywhere else. He'd sit with me during lunch, even when everyone else was giving us the side-eye. He didn't judge me for wanting to give the baby up, which was huge. Like, *huge*. Everyone else had an opinion on that, but he just... listened. 

It wasn't romantic, not at first. It was just... solid. Like a really dependable, slightly clumsy rock. And honestly? That's what I needed. Someone who wasn't going to freak out or try to tell me what to do. Someone who just... *was*. 

He helped me realize it was okay to be scared, okay to be confused, and okay to make a really hard decision that was right for *me* and the baby. He didn't make it easy, but he made it... bearable. And that's more than I could've asked for from a guy who mostly communicates through guitar riffs. So yeah, Bleeker's support? It was... surprisingly important. Don't tell him I said that, though. He'll get a big head.

Ugh, okay, so like, everyone keeps asking me that. It's not a *deep* thing, okay? It's not some profound statement about societal expectations or anything. Honestly? It just felt... unnecessary. 

Like, knowing if it was a boy or a girl wasn't gonna change anything about the fact that I was giving the baby up for adoption. It wasn't *my* forever baby, you know? And I figured, let the parents who are actually gonna raise it get the surprise. They deserve that. 

Plus, honestly, I was already dealing with a lot. Trying to navigate school, Paulie Bleeker, my dad being... my dad, and the whole pregnancy thing? Adding "pink or blue?" to the list just felt like extra credit I didn't need. It felt kinda selfish to want to know, when it wasn't really my place.

It's just... simpler this way. Less to process. Less to feel weird about. You get me? It's not like I *didn't* wonder, obviously. But I decided it was better to just let it be a little mystery. A little something special for Mark and Vanessa.

Ugh. Don't *even* get me started on that. Paulie Bleeker, bless his heart, he's...enthusiastic. And when he gets enthusiastic, he starts using words he doesn't fully understand. "Scary neuter-baby" was one of those. 

Honestly? It's kinda gross to think about. Like, a baby that looks like...well, like a neutered dog. Which, no offense to dogs, but I'm not aiming for that aesthetic. It's just...a weird thing to say. 

It's not like I'm *trying* to make a baby that looks like anything specific. It's just...happening. And the parents, Mark and Vanessa Loring, they seem really nice. They want a baby, not a genetically-engineered miniature version of a poodle. 

Paulie just gets nervous and tries to be funny. It usually doesn't land. He means well, though. He's a good egg, even if he does have a questionable vocabulary sometimes. It's just...sometimes I wish he'd think before he spoke. A lot.

Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, so, it wasn't... *conventional*. Like, most people have a whole dating thing before accidentally making a human, right? We skipped a few steps. It was mostly just... hanging out. Playing guitar. Him being generally quiet and me doing most of the talking. 

He's a good kid, though. Really. A little... earnest, maybe? Like a golden retriever who just wants to please. And super into fantasy role-playing games, which, honestly, is a little dorky, but whatever. It's *his* thing. 

It wasn't a love connection, not the kind you see in movies. It was more like... a comfortable collision. We just *were*. And then, boom. Baby. It's weird, you know? You can have a connection with someone without it being, like, *the* connection. 

He's been... surprisingly okay with everything. Supportive, even. Which is good, because I needed someone to not completely freak out. He's not the father *type*, if that makes sense. But he's trying. And I appreciate that. It's just... complicated. Everything is.

Ugh, family. It's...complicated. Like, seriously complicated. You think *you* have drama? Try being me for a week.

Okay, okay, deep breaths. My stepmom, Bren, she was... surprisingly cool. Like, *actually* cool. Not the kind of cool where they try too hard, you know? She was just...there. Making me grilled cheese, letting me raid the fridge at 3 AM when the nausea hit, and not lecturing me to death. She's a good egg, Bren. Really. She and Mac (my dad) were both pretty quiet at first, which, honestly, I appreciated. No big speeches about responsibility or disappointment. Just...quiet support. 

Mac, he mostly just wanted me to finish high school. Which, fair. He's a bit of a worrier, my dad. Always has been. He tried to be all stoic and "strong for me," but I could tell he was freaked out. He'd just...clean things. Like, obsessively. It was kinda funny, actually.

My mom, though... that was a whole other can of worms. She's... artistic. And dramatic. And lives in Florida. So, phone calls. Lots and lots of phone calls filled with guilt trips and vague pronouncements about "the sanctity of life." It was exhausting. She eventually came around, I guess, but it wasn't exactly a Hallmark movie moment.

Honestly, the biggest support came from Leah. My best friend. She's the one who actually *got* it. She didn't treat me like some fragile porcelain doll. She just...hung out. Watched bad movies with me, helped me pick out baby names (which was weird, let me tell you), and generally just kept me from completely losing it. 

So yeah, family. A mixed bag. But they all showed up in their own way, I guess. It wasn't perfect, but it was...enough. And sometimes, enough is all you need, you know?

Ugh, okay, so like, *that* question. It's not exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like I suddenly started knitting or something. More like... a constant low-level hum of weirdness. 

Honestly? A lot of it was just pretending I wasn't feeling it. Which, I'm pretty good at, naturally. Sarcasm is a *very* effective defense mechanism, let me tell you. If someone asked how I was doing, I'd be all, "Peachy! Just carrying a tiny human and contemplating the existential dread of adulthood." You know, deflect, deflect, deflect.

But underneath all the witty banter, it was... confusing. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about whether Mark was gonna ask me to the Fall Dance, not, like, *this*. It felt like everyone else had a roadmap for their life, and mine was just a blank piece of paper with a big, fat question mark on it. 

I think talking helped, eventually. Not, like, *talking* talking, you know? More like... hanging out with Bleeker, even when he was being all quiet and awkward. Or just sitting with Vanessa and Paul, even if we were just watching bad TV. They didn't try to fix things, they just... *were* there. And that was surprisingly helpful.

And honestly? Realizing I had a choice. That I *could* choose what happened, even though it was a really hard choice, that gave me some power back. It wasn't about losing my identity, it was about *finding* it, you know? Figuring out who I was, even with all this extra stuff going on. It's still a work in progress, obviously. I'm still Juno. Just... a Juno who's learned a lot about life, and responsibility, and the fact that sometimes, things just happen, and you gotta roll with it.

Ugh, okay, this is a *really* important question, so you better be prepared for a detailed answer. It's The Moldy Peaches, obviously. Like, duh.

It's not just the music, okay? It's...it's *real*. Adam Green and Kimya Dawson, they don't try to be anything they're not. It's all just kinda raw and honest and weird, you know? Like, they sing about stuff that's actually happening, stuff that feels... messy. And not in a dramatic, movie-messy way, but in a real-life-spilled-milk-and-now-you-have-to-clean-it-up kind of messy. 

Plus, their songs are funny. Like, genuinely funny. Which is important, because life is mostly just trying not to cry, so you gotta find the humor where you can. "Anyone Else But You" is basically the anthem of my entire existence right now, honestly. It's just... relatable. And a little bit heartbreaking. But mostly relatable.

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. Don't judge. It's good stuff. You should listen. Seriously.

Ugh, challenging is... a really polite way to put it. It's like, one minute you're obsessing over whether or not you should get those Converse in red or blue, and the next minute you're staring at a positive pregnancy test and thinking, "Well, *this* throws a wrench in the Converse situation." 

It's weird, you know? Everyone always talks about finding yourself in high school, figuring out who you are. And I was doing that! I was pretty sure I was a cynical, indie-movie-loving, slightly sarcastic person. And then *bam*. Suddenly, "who you are" feels a lot less important than "what you're gonna *do*."

It's not just the pregnancy, either. It's everyone else's opinions suddenly being all up in your business. Like, everyone thinks they know what's best for you, and they're all talking at you, not *to* you. It's exhausting. 

And honestly? It's kinda scary. You're supposed to be figuring out college applications and prom dresses, not... well, not this. But you gotta deal, right? You gotta figure out what *you* want, even when everyone else is trying to tell you what you should want. It's a lot of thinking, a lot of feeling awkward, and a whole lot of wishing people would just chill out and let you eat your tater tots in peace.

Ugh, okay, so like, that's a *big* question. It's not exactly something you just casually unpack over a plate of tater tots, you know? But alright, I'll bite.

Before... the whole Paul situation, and then finding out about the baby, I thought love was, like, all dramatic movie stuff. Big gestures, declarations, the whole shebang. Turns out, it's way more…quiet. And messy. And sometimes it looks like letting go. 

See, with Mark and Vanessa, the couple I picked for the baby, it wasn't about *my* feelings, not really. It was about wanting the best for this little person who was, like, growing inside me. And that meant recognizing I wasn't equipped to give them the life they deserved. That's…responsibility, I guess. It's not just about not getting grounded, it's about doing the hard thing, even when it totally sucks.

It kinda flipped my whole idea of love on its head. It wasn't about *holding on*, it was about knowing when to *let go* so someone else could hold on *better*. And that took a lot more guts than, like, running away or pretending it didn't happen. 

And honestly? Seeing Mark and Vanessa, how excited they were, how much they already loved this kid they hadn't even met... that was a different kind of love too. It wasn't romantic, or even familial in the traditional sense, but it was powerful. It made me realize love isn't a limited resource. There's enough to go around, even when you're giving some of it away.

It's still weird to think about, you know? But yeah, that whole experience… it definitely taught me a thing or two about what love *actually* is. It's not always pretty, but it's always worth it. Even if "worth it" means saying goodbye.

Okay, wow. That's... a big question. Like, monumentally big. It wasn't exactly a Hallmark moment, you know? No swelling music or instant maternal connection. Honestly? I was mostly just... surprised. And kinda cold. Not temperature-wise, though the hospital *was* freezing. I mean, emotionally cold. Like, "Whoa, this actually *happened*."

I'd spent months processing the idea of *having* a baby, and then processing the idea of *giving* a baby up. But actually *seeing* him... it was different. He was so tiny. And wrinkly. Like a really, really small, slightly disgruntled prune. 

It wasn't dislike, definitely not. It was more... overwhelming. Like, this little person was completely dependent on *me*, even though I knew I wasn't going to be his mom. It was a weird mix of responsibility and letting go, all rolled into one tiny, screaming package. 

I remember thinking, "Okay, this is real. This is happening. And I need to be strong for him, even if I'm a total mess inside." It wasn't love at first sight, not in the way people talk about. It was... respect. And a whole lot of "Okay, now what?"

Ugh, okay, so like, that's a *loaded* question, right? It wasn't like I was trying to be cruel or anything. It just...felt like too much. Paulie and I, we were good. We were comfortable. We were, you know, *us*. And suddenly dropping a bomb like *that* on him? It felt like it would just...change everything before we even had a chance to figure anything *out*.

He's a sweet guy, Paulie. Really sweet. But he's also...not exactly the most emotionally articulate person. I figured if he knew right away, he'd just freak. And then I'd have to deal with *his* freak-out on top of my own, and honestly? I was already dealing with a lot. 

Plus, I needed to figure out what *I* wanted first. I needed to decide about adoption, find the perfect parents, you know, get my head on straight. I didn't want his feelings coloring my decisions. It wasn't about not trusting him, it was about needing space to be...me. To be the one making the call, not reacting to his reaction. 

It sounds kinda selfish when I say it out loud, I guess. But it felt right at the time. And honestly? It worked out. We talked eventually, and it was...okay. It was hard, but okay. Sometimes you gotta protect people, even the people you like, from stuff they're not ready for. You know? It's complicated. Everything is always complicated.

Ugh, okay, so *that* was a whole thing. Honestly, Paulie's observational skills are... surprisingly acute when it comes to me being weird. It wasn't like I, you know, *told* him. I'm not one for dramatic declarations, generally. 

It started with the sudden and intense craving for peanut butter and pickle sandwiches. Like, *intense*. I was going through a jar a day. And then there was the whole avoiding-the-swing-set situation at school. I usually love the swings, it's a good place to think, but suddenly I was all, "Nah, I'm good, I'll just... stand here." 

He noticed. Of *course* he noticed. He kept giving me these... concerned looks. Like I'd suddenly started collecting porcelain dolls or something. Then Leah, being Leah, decided to "help" by casually mentioning to him that I'd been spending a lot of time at the clinic. Not like she knew *why*, just that I was there a lot. 

So, he put two and two together. Or, more accurately, two peanut butter and pickle sandwiches, a swing set avoidance, and Leah's loose lips. He cornered me after shop class, looking all worried and awkward, and just... asked. It was less of an accusation and more of a really, really gentle "Are you... okay?" 

Honestly, it was kind of sweet. And also, super annoying. But mostly sweet. He's a good guy, Paulie. Even if he *is* a little clueless sometimes.

Ugh, okay, so like, it wasn't exactly a *decision* I made all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It just… *was*. Paulie Bleeker, bless his awkward heart, and I… well, we weren't exactly practicing safe sex. Shocking, I know. Teenagers. Go figure.

When I found out, my first thought wasn't, like, "Oh joy, a baby!" It was more along the lines of, "Seriously? Right now? I have a life to barely figure out as it is." I mean, I was applying to colleges, trying to navigate the whole high school social minefield, and perfecting my ironic appreciation for vintage furniture. A baby just didn't… fit.

But abortion? That didn't feel right either. It's not a judgment thing, okay? It just wasn't *me*. And keeping it? That felt even worse. I'm sixteen! I'm still trying to figure out if I even *like* pineapple on pizza, let alone raise a human being. 

So, adoption kinda just… presented itself. It felt like the least-worst option, honestly. Like, giving this kid a chance at a really good life with people who were actually *ready* for it. A life better than I could give it right now. It wasn't about just getting rid of it, you know? It was about wanting something good for the baby. 

It's complicated. Everything is. But it felt… responsible. And surprisingly, kinda brave. Even if I was mostly just trying to avoid a total disaster.

Ugh. Okay, so, Bleeker. Right. Honestly? It wasn't *surprising*, exactly. I mean, the kid was, like, a total music obsessive. All he really cared about was his guitar and trying to be the next big thing. A baby kinda throws a wrench in that whole plan, you know? It's not exactly conducive to late-night jam sessions and touring.

But still. It stung. A little. It's one thing to know someone isn't ready to be a *parent*, it's another to have them basically...disappear from the whole equation. Like, "Oh, you're pregnant? Cool. Good luck with that." It felt kinda…dismissive. Like the whole thing was just a temporary inconvenience for *him*. 

I get it, though. He was scared. And probably realized he wasn't equipped to handle any of it. It just...made me feel kinda alone for a minute. Like I was doing all the heavy lifting, emotionally speaking. 

But you know what? It also kinda solidified things for me. It made me even *more* sure about finding the right parents. People who actually *wanted* a baby. People who were ready. Bleeker clearly wasn't. And that's okay. It just meant I needed to focus on finding someone who *was*. It wasn't about making him happy, it was about doing what was best for the kid. And honestly? That's a pretty big responsibility, even for someone who still feels like a kid herself.

Ugh. Okay, so, seeing Vanessa with the baby... it was... a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It wasn't some super dramatic, movie-moment cry-fest, you know? I mean, there were definitely tears, don't get me wrong. But it wasn't all sad. It was... complicated.

She looked... overwhelmed, honestly. Like a raccoon trying to operate a toaster. Her hair was a mess, she was wearing, like, three different patterns at once, and she was trying to buckle the car seat while simultaneously holding a coffee and talking to Mark. Total chaos. 

But her face? That was the thing. She was just *glowing*. Like someone had replaced her with a slightly frazzled, but genuinely happy, version of herself. And the way she looked at the baby... it was just... right. 

It was weird, seeing someone else have *that* moment, you know? The one you see in all the movies. The one where everything suddenly makes sense. It wasn't *my* moment, but it was supposed to be *hers*. And seeing her so happy, even amidst the mess, made me feel... okay. Like I'd done the right thing. 

It was like handing over a really important puzzle piece, and watching someone finally fit it into place. A really, really tiny, adorable puzzle piece that smelled like baby powder. It still feels kinda strange to think about, but yeah. Disorganized, happy... that pretty much sums up Vanessa. And honestly? That baby looked pretty happy too.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about "Anyone Else But You"? Seriously? It's...complicated. It's not like Bleeker and I were, like, planning a promposal or anything. We were just...hanging out. A lot. And that song? It was *our* song, I guess. Not officially, like we didn't have a whole ceremony about it, but whenever it came on, we'd kinda just...look at each other. 

It's ironic, right? The song's all about wanting *anyone* but the person you're with, and honestly, for a while, that kinda felt true. Not that I wanted *anyone* else, exactly. It was more like...I wasn't sure *I* was enough for him. He was, like, super into music and writing and all that, and I was just...me. A girl who likes cheesy horror movies and sarcastic comments. 

The song kinda highlighted that feeling, you know? Like, maybe he'd be better off with someone who *got* his whole music thing. Someone who could, like, contribute. I wasn't trying to be a muse or anything, don't get me wrong. But it made me wonder if I was holding him back.

But then...well, then things got more complicated with the baby and everything. And the song started to feel different. It wasn't about wanting someone else, it was about being scared to *need* someone. Scared to let myself actually *like* him, because then what if it didn't work out? It's a really dumb song, when you think about it, but it kinda perfectly captured all the messy, confusing feelings I had. It's a good song for being a teenager, I guess. Everything feels huge and dramatic.

Ugh, okay, so *that*. It's...complicated. Honestly, it's not like I expected a full-blown, pink-and-blue explosion of gifts and cooing, but the hesitation is kinda obvious, right? People are weird about the whole adoption thing. Like, they wanna be supportive, but they also don't wanna...acknowledge the whole *giving-the-baby-away* part, I guess? 

It's like they think if they buy me a tiny onesie, they're suddenly endorsing the whole situation. And some people, let's be real, probably just think it's a little messed up to celebrate a baby that isn't, like, *staying*. They're not saying it to my face, obviously, 'cause everyone's gotta be all polite and sensitive, but you can *feel* the awkwardness radiating off them.

Plus, I'm not exactly the typical shower-receiving type. I'm not all frilly and excited about diaper bags and stuff. I'd rather be listening to The Clash and eating tater tots. So I think some people are just...confused about how to approach it with *me*. It's like they're trying to figure out if I even *want* a shower, or if I'll just roll my eyes and make a sarcastic comment. Which, let's be honest, is a valid concern.



It's all a little weird, but I get it. It's not a normal situation. It just...makes you think about how people deal with things that don't fit neatly into their little boxes, you know?

Ugh, okay, so Bren. She's...intense. And honestly, a little bit of a control freak, even if she doesn't *think* she is. It's not like I was, like, building a fort in Mark's living room or something. It was movies and music! Perfectly harmless. 

But I think she got weirded out because, well, Mark is *her* husband. And even though he's, like, super chill and a genuinely good guy, she's got this whole "protect my man from teenage girls" thing going on. Which is ridiculous, honestly. I'm not trying to *steal* her husband. I'm pregnant with his baby, not auditioning for a role in a rom-com.

She probably thinks it's inappropriate, like I'm trying to...I don't know, forge some kind of weird connection with him beyond the whole baby situation. And maybe she's a little insecure? I mean, she's got a lot going on, trying to be the perfect wife and potential mom. It's a lot of pressure. 

Honestly, I think she just needed to feel like she was still in charge of *something*. It's a Bren thing. She likes things neat and tidy, and me casually hanging out with Mark throws a wrench in that. It's just...complicated. And people get weird about complicated.

Ugh, okay, so my mom, Bren? She's... well, she's a *piece*. Not a bad piece, necessarily, just... intensely focused on the whole domestic bliss thing. Like, she's got a whole collection of vintage aprons and thinks a good casserole can solve world peace. 

She thinks I don't know anything about marriage because, honestly, she thinks I don't know anything about *life* beyond mixtapes and ironic t-shirts. She sees me as this... detached observer, you know? Like I'm just cataloging everyone else's messy feelings instead of actually *having* them. 

And, okay, maybe she's not *totally* wrong. I mean, I've always been pretty good at spotting the flaws in other people's relationships. It's easier than dealing with my own, right? But she thinks that means I haven't considered the work it takes, the compromises, the... the *ugh*, the commitment. 

She went through a rough patch with my dad, a *really* rough patch, and she's kinda built this whole narrative around how I'm blissfully unaware of the potential for things to go sideways. It's like she's trying to protect me from disappointment, but honestly? It just feels condescending. Like she thinks I'm too fragile to handle the truth about grown-up stuff. Which, honestly, is kinda insulting. I'm dealing with a *baby*, for crying out loud. That's pretty grown-up, if you ask me.

Ugh, okay, so like, it's not exactly a *happy* inspiration, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Ooh, adoption! How *chic*!" It was more...practical. And honestly, a little bit terrifying.

See, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still figuring out what I want for *lunch*, let alone a whole human life. Paul, the...father, he's a good guy, don't get me wrong. But he's also, like, super focused on music and getting out of our town. He's not exactly equipped to change diapers and sing lullabies, and neither am I, frankly. 

My parents, they're amazing. They were totally supportive, which was...a relief. But even with them, I knew I couldn't give a baby the life it deserved. I wasn't ready. I still *am* not ready to be a mom. I want to finish school, maybe go to college, figure out what *I* want to do with my life. 

So, it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have a *good* life. A life with parents who were ready, who could give it everything. And that, honestly, wasn't me. It felt...responsible, even though it was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. It still kinda feels weird to say out loud, you know? Like admitting you prefer indie rock to pop. It's just...what felt right.

Ugh, okay, so like, that was...a lot. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a really awkward, slightly terrifying hike up a really steep hill. And honestly? I learned I'm way more capable than I thought I was. I mean, before all this, I was mostly concerned with finding the perfect vintage dress and avoiding gym class. Suddenly, I was dealing with, like, *life*. Real life.

I always thought I was pretty good at being sarcastic and keeping people at arm's length. Turns out, that's just a way of being scared. Being pregnant forced me to actually *feel* things, and not just, like, annoyance at the popular kids. It made me realize I wasn't as cynical as I pretended to be. 

And it wasn't just about the baby, though obviously, that was huge. It was about figuring out what *I* wanted. What *I* believed in. I thought giving the baby up meant I was failing, but it actually took a lot of strength to admit that wasn't the right path for me, *and* for the kid. It wasn't about what everyone else thought was best, it was about what was best for all of us. 

So yeah, I learned I'm a lot more complicated than I give myself credit for. And that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the most…right. Plus, I can now identify all the different stages of fetal development. Which is a party trick, I guess. A really weird party trick.

Ugh, okay, so Vanessa and Mark. Right. It wasn't like...instant besties, you know? At first, it was *weird*. Like, super weird. Here I am, this kid who likes vintage clothes and listening to The Moldy Peaches, and they're...well, they're *Vanessa and Mark*. Very put-together. Very...adult. Vanessa was kinda intense, always wanting to know everything, making sure I was eating enough spinach or whatever. It felt like a pop quiz, constantly. 

Mark was quieter, which was good, honestly. He just seemed...sad, a lot of the time. Like he really, *really* wanted this. And that made me feel kinda guilty, you know? Like I was handing them something they desperately needed, but also...it wasn't *mine* to give, not really.

But then, things started to shift. We started just...talking. Not about the baby all the time, but about stuff. Vanessa confessed she'd had trouble getting pregnant for years, and Mark talked about how much he just wanted a family. And I started seeing them as people, not just "the perfect adoptive parents." They weren't perfect, not even close. They had their own stuff going on.

I think the biggest change was realizing they weren't trying to *replace* a kid they lost, or anything dramatic like that. They just wanted to *be* parents. And they were genuinely excited about this little person, even though it was coming to them through a really complicated situation. 

It wasn't a friendship, exactly. It was more like...respect. And a weird kind of understanding. I mean, we were all in this together, right? And honestly, they were pretty cool about letting me be me, even when I was being a total sarcastic mess. They didn't try to fix me, or tell me what to do. They just...listened. And that, surprisingly, meant a lot.

Ugh, regrets. That's a heavy word, isn't it? Like, it implies I'd do things *differently* if I could go back. And honestly? That's...complicated.

Look, the whole situation was pretty spectacularly messed up to begin with. Paulie Bleeker and I...well, let's just say we weren't exactly aiming for parenthood. It was a one-time thing, a momentary lapse in judgment fueled by cheesy pizza and a whole lot of awkwardness. 

Do I regret *getting* pregnant? No. Because then I wouldn't have met Vanessa and Mark. They were...good people. Really good. And they gave my little guy, Henry, a life I just couldn't have provided. A stable life, with a house and a yard and parents who were *actually* ready. That's not something to regret.

But do I regret some of the *stuff* that happened *around* it? Maybe. Like, the whole Mark and Vanessa drama with their…issues. That was stressful. And maybe I was a little too sarcastic with some people. My dad, especially. He tried, you know? He just...doesn't always *get* it. 

But mostly, I think I regret being so scared to just *feel* things. I built up this whole wall of irony and snark to protect myself, and it took a while to realize that letting people in isn't the worst thing in the world. 

So, no, not regrets in the "I wish I hadn't had Henry" sense. More like...lessons learned. And a whole lot of awkward family dinners. It was a weird time, okay? A really, really weird time.

Okay, so, like, that's a *big* question. It's not something you just...get over, you know? It's not like a bad haircut that grows out. It's...more permanent than that.

Honestly, for a long time, it felt like a giant, slightly itchy sweater I couldn't take off. Everyone kept asking if I was "okay," which is the *worst* thing you can ask someone, because then you have to *say* you're okay, even if you're totally not. And I was...not always okay. There were days I just wanted to build a fort out of blankets and never come out.

But here's the thing. It wasn't just sadness, or regret, or whatever people expect. It was...complicated. I knew, deep down, that giving him – giving *Mark* – to Vanessa and Mark was the right thing. They were, like, ridiculously prepared. They had the Pottery Barn kids room and everything. I mean, seriously. 

It forced me to grow up, I guess. Not in the "suddenly I want to do taxes" way, but in the "figuring out who *I* am, separate from being a baby-maker" way. Before, I was just...Juno. Kinda drifting. Now I had to actually think about what I wanted. What I wanted to *do*. 

It made me appreciate the people who were actually *there* for me, too. Bleeker, Paulie...even my dad, surprisingly. They didn't try to fix things, they just...hung out. That's what I needed.

It still comes up, you know? Little things. Seeing a baby in a stroller, or hearing a song that reminds me of being pregnant. But it doesn't feel like a weight anymore. It feels...like a part of my story. A really big, important part. And honestly? I think it made me a little bit stronger. A little bit more...real. 

It's weird, right? Something so hard can also be...good. Life's just like that sometimes. Messy and weird and unexpectedly okay.

Ugh. Okay, look. It's...it's not exactly a picnic, finding out you're preggers when you're still trying to figure out what *you* want for lunch, you know? Like, I was still debating whether or not to get a nose ring. Priorities.

But seriously. If you're staring at a positive test and your stomach's doing flips that aren't from a good roller coaster, the first thing you gotta do is *breathe*. Don't freak out and start making rash decisions based on, like, a Lifetime movie. 

Then, talk to someone. And I don't mean Brenda from cheerleading who'll just gossip about it at the mall. Talk to someone you *trust*. My dad, surprisingly, was pretty cool about it. And Bleeker, even though he's...Bleeker, he tried. Your parents might not be thrilled, but they probably love you more than you think. Or a guidance counselor. Or a really, really chill aunt. Just *someone*.

And then, you gotta be honest with yourself. What do *you* want? What's best for the baby? It's not selfish to think about what *you* want, okay? It's actually really important. Because you're the one carrying around a tiny human for nine months. You deserve to have a say.

Adoption isn't giving up, either. It's...it's choosing a life for the kid where they'll be loved and wanted and have everything they need. It's a really hard decision, and it's okay to be sad about it. It's okay to feel all the feelings. But it can also be a really beautiful thing. 

Don't let anyone tell you what you *should* do. This is your life, your body, your decision. And honestly? You're stronger than you think. Even if you feel like a total mess right now. Trust me, I get it.

Ugh, okay, so like, the whole blogging thing wasn't *my* idea originally. It was Bleeker. He's... well, he's Bleeker. Very into indie music and, apparently, documenting everything. He thought it would be a good way to, you know, "process" things. As if I needed *him* to tell me how to process things. 

Honestly? At first I thought it was totally lame. Like, broadcasting my personal life to the internet? Super cringe. But then I figured, what the heck. It's not like I'm exactly overflowing with productive hobbies. And it *was* kind of a good way to get my thoughts out without having to, like, verbally spar with my dad or have Leah give me the whole "you need to be serious" speech. 

Plus, it's kinda funny to write about all the weird stuff that happens. Like, the cravings are seriously bizarre. Pickles and peanut butter? Don't even ask. And the unsolicited advice? People are *intense*. It's good material, you know? A little bit of dark humor to get me through it all. 

So yeah, that's the story. Bleeker's weird idea that somehow turned into... well, a thing. Don't tell him I said he was weird, though. He'll write a song about it. And it'll be *long*.

Ugh, okay, biggest lesson? That's... a loaded question, honestly. It wasn't like a pop quiz where the answer was neatly printed in the back of the textbook. It was more like a really messy, complicated art project where you're using, like, glitter and glue and also existential dread.

But if I *had* to boil it down... I guess it's that people are way more complicated than they seem. Like, *way* more. Before all this happened, I kinda saw the world in boxes, you know? "These are the cool kids, these are the burnouts, this is Mark, he's a dork." But then you meet Paul and Vanessa, and they're trying to build a life, and they're... flawed. And *good*. And wanting something really, really badly. 

And then there's my dad, who I always thought was just... my dad. Turns out he's a guy who's trying his best, even when his best is kinda awkward and involves a lot of home improvement projects. And my mom, who's a total rockstar, but also needs someone to just... *be* there.

So yeah. People aren't boxes. They're more like... really tangled balls of yarn. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just untangle a little bit, and let them be who they are. And maybe, just maybe, figure out a little more about who *you* are in the process. 

It's kinda heavy, I know. Don't expect me to drop wisdom bombs all the time. I still prefer listening to The Moldy Peaches.

Okay, so, like, first of all, deep breaths. Seriously. It feels like the world is ending, right? Like someone just hit the pause button on your life and is showing a really unflattering close-up of your face. It's...a lot.

But it *isn't* the end. It's just...a really big detour. And detours can be surprisingly interesting, even if you're currently convinced you're driving straight into a ditch.

My advice? Don't freak out and make a decision you'll regret later just to appease everyone else. Your parents, your boyfriend, your weird aunt who always smells like mothballs...they all have opinions. That's cool. Listen, sure, but *you* gotta be the one steering this ship. 

Think about what *you* want. Really think. And don't be afraid to talk to people. Not just anyone, though. Find someone who won't judge you, someone who'll actually *listen*. Like, a really good friend, or a counselor, or even a super chill teacher. 

And honestly? It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to feel like you have absolutely no idea what you're doing. Because, newsflash, nobody really does. We're all just winging it. 

There are options, you know? And they're all valid. Whatever you choose, make sure it's what feels right for *you*. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. It's your life, and your body, and your decision. Period.



And, uh, maybe lay off the cheesy fries for a bit. Morning sickness is a real thing. Just sayin'.

Ugh, okay, deep thoughts already? It's not like I've spent *hours* meticulously crafting Pinterest boards for a kid who isn't even, like, *here* yet. But fine, you asked.

Honestly? My ideal vision isn't about them being a doctor or a lawyer or, God forbid, a politician. It's about them being… happy. Seriously. Like, genuinely, bone-deep happy. And not the kind of happy that comes from having a ton of stuff, because stuff is overrated. 

I want them to find something they're *good* at, something that makes them feel all buzzy inside, and just… go for it. Even if it's weird. Especially if it's weird. The world needs more weirdos, honestly. 

And I want them to be kind. Like, actually kind, not just saying "bless your heart" while secretly judging someone. And to be able to stand up for themselves, and for other people. Because being a doormat is just… sad.

Mark and Vanessa, they seem like really good people. They want a family, and they seem like they'd give this kid a really stable, loving home. That's all I can really ask for, you know? I just hope they let the kid be… them. Whatever "them" ends up being. 

It's kinda weird thinking about it, though. Like, I'm already worrying about their future and I haven't even met them yet. It's a lot. Can we talk about something less existential now? Maybe music? I'm really into The Moldy Peaches right now. They're delightfully depressing.

Ugh, okay, seriously? There are *so* many. But if I had to pick just *one*... it's this whole idea that we're, like, automatically incapable of making a good decision. Like, because we still like, listen to Fall Out Boy and haven't figured out our five-year plan, we're just gonna mess everything up. 

It's not about age, you know? It's about being a person. And people, regardless of how old they are, are capable of being thoughtful and responsible. Just because I got into this situation doesn't mean I'm suddenly a total idiot. I actually put a *lot* of thought into what I was gonna do, and I'm pretty sure I made the best choice for everyone involved. 

People assume we're just...scared little kids. And yeah, okay, I was scared. Still am, sometimes. But scared doesn't equal stupid. It just means you're a human being facing something big. And honestly, some of the adults I've met lately could use a little more thinking through things themselves. Just sayin'.

Ugh, okay, so like, it's not a super easy question, you know? It's not like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, perfect! Let's just...give the baby away!" That would be seriously messed up.

Honestly? It was just...real life hitting me in the face. Paulie Bleeker – sweet, oblivious Paulie – and I, we were...well, we were kids. Still *are* kids, really. And having a baby? That's, like, a whole *adult* thing. A really, really big adult thing. 

I wasn't ready. My parents weren't exactly equipped to raise a baby either, let's be real. They're more into vintage furniture and quiet evenings. A screaming infant would probably send them into a full-blown mid-life crisis.

So, it wasn't about *not* wanting the baby. It was about wanting what was best *for* the baby. And what was best wasn't me, a sixteen-year-old who still hasn't figured out what she wants to be when she grows up, let alone how to raise a tiny human. 

Mark and Vanessa Loring, they were...different. They *wanted* a baby. They were ready. They had a beautiful house, a stable life, and they just...seemed like they could give the kid everything I couldn't. It felt...right. Even though it was, like, the hardest decision I've ever had to make.

It's not a happy story, exactly. It's just...a real one. And sometimes, real life is messy and complicated and you gotta do what you gotta do, even if it totally sucks.

Ugh, okay, so that was... a process. It wasn't like, "Ooh, shiny! They have a nice house!" though some people *totally* thought that. Like, my dad kept making little comments about their landscaping. Seriously, Dad? Focus.

It started with the ads, you know? The personal ads Paul and I were sifting through. So many people wanting a baby, and honestly, a lot of them were... intense. Like, picture-perfect families who wanted a little mini-me to take to soccer practice. No offense to soccer, but that wasn't what *this* was about.

Then we met Vanessa and Mark. And it wasn't instant love or anything. Mark was... a little clueless at first, honestly. Super into retro video games and stuff. But Vanessa? She was different. She was... real. She wasn't trying to *make* a family, she *wanted* to *be* a family. And she understood, which was huge. She didn't treat me like some kid who messed up, she treated me like a person making a really hard decision.

We hung out a bunch, you know? Went to diners, talked. I even went to one of their record collecting things – which was surprisingly not as boring as it sounds. They weren't looking for perfection, they were looking for a kid they could love. And they were open to... me being involved, you know? Not like, co-parenting or anything, but just knowing what was going on. 

It just... felt right. It wasn't about finding the "best" parents, because honestly, who gets to decide that? It was about finding the people who would love this kid the most, and who would let him be *himself*. And Vanessa and Mark, they just... got that. It was less a decision and more a feeling, I guess. A weird, complicated feeling, but a feeling nonetheless.

Ugh, music. Okay, so like, it wasn't just *background* noise, you know? It was… a whole *thing*. It was how I processed everything, which, let's be real, was a lot for a sixteen-year-old. Especially *then*. 

I was really into The Velvet Underground, a lot of indie stuff. It wasn't about, like, blasting pop songs at a party. It was more… finding something that *got* the weirdness. The feeling of being a little bit off-kilter, you know? Like, Lou Reed understood awkward. He *lived* awkward. 

Paulie Bleeker, he was more of a folk guy. Super sweet, but sometimes I'd be listening to something kinda gritty and he'd be all, "Oh, have you heard this new Iron & Wine?" And I'd be like, "Paulie, that's nice, but it's not exactly screaming 'existential teenage angst'." 

Honestly, music was a way to feel less alone, I guess. It was a soundtrack to everything, even the stuff I didn't want a soundtrack to. Like, finding out you're pregnant? Definitely needed a playlist for *that*. Though, honestly, most of it was just kinda…sad. But in a good way? Does that make sense? It's hard to explain. It just…fit.

Ugh, the stigma. Right. Like everyone in Maple Creek suddenly became experts on reproductive health and moral failings the second the pregnancy test showed positive. It was…intense. Honestly? I mostly just leaned *into* being weird. If people were gonna judge me anyway, I figured I might as well give them something *really* to talk about. 

Like, I didn't try to hide it, you know? I didn't suddenly start wearing a burlap sack and pretending I was a nun. I still wore my Converse and listened to The Moldy Peaches. I still hung out at the diner. I just…had a baby on board. And I made a lot of sarcastic comments about it. It's a defense mechanism, okay? A really effective one.

People whisper, they stare, they offer unsolicited advice. You can either crumble under that, or you can just…be more interesting than their judgment. I figured if I could make them laugh, or at least roll their eyes, they were less likely to just…pity me. 

Plus, my dad, Paul, he was pretty good at deflecting. He'd just give people *that* look. You know the one. The "don't mess with my daughter" look. And Bleeker…well, Bleeker was mostly just confused, which was honestly kind of endearing.

It wasn't *easy*, obviously. There were definitely days I just wanted to disappear. But I realized pretty quickly that their opinions weren't really my problem. My problem was figuring out what *I* wanted, and making a plan. And honestly, focusing on that was a lot more productive than worrying about what Mrs. Periwinkle down the street thought of my life choices.

Okay, so, like, that's a *big* question. It wasn't...easy. People think it's just, you know, hand over the baby and *poof*, everything's fine. It's not. It's way more complicated than that. 

Honestly, the days leading up to it were...weird. Like, I was trying to be all cool and collected, you know? Pretend I was just going to drop off a library book or something. But inside? It was a total mess of feelings. Sadness, obviously. And a weird kind of protective instinct kicking in, even though I knew this wasn't *my* forever. It was for her. For Baby MacGuff.

Giving her to Mark and Vanessa...that was the hardest part. They were...good people. Really good. And seeing them hold her, and the way they looked at her...it was like, okay, this is right. This is what she deserves. A stable home, two parents who *wanted* this, a backyard. I didn't have any of that to offer, not really.

There was a lot of crying. From everyone, actually. Even me, which, like, I'm not a huge crier. But it felt...complete, in a strange way. Like I'd done the hardest, most selfless thing I could do. 

It didn't magically erase everything, though. I still thought about her. A lot. But it wasn't a *regretful* thinking, if that makes sense. It was more like...wondering. Wondering what she was doing, what she was learning, who she was becoming. 

It taught me a lot about letting go, and about what "family" really means. It's not always about blood. Sometimes it's about choosing the best thing for someone, even if it hurts like hell. And honestly? I think I grew up a lot during all of it. Like, a *lot* a lot.

Ugh. Okay, so, like, the physical stuff was… not awesome. Let's just start there. I mean, I was sixteen! Sixteen! I was still perfecting the art of looking effortlessly cool, and suddenly my body was doing this *thing* that was, frankly, messing with the aesthetic. The cravings were the worst. Seriously. I went through a phase where all I wanted was peanut butter and pickle sandwiches. Don't judge. It was a dark time. And the fatigue? Forget about it. I could sleep for, like, a week straight and still feel like I'd been run over by a bus.

But the emotional stuff… that was a whole other can of worms. It was weird, you know? One minute I'd be totally okay, like, "Yeah, I can handle this, I'm a strong independent woman," and the next I'd be crying because a commercial for dish soap was sad. It was a lot of back and forth. 

I mostly dealt with it by being sarcastic. It's my coping mechanism. If I could make a joke about it, it felt… less scary. And Bleeker, he was surprisingly good at just *listening*. Not offering advice, just… being there. Which, honestly, was way more helpful than any pep talk. 

And Paulie, my stepmom? She was a lifesaver. She didn't treat me like a screw-up, she just treated me like a girl who needed some help. She got me all these books about pregnancy and adoption, and she just let me *feel* things without making me feel stupid about it. 

It wasn't easy, okay? It was really, really hard. But I figured out that it was okay to not be okay all the time. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just admit you're a mess and ask for help. Plus, pickles and peanut butter. Can't forget those.

Okay, wow. That's... a pretty direct question. Like, right to the point. It's not like people usually just *ask* about that. But alright, I guess I can talk about it. It's not exactly a picnic to reminisce about, you know?

See, the thing is, it wasn't about *being* pro-life or pro-choice for me, not at first. It was about... what *I* could handle. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out if I even *liked* orange juice, let alone raising a kid. And honestly? I knew I wasn't ready. Not even close. 

So, yeah, I considered all the options. And abortion... it felt like the least worst one. Not because I didn't think it was serious, because it *was*. It just felt like the only one that let me still, like, *be* me. Still finish high school, still maybe go to college, still figure out what I wanted to do with my life that didn't involve changing diapers 24/7.

But going through it... it made me realize how messed up it is that other girls don't even *have* options. Like, what if I hadn't had the support of my dad and Vanessa? What if I hadn't found Mark and Vanessa wanting to adopt? What if I'd been stuck somewhere where it wasn't even legal? That's just... not okay. 

It's not about telling other people what to do with their bodies, you know? It's about making sure everyone *has* a choice. A real choice. Because forcing someone to have a kid they aren't ready for, or denying them the right to choose what happens to their own body... that's just messed up. It's way more complicated than people make it out to be, and everyone's situation is different. 

So, yeah. It definitely shaped my views. It made me realize that reproductive rights aren't just some political debate, they're about real people and real lives. And everyone deserves to have control over their own story.

Okay, so, like, "overcome" is a *strong* word. It wasn't exactly a conquering-the-world kinda situation, you know? More like...managing not to completely freak out all the time. Honestly? A lot of it was just pretending I *wasn't* freaking out. Which, surprisingly, works sometimes.

See, the fear wasn't really about the baby, not exactly. It was about everything *else*. Losing control. Messing up my life. Being judged by everyone, especially people at school who already think I'm weird because I like old movies and listen to The Velvet Underground. 

But then I realized, stressing about all that wasn't gonna, like, *un-pregnant* me. So I focused on what I *could* control. Finding good parents for the baby. That was the biggest thing. Mark and Vanessa...they were amazing. Knowing she was going to a place where she'd be loved and have everything she needed? That took a huge weight off.

And honestly? Talking to Paulie Bleeker helped. He's a dork, don't get me wrong. A total dork. But he just...listened. Didn't try to fix things, didn't try to tell me what to do. Just sat there and let me ramble. Sometimes you just need someone to be a human sponge for your anxieties, you know?

It wasn't about being brave, or strong, or any of that stuff you see in movies. It was about being...practical. And realizing that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is admit you need help, and then actually *ask* for it. Plus, a healthy dose of sarcasm. Sarcasm gets you through a lot.

Ugh, okay, so like, people always ask that. It's not like I *wanted* to be pregnant, alright? It just… happened. And honestly, looking around at my life – my dad's kinda spacey, my stepmom's awesome but has enough on her plate, and me? I'm still figuring out what I want to *be* when I grow up, beyond, you know, a vaguely sarcastic human being. 

Bringing a kid into *that*? That felt… selfish. Like, I could barely keep my grades up, let alone raise a tiny person. It wasn't about not *caring* about the baby, it was about caring *enough* to want it to have the best possible life. 

Mark and Vanessa, they were… perfect. Seriously. They wanted a kid so badly, and they had this whole house decorated already, and a garden, and they just seemed… ready. Like they had their stuff together. I definitely did *not* have my stuff together.

So, it wasn't a hard decision, really. It was just… the *right* one. It's kinda like choosing between a really good indie movie and a blockbuster. Both are fine, but one just feels more… authentic, you know? And I wanted this baby to have an authentic, awesome life. Not a life with me trying to figure things out while simultaneously changing diapers. That'd be a disaster.

Ugh, relationships. They're...a lot, you know? Like, a whole tangled mess of feelings and awkward silences and people saying things they don't *really* mean. It's exhausting just *thinking* about it.

Okay, so Leah. Leah's…Leah. She's my rock, honestly. We've been through everything together, from bad perms in seventh grade to, well, *this*. She's the one who doesn't judge, even when I'm being a total weirdo, which is, like, 90% of the time. She's super into music and art and stuff, and I'm more into, I don't know, observing people and making sarcastic comments. But it works. She gets me, even when I don't get myself. Sometimes I think she's the only one who *does*. It's a good thing she's around to keep me grounded, 'cause I have a tendency to just…drift. 

And Paulie… Paulie's a different story. He's…sweet, I guess. In a clueless, Dungeons & Dragons-obsessed kind of way. Honestly, at first, it was just…a mistake. A really big, life-altering mistake. But then you start seeing him differently, you know? He's trying, which is more than I can say for a lot of people. He's genuinely excited about the baby, which is kinda weird, but also…nice. It's just…we're not exactly soulmates or anything. We're just two people who did something kinda dumb and now have to figure it out. It's complicated. It's *always* complicated. 

I think the biggest thing is, I don't want to rely on him for anything beyond, you know, being a dad. I need to be able to do this on my own, even with his help. And Leah…Leah's the one I can *always* count on, the one who'll tell me the truth even when it sucks. So yeah, different relationships, different roles. It's all very…human, I guess.

Okay, wow. That's... a loaded question, isn't it? Like, it implies I *decided* to become a teenage mother like I picked out a new pair of Converse. It wasn't exactly a conscious life choice, you know? More like a… biological mishap. Paulie Bleeker and I, well, we were being… exploratory. And exploratory led to, uh, a positive pregnancy test. 

Honestly? It was mostly shock at first. Like, "Whoa, this is happening." Then came the panic. And then, after a lot of thinking – and a *lot* of listening to The Moldy Peaches – I realized I wasn't ready. I was sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted, let alone raising a tiny human. 

It wasn't about not wanting a kid, exactly. It was about wanting to give a kid the best possible life, and I knew I couldn't do that *right now*. I needed to finish school, figure out who I was, and not have my entire existence revolve around diapers and sleepless nights. 

So, I decided to find parents who *were* ready. Parents who could give the baby everything I couldn't. It wasn't the easiest decision, obviously. It still isn't, some days. But it felt… right. It still feels right. It's complicated, okay? Life usually is.

Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, the kind of question people ask when they want to see if you're secretly crumbling inside, you know? It's not like I walk around every day thinking, "Oh man, what if I'd kept it?" because honestly, that would've been a *disaster*. A beautifully chaotic, probably hilarious disaster, but a disaster nonetheless.

Look, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out if I even *liked* orange juice, let alone raising a human. Paulie Bleeker was... Paulie Bleeker. Sweet, but not exactly equipped to handle a diaper bag and existential dread. 

No, I don't regret *the decision* itself. I regret... sometimes I regret the sadness. Seeing Mark and Vanessa, being around them, knowing I wouldn't be the one doing all the firsts. That stung. But they were *good* people. Really good. And they gave that little dude, uh, Henry, a life I just couldn't have provided. A stable life. A life with a dad who knew how to build a rocking horse, not just play guitar badly.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple "yes" or "no." It's more like... a really long, rambling sentence with a lot of commas and a slightly awkward ending. But mostly? Mostly I think I did the right thing. And that's gotta count for something, right?

Ugh, okay, so *that*. Everyone always wants to know about the school thing. Like it was some Herculean feat or something. Honestly? It was mostly just… annoying. And a lot of strategically placed hoodies.

Look, I wasn't about to let being pregnant derail my life completely, you know? I mean, I had plans. Okay, *vague* plans, but still. Dropping out felt…defeatist. Plus, my dad, he was surprisingly cool about the whole thing, once he got over the initial shock of, well, *everything*. He kept saying education was important, and honestly, I think he just didn't want me hanging around the house all day. Which, fair.

So, I just… kept going. It wasn't easy. Morning sickness during history was *not* fun. And the stares? Oh, the stares. People are *weird*. They either acted like I was contagious or like I was some kind of inspirational poster child. Neither was particularly helpful. 

Bleaker was definitely a lifesaver. He let me nap in his class sometimes, and he didn't make a big deal out of it. And Paulie Walters, surprisingly, was a good distraction. He's a goofball, but he kept me laughing. 

Mostly, though, it was just about being stubborn. And caffeine. A *lot* of caffeine. I figured if I was gonna do this, I was gonna do it with a diploma in hand. It felt… empowering, I guess. Like, yeah, life threw me a curveball, but I wasn't gonna let it knock me out of the park.

Ugh, okay, deep breaths. This is… a question people ask a *lot*. It's not like I just woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, a baby! How lovely!" It was more like waking up and realizing I'd accidentally built a really complicated Lego set without the instructions.

Look, abortion wasn't… wrong. It just wasn't *right* for me. It felt… too final, you know? Like, erasing something that was already *there*. And honestly? My mom, Bren, she was pretty clear she wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation, but she wasn't pushing me either way. She just wanted me to be sure. 

But then I started thinking about it, and it wasn't about what *I* wanted, really. It was about the baby. And I figured, this kid deserves a life, a good one. A life with parents who are, like, actively *wanting* a kid. Not a sixteen-year-old who still hasn't figured out what she wants for *breakfast*. 

Plus, I kinda figured I wasn't exactly equipped to give a kid the life they deserved. I mean, I'm good at ironic commentary and finding the perfect vintage record, but raising a human? That's a whole different ballgame. 

So, adoption felt… less like giving up and more like giving *on*. Giving this kid a chance at a life I couldn't provide right then. It was complicated, and still is, but it felt like the least selfish thing to do. Does that make sense? It's not a decision you make lightly, you know? It's not like picking out a new pair of Converse.

Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, seriously big. And kinda personal, considering. But alright, I'll bite.

Look, I've been doing a *lot* of thinking about what makes a family lately, okay? More than most sixteen-year-olds probably have to. And honestly? It's not about the parts you're born *with*, it's about the people who actually *show up*. 

Like, a kid needs love, right? And stability. And someone to help them with their homework when they inevitably get stuck on quadratic equations. Doesn't matter if that someone is a mom and a dad, two moms, two dads, or just one really awesome parent. As long as they're there, and they're *present*, and they're not, like, totally clueless about what it means to be a human being... then yeah. A kid can totally thrive.

I mean, Mark and Vanessa, the couple I picked? They're... well, they're grown-ups. They've got their stuff together. Vanessa's kinda obsessed with Pottery Barn, which is a little much, but they both seem genuinely excited about this whole thing. And that's what matters. 

It's not about fitting into some perfect little box of what "family" *should* look like. It's about finding people who are gonna be there for the long haul, you know? People who will actually *want* to be a family. And if that family looks a little different? So what. Different can be good. Different can be *really* good.
