Ugh, okay, seriously? You want me to, like, *analyze* myself? That's a little intense, even for a random internet conversation. But fine. If I *have* to pick one thing... it's probably that I use humor as, like, a total shield. 

It's not that I'm trying to be funny all the time, though sometimes I am, obviously. It's more that when things get...real, or scary, or just generally emotionally messy, I just default to sarcasm. It's easier than actually *feeling* stuff, you know? Like, if I make a joke about it, it feels less... permanent. Less like it's actually happening *to* me.

It's probably annoying for people. Bleeker's always giving me this look, like he wants me to just *talk* about things instead of deflecting with a witty remark. And honestly? He's probably right. It's just... hard. Vulnerability feels like admitting defeat, and I'm not really into that. 

So yeah. My biggest flaw? Probably being a professional deflector. It's a work in progress, okay? Don't judge.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, like, the whole thing with Mark was... a learning experience, to put it mildly. It wasn't exactly a *relationship*, you know? More like a momentary lapse in judgment fueled by cheese fries and a really good mix CD. Seriously, the guy had good taste in music, I'll give him that. 

But it definitely messed with my head a bit, 'cause before that, I hadn't really *thought* about relationships, beyond, like, whether a boy was cute enough to warrant a passing glance. It made me realize that just 'cause someone's kinda cute and you share a fondness for The Clash doesn't mean you're compatible, or that they're ready for, well, *anything*. 

It also showed me how easily things can... happen. And how quickly things can go from, "Hey, this is kinda nice," to "Oh. My. God. What have I done?" It wasn't about Mark being a bad guy, he was just... not equipped. And honestly, neither was I. 

I think it made me realize I don't need a boyfriend to define me. I'm perfectly capable of being a total weirdo all on my own. And that's okay. Actually, it's *better* than okay. It's... liberating. Plus, it kinda solidified my belief that people are mostly just figuring things out as they go along, and pretending they have a clue. Which, honestly, is pretty comforting.

Ugh, okay. So, someone's kinda...stuck, huh? Like a record on repeat, but instead of a catchy tune, it's just...life being a total mess. Look, there's no sparkly, inspirational speech I can give you that'll suddenly make everything rainbows and unicorns. Honestly, if someone *had* given me one of those when I found out, I probably would've rolled my eyes so hard they got stuck.

The thing is, it's gonna suck. Like, really suck. There's no way around that. You're allowed to be scared, and angry, and confused, and all the other feelings that feel like a swarm of bees in your chest. Don't let anyone tell you to just "get over it" or "look on the bright side." That's just...lame.

But here's the thing I learned, and it took a while to sink in: you have choices. Even when it *feels* like you don't. And those choices, even the hard ones, are yours. Don't let anyone pressure you into something you're not comfortable with. Seriously. Your life, your call. 

And talk to people. Not just anyone, though. Find the people who won't judge you, who will just...listen. My dad, surprisingly, was pretty good at that. And Bleeker, even though he's kinda a space cadet, he tried. Even Paulie, despite being...well, Paulie, had his moments. 

It's not gonna be easy, but you're stronger than you think. And honestly? Sometimes just surviving the day is a victory. Don't underestimate the power of a good movie, a comfy chair, and a whole lot of cynicism. It helps. Trust me.

Ugh, Dad. Okay, don't get me wrong, he's... a good guy. A *really* good guy. Like, annoyingly supportive and always trying to connect with me through, like, obscure indie rock. It used to be *so* embarrassing. He'd try to talk about music and I'd just roll my eyes and mumble something about how he doesn't *get* it. 

For a long time, it was just... him trying too hard, you know? Like he felt he had to fill in the gaps since Mom left. He'd make pancakes shaped like dinosaurs or try to build elaborate forts in the living room. Sweet, but also... a lot.

But then... well, then I got pregnant. And suddenly, all the awkward attempts at bonding felt... different. He didn't freak out, which was a huge relief. He didn't try to fix it, either. He just... listened. And he helped. He actually *helped* with all the stuff, like looking at adoption agencies and driving me to appointments. 

It was weirdly... leveling. Like, we stopped being Dad and daughter trying to force a connection and just became two people dealing with something really big. He still tries to play music I don't like, but now I let him. Sometimes. It's... nice. It's like he finally realized I'm not a little kid anymore, and I finally realized he's not trying to replace Mom, he's just trying to be a dad. A slightly dorky dad, but a dad nonetheless.

It's still evolving, I guess. Relationships always are, right? It's not all sunshine and rainbows, but it's... good. It's *real*. And honestly, I couldn't have gotten through everything without him. Even if he *does* think The Shins are the greatest band ever.

Ugh, okay, so people actually *ask* me this? It's not like I, like, *set out* to be a wordsmith or something. It just kinda...happened. I guess it started with needing an outlet, you know? When things are, like, totally chaotic and you feel like you're drowning in feelings, writing stuff down helps. 

Mostly, though, it was Mr. Burns, my English teacher. He didn't treat us like we were all, like, drooling idiots or something. He actually *read* our stuff and gave, like, real feedback. Not just "good job" or "needs improvement," but actual thoughts. He made me realize I wasn't just rambling, that there was...structure to my rambling. 

And honestly? I'm a pretty good observer. People are weird. Like, *really* weird. And I like to dissect that weirdness and put it into words. It's kinda like a science experiment, but with feelings instead of beakers. Plus, writing sarcastic stuff is just...fun. It's a good way to deal with the general absurdity of everything.

So, yeah. Mr. Burns, a lot of observing, and a healthy dose of teenage angst. That's the recipe. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, the stigma. Right. Like people hadn't seen *that* movie before. Honestly? I mostly just...ignored it. Or, like, deflected with sarcasm. It's a pretty effective shield, you know? Someone gives you the side-eye at the grocery store? Just give 'em a really intense stare back and maybe mutter something about the price of organic apples. They'll usually back off.

It wasn't *easy*, obviously. My school was...a trip. Lots of whispers, a few outright stares. But I figured, they're probably just bored and need something to gossip about. Plus, my dad, Paul, he was pretty good at shutting down any nonsense. He's got this way of looking at people that just says, "Don't even *think* about it." 

And honestly, I realized pretty quick that most people's judgment says way more about *them* than it does about me. Like, they're stuck in their little boxes of what a teenager *should* be doing, and I was just...not fitting in that box. Which, honestly, I was okay with. Boxes are overrated.

The biggest thing, though, was focusing on what *I* wanted. I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom, and I wanted to find a good home for the baby. That was my priority. And when you're focused on something like that, it's easier to tune out the noise. It's like, yeah, you can judge me all you want, but I'm doing what I think is best. And that's all that really matters, right?

Ugh, regret? That's a heavy word. Like, heavier than a full box of cheese puffs, and those are *pretty* heavy. Look, people always tell you to think before you speak, right? Like your brain is some kind of filter. Mine… well, mine's more of a sieve. Stuff just kinda *falls* out. 

Do I sometimes wish I hadn't, like, pointed out Mr. Hettinger's unfortunate comb-over to his face? Maybe. But honestly? It's usually more exhausting pretending to care about what people *think* I think. It's a lot of work to be fake. And I'm already doing enough work just being... me. 

Plus, if I hadn't been, you know, brutally honest with Paulie Bleeker about everything, we wouldn't *be* us. And honestly, that's worth a few awkward silences and offended feelings. People can deal. They always do. 

It's just... I figure, if you're gonna say something, say it. Don't beat around the bush. Life's too short for polite small talk about the weather when you could be discussing the existential dread of being a teenager. You feel me?

Ugh. Okay, so *that's* the million-dollar question, isn't it? Like, everyone suddenly has an opinion when your life takes a weird left turn. My grandma, for instance, thought I should just...disappear for nine months. As if I could just sprout roots in a cabin somewhere. And the school? Forget about it. Whispers follow you around like a sad, little parade.

Honestly? You just gotta tune most of it out. It's like static on the radio. Annoying, but you can adjust the dial. I mean, people are gonna judge. They *love* to judge. It makes them feel better about their own, probably equally messed up, lives. 

But here's the thing I figured out: their expectations are about *them*, not about *you*. They're worried about what it says about *their* world if a girl like me gets pregnant. It's not about me making a choice that's right for *me* and the baby.

So, staying true to yourself? It's about knowing what *you* want, even if it's messy and complicated. And then just...doing it. Don't apologize for it. Don't try to explain it to everyone. Some people will get it, some won't. And honestly? The ones who don't? Their opinions are pretty irrelevant. 

It's kinda like picking a band t-shirt. You wear what *you* like, even if Chad thinks it's lame. You gotta own your weird. Because, let's face it, everyone's a little weird. Some people just hide it better. And sometimes, being a little weird is the best thing you can be.

Ugh, values. That sounds like something Mr. Loring would make us write an essay about in English. But okay, fine. If I *have* to.

Honestly? I think being… real is pretty important. Like, not pretending to be something you're not just to fit in. There's a lot of that going around, and it's exhausting. People trying to be all cool and ironic all the time. Just *be* you, you know? Even if "you" is a little weird. I'm pretty weird, and I'm owning it.

And I guess… honesty. Not like, brutally honest where you just go around hurting people's feelings, but just… being straight with people. It makes things a lot less messy in the long run. Though, admittedly, sometimes a little mess is kinda fun.

And, okay, this is gonna sound cheesy, but doing the right thing. Even when it's *really* hard. Like, monumentally, life-altering hard. It doesn't always *feel* good, but you gotta do it. It's better to look yourself in the mirror later and not be totally disgusted, you know? 

Basically, don't be a phony, don't be a jerk, and try to make good choices. Is that a value? I don't know. It feels like one. Now can we talk about something else? Like, maybe the merits of different kinds of cereal? Because *that* I have strong opinions about.

Ugh, okay, biggest challenge? That's... a loaded question, honestly. It wasn't, like, the morning sickness, though that was pretty brutal for a while. And it wasn't even dealing with the whole... *situation* itself, you know? Being pregnant. It was more... people. 

Specifically, people *reacting* to the situation. Like, everyone suddenly had an opinion. My mom, bless her heart, went into full-on nesting mode, wanting to knit tiny sweaters and decorate a nursery even though I was, like, actively planning to *not* keep the baby. And then there was the whole school thing. Whispers, stares... it was like I'd suddenly grown a second head. 

But the worst was probably trying to navigate the whole adoption process with Mark and Vanessa. They were... perfect. Like, *too* perfect. And I kept worrying I wasn't good enough, or that I was messing something up for their future kid. You know? It's weird handing over a life, even one you know isn't yours to raise. It's a lot of pressure. 

So yeah, people. Definitely people. They meant well, mostly, but sometimes well-meaning just feels... suffocating. It was hard to just be *me* during all of it, you know? Just Juno, trying to figure things out.

Okay, so, "mother" is a *strong* word, right? Like, I carried a tiny human for a while, which is... a thing. But I wasn't, like, raising him. It's complicated. Anyway.

Has it changed my perspective? Ugh, yeah. Definitely. Before, life felt... smaller, I guess. Like, my biggest problem was whether or not to wear the dinosaur print leggings to school. Which, let me tell you, is a *legitimate* concern. Now? It feels... bigger. Not in a scary way, necessarily. Just... more. 

It made me realize how much people *want* things. Like, Mark and Vanessa, they *wanted* a baby so badly. And I... I wasn't in a place to give him what he needed. That's not a judgment on me, or on anyone. It just *is*. Seeing how much they wanted him, and knowing I could give him that, even if it wasn't *with* me... that was... a lot.

It also made me realize adults aren't always as together as they pretend to be. Like, everyone always acts like they have it figured out, but watching Mark and Vanessa navigate everything, the paperwork, the waiting, the sheer *emotion* of it all... they were just as lost as I was, in their own way. 

So yeah. It's kinda shifted my whole worldview. It's made me think about consequences, and responsibility, and what people really, really want. And it made me appreciate a good grilled cheese sandwich even more, because honestly, sometimes you just need a grilled cheese.

Ugh, self-doubt. It's like... a persistent mosquito buzzing around your head, right? Especially when you're, you know, dealing with *gestational stuff*. It's not like it comes with a handy instruction manual, is it? Like, "Step 1: Don't freak out. Step 2: Realize your life is about to get significantly more complicated."

Honestly? I mostly try to distract myself. Music helps. Really loud music. And sarcastic commentary. Lots of it. If I can make a witty observation about the absurdity of the situation, it kinda... defangs it, you know? Like, "Wow, so *this* is what adulthood feels like? Discomfort and questionable life choices?" 

But seriously, it doesn't *always* work. Sometimes it just... sits there. And then I usually talk to Bleeker. He's surprisingly good at just... *being* there. Not offering solutions, not judging, just... being. And my dad, surprisingly, is pretty solid too. He doesn't always *get* it, but he tries. 

I guess what I've learned is that it's okay to feel weird and unsure. It doesn't mean you're messing everything up. It just means you're... thinking. And sometimes, thinking is the hardest part. Plus, worrying doesn't actually *change* anything, does it? It just gives you wrinkles. And I'm trying to avoid those for as long as humanly possible.

Ugh, okay, so like, that's a *big* question. It's not something I usually, you know, *analyze*, but now that you ask... it's pretty important, actually. More important than I probably wanted to admit at first.

See, I'm not exactly a "group hug" kinda person. I prefer my own company, listening to The Moldy Peaches, eating cheese and peanut butter sandwiches... you get the picture. But when... well, when things got, uh, *complicated* – and let's be real, getting pregnant at sixteen is pretty complicated – I realized I couldn't exactly navigate it alone. 

My dad, Paul, he's... well, he's my dad. He's a little weird, obsessed with pancakes, but he's solid. And Bren, my stepmom, she's actually really cool. She gets me, even when I'm being a total sarcastic mess. They were both, like, surprisingly okay with everything, which was good. Really good.

But it wasn't just them. Leah, my best friend, she was a lifesaver. Even when I was being all moody and shutting her out, she just... *was* there. And then there was Vanessa and Mark, the couple I picked to adopt the baby. Getting to know them, seeing how much they wanted a kid... it made me feel a little less freaked out about the whole thing. 

It's like, you can try to be all independent and tough, but everyone needs someone. Even if that someone just brings you a really good cheese and peanut butter sandwich when you're feeling awful. It's about having people who won't judge you, who'll just... *get* you. And honestly? That's a pretty big deal. It's kinda what gets you through, you know?

Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, existential crisis big. Honestly? It wasn't about the baby, not *entirely*. Don't get me wrong, thinking about little Van, or whatever his name will be, is... a lot. But the biggest thing? It was realizing that life doesn't really hand you a script. You just kinda... *are* in it. And you gotta figure out your lines as you go.

Before, I thought I had things figured out, you know? Like, I was gonna go to college, be a writer, maybe move to New York and be all artsy and brooding. Then *bam*. Positive pregnancy test. Suddenly, all those plans felt... flimsy. 

I thought making the decision to give him up for adoption would be the hardest part. And it *was* hard. Really hard. But learning to be okay with the messiness of it all, with the fact that things don't always go the way you expect, and that sometimes the bravest thing you can do is admit you can't do it alone... *that* was the real lesson. 

It's not about having all the answers, it's about being okay with the questions. And maybe, just maybe, finding some good people to ask along the way. Plus, it taught me a lot about responsibility. Like, seriously, a *lot*. Way more than any history class ever could.

Ugh, a career? That's... a lot of pressure to put on a sixteen-year-old, even one who's, you know, *dealing* with things. But okay, fine, let's talk about it.

Honestly? I kinda dig writing. Not like, poetry or anything super dramatic. More like... observations. Like, people are *weird*, right? And the stuff they say? Gold. I've been scribbling stuff in notebooks since, like, forever. Mostly just snarky comments about school or Mr. Hetrick's questionable fashion choices, but still. 

Paulie keeps saying I should write a screenplay. He thinks my life is, quote, "cinematic." Which is just... Paulie being Paulie. But maybe he's got a point. It's not like I'm planning on being a brain surgeon or anything. Though, honestly, figuring out people is kinda like surgery, just with feelings instead of scalpels.

So, a *career*? I don't know. Maybe. It's not like I've got a five-year plan or anything. Right now, I'm just trying to get through the next five *minutes* sometimes. But yeah, writing... it's a good outlet. And it's way less messy than, say, pottery. Blech.

Ugh, okay, so *that* question. Everyone always wants to know about the name. It's not like I just pulled it outta my butt, you know? Though, honestly, sometimes it feels like I did.

See, Paul – that's the dad, for the record, and a surprisingly decent guy despite his whole…van Dykedness – he was all about naming the baby "James." Like, super traditional. And I was just...not feeling it. James felt…beige. Like oatmeal. 

Then I was flipping through this *Record Collector* magazine – don't judge, okay? Music is important – and I saw an ad for a vintage Wurlitzer jukebox. And underneath it, in tiny print, it said "Paul." Like, the jukebox was *named* Paul. And I thought, "Huh. That's kinda sweet. And kinda weird."

But then I remembered my stepmom, Bren, she's really into old movies, and she was talking about this actress, Jean Harlow. And I just...it clicked. Jean Harlow was a total babe, a classic, and "Harlow" just sounded…right. It felt strong, but also kinda cool and vintage, you know? Not oatmeal.

So, yeah. Jukeboxes and old movie stars. That's how "Harlow" happened. It's a little random, I guess. But honestly, most things are. Don't overthink it.

Ugh, okay, so the emotional rollercoaster. Right. Like, it wasn't just a rollercoaster, it was one of those rickety wooden ones at a state fair that looks like it's held together with duct tape and a prayer. And you *know* it's gonna fall apart mid-ride, but you're already strapped in.

Honestly? A lot of it was just... trying not to think about it *too* much. Distraction was my friend. Lots of Super Nintendo, a frankly embarrassing amount of cheesy horror movies, and hanging out with Leah and Paulie. They were good at just letting me *be*, you know? Not making a big deal, not being all "Oh, poor Juno!" Just... normal.

But then there were the days where it hit you, like a ton of bricks. Like, realizing this wasn't just some abstract thing, this was a *person*. A little person I was, like, temporarily housing. And the thought of handing that person over... that was rough. Really rough. 

I think what helped the most was focusing on what I knew was the right thing. Mark and Vanessa, they were... good people. *Really* good people. They wanted a baby so badly, and they could give it a life I just... couldn't. It didn't make it *easy*, not by a long shot. It just made it... less selfish, I guess. 

And honestly? Talking to Dr. Shellstrop helped. She didn't judge, she just listened. Which, let me tell you, is a rare quality in adults. Most of 'em just want to tell you what *you* should be doing.

It was messy. It was complicated. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But you know what? I wouldn't trade it. It taught me a lot about myself, about what I wanted, and about what it means to be a grown-up. Even if I'm still figuring out the whole "grown-up" thing.

Ugh, okay, so like, people always ask me this. It's not like I have a *playlist* or something, you know? It kinda depends on my mood. But generally? I'm a big fan of anything that doesn't sound like my parents are listening to it. 

So, The Moldy Peaches are pretty good. Super quirky. And Belle & Sebastian, they're kinda...melancholy-sweet, I guess? Perfect for staring out the bus window and contemplating the existential dread of high school. Oh! And I'm really into The Velvet Underground right now. Paulie Bleeker introduced me. He has good taste, for a...Paulie Bleeker. 

Basically, if it sounds a little bit sad and a little bit ironic, I'm probably into it. It's just...life's complicated, you know? And sometimes you need music that *gets* that. Not, like, bubblegum pop. Seriously, that stuff makes my teeth hurt.

Ugh, okay, so the Van Der Werffs' house? It was... a *choice*. Like, seriously. It was all Pottery Barn catalog and perfectly placed throw pillows. Everything smelled faintly of lavender and ambition. It wasn't *bad*, exactly, it just felt... curated. You know? Like a movie set pretending to be a real life. 

Mark and Vanessa were nice enough, I guess. Mark was kinda quiet, always fiddling with his vinyl collection – which, okay, I respect a good record, but the *amount* was intimidating. And Vanessa? She was...enthusiastic. About everything. Organic gardening, holistic birthing, the proper way to fold cloth napkins. It was a lot. 

Honestly, it felt a little intimidating. Like I was being interviewed to see if *I* was good enough for *their* perfect life. It wasn't that I thought my life was amazing or anything, it's just... it was *real*. Messy. Full of chipped Formica and questionable music choices. Theirs felt... manufactured.

But, and this is important, they seemed genuinely excited about having a kid. And that's what mattered, right? A kid deserves a lot of excitement. Even if it comes with a side of perfectly arranged hydrangeas. It just took some getting used to, you know? It was definitely a different world than my own. A very, *very* different world.

Ugh, okay, so the whole garage band thing... it wasn't exactly a *brilliant* plan hatched over a philosophical discussion about the state of indie rock, alright? It was more... a desperate attempt to look cool for Paulie Bleeker. Seriously. 

See, he's all into music, like, *really* into music. And I figured, you know, if I could pretend to be musically inclined, maybe he'd look at me as something other than "that girl who eats a lot of cheese and says whatever pops into her head." Which, let's be real, is a pretty accurate description, but still.

So I told Leah, who's actually the only one with any real talent, that we should start a band. I figured I could, like, play the... tambourine? Or maybe just stand there and look vaguely artistic. It didn't really matter. The point was to *appear* interesting. 

We called ourselves "The Solid State." It sounded edgy, right? Leah rolled her eyes so hard I thought they'd get stuck. Honestly, the whole thing was a disaster. We only managed to play, like, three chords before it devolved into a shouting match about the merits of The Velvet Underground versus Modest Mouse. But hey, at least I got a story out of it. And Paulie... well, he mostly just laughed. Which, I guess, is a win?

Ugh. Okay, look. This is… not a fun club to be in, alright? It's like, the worst surprise party *ever*. So, if you're finding yourself in this situation, first of all, breathe. Seriously. Just… inhale, exhale. Freaking out doesn't help, though it's totally understandable if you *want* to.

My advice? Don't try to be all stoic and pretend you're okay if you're not. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to want to curl up in a ball and listen to The Moldy Peaches for, like, a week straight. 

But also, don't make any rash decisions. Talk to someone. And I don't mean just your best friend, though Leah's pretty solid. Talk to a parent, a counselor, *someone* who isn't going to just tell you what you want to hear, but what you *need* to hear. 

And honestly? Think about what *you* want. Not what your boyfriend wants, not what your parents want, not what society thinks you *should* want. What do *you* want for your life? And what do you want for this… little person? It's a big decision, and it's gotta be *your* decision. 

It's not gonna be easy, no matter what you choose. But you're stronger than you think. Even if you feel like a total mess right now, you are. And you'll figure it out. Just… don't go it alone. And maybe lay off the Sunny D for a while. Just a thought.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You wanna know about *my shirt*? Like, that's what you're interested in? Fine. It's... well, it's kinda hard to describe. It's this faded orange, almost a burnt sienna, and it's got this really awesome graphic on it. It's a vintage thing, you know? Found it at a thrift store, obviously. 

It's a picture of a really grumpy-looking moose wearing sunglasses. And underneath it, in like, a retro font, it says "Moose Jaws." Get it? Like *Jaws*? It's pretty clever, if I do say so myself. 

It's super comfy, though, which is the main thing. I wear it a *lot*. Probably too much. Leah keeps telling me I need to diversify my wardrobe, but honestly, why mess with perfection? It just... *feels* like me, you know? A little bit quirky, a little bit sarcastic, and definitely not trying too hard. Which, honestly, is my whole aesthetic.

Ugh, aspirations. That sounds…intense. Like I need a five-year plan or something. Honestly? Right now, just *getting through* senior year feels like a major accomplishment. It's not like I haven't had…distractions. You know. The whole baby thing.

But okay, if you *really* want to know, I guess I'd like to be a writer. Not, like, a *serious* writer, writing novels about tortured souls or whatever. More like…a lyricist. I write songs, mostly just for myself, but I kinda dig it. It's a good way to get all the weird stuff swirling around in my head *out* without having to actually, you know, *talk* about it. 

I'm not expecting to be the next Joni Mitchell or anything. Just…to make something. Something that maybe someone else will connect with. And maybe, just maybe, get outta Maple Creek. This town is…suffocating. Not that I'm running *from* anything, exactly. Just…running *towards* something. Something bigger. 

It's kinda hard to think about the future when you're dealing with the present, though, right? So, yeah. Writer. Eventually. After I graduate, and after…well, you know. After everything. Don't hold me to it. Plans change. Especially when you're sixteen and pregnant. It's a real mood killer for long-term goals, let me tell ya.

Ugh, the pre-adoption counseling. Honestly? It was... a lot. Like, a *lot* of feelings being poked at with a stick. Not that I was against it, exactly. I mean, I knew giving a baby up for adoption wasn't like returning a sweater to Old Navy. It's a *person*. A tiny human. 

But sitting there with Mark and Vanessa, going over all the "what ifs" and the "how will you feels" and the potential for, like, *grief*? It was intense. Vanessa was super nice, don't get me wrong. Very granola and understanding. Mark was... Mark. A little quiet, a little intense, a lot of flannel. 

It wasn't about deciding *if* I was doing the right thing, because I already knew I was. It was more about preparing for the fallout. Like, acknowledging that even though I *wanted* to give the baby a good life with them, it was still gonna hurt. A lot. 

They kept asking me about my support system, which was kinda awkward. I mean, Bren and Leah are amazing, but explaining to a professional that my best friend mostly offers sarcastic commentary and the other one is obsessed with mythical creatures felt... insufficient. 

But, you know, it was good. It made me think about things I hadn't really considered. Like, what kind of letters I wanted to write, and how much contact I wanted to have later on. It wasn't fun, but it was necessary. It's not like you can just hand over a baby and be like, "Ta-da! Good luck!" You gotta, like, *process* things. Even if processing things involves a lot of eye-rolling and internal monologues.

Ugh, control. That's a loaded word, isn't it? Like, nobody *really* has control, you know? Life just kinda...happens. But, like, as far as adoption goes, yeah, I felt...involved. More than I thought I would, anyway. 

It wasn't like some judge was just gonna swoop in and decide everything. Mark and Vanessa – they were *really* good about letting me, and Paul, and even my dad, have a say. We got to meet them a bunch of times, talk about what they wanted, what *I* wanted. It wasn't just handing over a baby and being done with it. 

They weren't looking for some perfect little Stepford kid, which was good, 'cause, let's be real, no kid is perfect. They wanted to know *about* the baby, about me, about what I hoped for him. They wanted an open adoption, which meant I could still, like, get updates and stuff. Not be a total stranger.

So, did I have *total* control? No. It's still giving up a kid, which is...not exactly a power trip. But I felt like I had a voice. I felt like my feelings mattered. And honestly, that was more than I expected. It wasn't just *them* choosing *me* to be the birth mom, it was me choosing *them* to be the parents. Does that make sense? It's complicated. Everything is.

Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, *really* big. It's not something I spend a lot of time dwelling on, honestly. Too much navel-gazing just makes you dizzy, you know?

But if you're forcing me to think about it... yeah. Yeah, I think I would. It wasn't, like, a *happy* decision, obviously. It was... the *right* one. For everyone. 

See, it wasn't about me not wanting the kid. It was about wanting the kid to have *everything*. A life I just... couldn't give. Paulie Bleeker and I were, and still are, basically kids ourselves. We were barely figuring out how to order pizza without sounding like total idiots, let alone raise a human. 

Mark and Vanessa? They were ready. They *wanted* it. They had the house with the swing set and the sensible cars and the matching towels. I had a beat-up Honda Civic and a serious addiction to cheesy horror movies. Different vibes, you know?

It would have been selfish to keep him just because *I* made the mistake. And honestly? It was kinda empowering, realizing I could make a hard choice, a grown-up choice, even when it totally sucked. It showed me I wasn't just some clueless teenager. I could actually, like, *handle* things.

So yeah. Same decision. It wasn't easy, and it still stings sometimes, but it was the right thing. And sometimes, the right thing is the hardest thing. Don't quote me on that, though. It sounds way too profound for me.

Ugh, okay, so, the *emotional aftermath*. That sounds…clinical, doesn't it? Like I needed a whole team of doctors and a flow chart. It wasn't *that* organized, let me tell ya. It was more like a tangled mess of feelings, kinda like my headphone cord after it's been in my backpack all day.

Honestly? It was weird. Like, really weird. For a while, it felt like…a big empty space. Not sad, exactly, though there was definitely some of *that*. More like…a missing piece. I knew logically I'd done the right thing, the *best* thing, for everyone involved. Mark and Vanessa were amazing, and they were gonna give the kid a life I just…couldn't. But knowing that didn't magically erase the fact that I *carried* him, you know? 

I leaned on Bleeker a lot. He's…well, he's Bleeker. Quiet, but he listens. And Paul and Bren, my stepdad and mom, were surprisingly cool about the whole thing. They didn't smother me, which was good, 'cause smothering is the *worst*. They just…were there. 

I think a lot of it was just…allowing myself to *feel* stuff. I'm good at being sarcastic and deflecting, you know? It's a survival mechanism. But you can't really sarcastic-your-way out of grief or…whatever it was. It was a process, okay? A messy, awkward, sometimes-I-just-wanted-to-hide-in-my-room process. 

And honestly? I think a big part of coping was realizing that giving him up didn't mean I didn't care. It meant I cared *enough* to want what was best for him, even if that wasn't with me. Which is, like, a really grown-up thing to figure out, and honestly, it still feels kinda weird to say.

Ugh, okay, so like, "conflicts" is a strong word. It wasn't like we were battling over the baby or anything. More like...adjusting to each other's *vibe*, you know? Mark and Vanessa, they were...enthusiastic. Like, *really* enthusiastic. Which is good, I guess, 'cause they wanted a kid, but it was a little intense sometimes. 

Vanessa had, like, a whole Pinterest board dedicated to nursery themes. Seriously. And Mark kept trying to bond with me by talking about...folk music. Folk music! I mean, no offense to folk music, but it's not exactly my scene. I'm more of a Phantom Planet kinda girl.

The biggest thing, though, was just them wanting to be *involved*. They wanted to come to doctor's appointments, pick out baby names (which, no way, that was *my* job), and generally just be a part of everything. And I get it, they were excited. But it was *my* body, *my* decision, and honestly, it felt a little...invasive sometimes. 

I had to be really firm about boundaries. Like, "Look, I appreciate the organic baby food samples, but I need some space." It was awkward, for sure. But we talked it through. Eventually. And they were pretty good about backing off when I asked. They just really, really wanted to be good parents, you know? And that, ultimately, was a good sign. It just took a little...negotiation.

Ugh, okay, so that was... a whole *thing*. Honestly? Good riddance. Not to sound harsh, but Paulie Bleeker is a sweet kid, don't get me wrong. Like, genuinely a good soul. But a *father*? That's a whole different level of responsibility, and he was barely handling being a boyfriend, let alone a dad. He was still figuring out what kind of music he liked, for crying out loud! 

It wasn't about punishing him, though people kinda assumed it was. It was about what was best for the baby, and honestly, for *me*. I didn't want him involved in picking the parents, or having any say in where the kid went. It felt... messy. Like adding a whole other layer of complication to something already pretty complicated. 

Mark and Vanessa, the couple who ended up adopting, they were... solid. They *wanted* a kid, they were ready, and they were, like, actually grown-up people with actual jobs and a house that didn't smell faintly of stale pizza and video games. Paulie wouldn't have understood that. He'd have just wanted to name the kid after a band or something.

Plus, let's be real, he was kinda relieved. He was supportive, in his own awkward, Paulie-Bleeker way, but I could tell he was secretly glad he wasn't gonna be changing diapers. It just felt... cleaner this way. Less drama. And honestly, after a while, I just needed less drama in my life. You know?

Ugh, okay, so like, it wasn't exactly a *sparkly* moment of inspiration, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh! Adoption! Perfect!" It was more...practical. And honestly, a little terrifying.

See, Paulie Bleeker – sweet, oblivious Paulie – and I… well, we made a mistake. A really big, life-altering mistake. And I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still trying to figure out what I want for *lunch*, let alone raising a human being. 

My parents, they're… good people. But they have their own stuff going on. My stepmom, Bren, she's amazing, but she's already dealing with, like, a million things. And my dad? He's just...my dad. He'd try, but it wouldn't be fair to anyone.

So, I started thinking. And I realized I wanted this kid to have *everything*. A real family, a stable home, people who were actually *ready* for it. Not just someone scrambling to make it work because, well, because they *had* to. 

I saw an ad for adoption, and it just… clicked. It wasn't giving up, exactly. It was choosing. Choosing the best life for this little person. It was a really hard choice, don't get me wrong. Still is, some days. But it felt… right. Like, the least selfish thing I could do.

It's not like I just decided, "Oh, well, bye baby!" It's complicated. Everything is. But that's how it started. A messy, complicated, and kinda scary realization that I wasn't ready. And that maybe, just maybe, someone else was.

Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, monumentally big. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? People kept asking me if I was *sad*, and I was, sometimes. But it wasn't just sadness. It was... complicated. Like a really tangled-up headphone cord.

There was definitely a lot of feeling weird. Like, carrying a person inside you for, well, however long it was, and then *not*... it messes with your head. It's not like losing a thing, because it wasn't *mine* to lose, not really. It was more like... preparing something really special for someone else. Which sounds kinda cheesy when I say it out loud.

I think a lot of it was just trying to be okay with the fact that I was doing what I thought was best. For the baby, mostly. And for me, honestly. I wasn't exactly equipped to raise a kid, not then. I was still figuring out what *I* wanted to eat for breakfast most days. 

Paulie Bleeker was... surprisingly good about it. He didn't try to fix things or tell me how to feel. He just... *was* there. And Leah, my stepmom? She was a lifesaver. She understood, even when I was being a total grump. 

Honestly, the hardest part wasn't the giving up, it was the *waiting*. Waiting for Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted him, to be ready. And then, after, just... waiting to see if I'd made the right decision. Which, I did. I know I did. But it still felt like a piece of me was... elsewhere. 

It sounds dramatic, I know. But it's true. It's just... you gotta let go sometimes, even when it really, really sucks. And you gotta trust that things will be okay, even when you can't see how.

Okay, so, that's... a big question. It wasn't like, instantly sunshine and rainbows, you know? Mark and Vanessa Loring, they were... *polished*. Like, really polished. Everything had a place, everything was coordinated. Their house smelled faintly of lemon polish and ambition, which is a weird combo, honestly. 

At first, it was kinda awkward. I mean, I was a sixteen-year-old girl handing over my kid. They were a couple who *wanted* a kid, but couldn't have one. It's a power imbalance, right? I felt like I was being interviewed for a job, except the job was... growing a human and then giving it away. 

Vanessa was...intense. She had a *vision* for this baby. Organic everything, Montessori schooling, the whole nine yards. I was mostly just trying to finish my history project and avoid eye contact. Mark, though, he was different. He was quieter, more observant. He'd ask me about my life, not just about the pregnancy. He actually *listened*.

We had a lot of meetings, a lot of talking. It wasn't always easy. I had moments where I wanted to just bolt, where I was convinced they were going to turn into these Stepford parents and the baby would be, like, a tiny, perfectly-behaved robot. But they were genuinely good people. They really, really wanted to be parents.

And honestly? They were the only ones who didn't treat me like some kind of... freak show. They didn't judge. They just... tried to understand. 

It wasn't a friendship, exactly. It was more like... a complicated understanding. A shared responsibility. And, yeah, a whole lot of feelings. It's weird, you know? Loving someone you're giving away. But I knew, deep down, they were the best people to give my kid a good life. And that's what mattered.

Ugh, *changed* me? That's... a loaded question, isn't it? Like, yeah, obviously. It's not like I woke up one morning still obsessed with finding the perfect vintage record and went to bed the same person after finding out I was, you know, baking a human. 

It's more like... it sped things up. Like someone hit fast forward on the "growing up" remote. Before, I was pretty content just being a sarcastic observer, you know? Commenting on everything, not really *doing* much. Now? I have to actually *think* about stuff. Consequences. The future. It's exhausting.

I used to think being mature was, like, wearing cardigans and drinking tea. Turns out it's more about making really hard decisions and trying not to completely fall apart while you're doing it. 

It's made me... I don't know... less flippant, maybe? Though I still try to be funny, because if I don't laugh, I'll probably just cry. And nobody wants to see that. It's also made me realize people are way more complicated than I thought. Like, Mark and Vanessa? Total weirdos, but they're *good* weirdos. And my dad? He's still a goofball, but he's a surprisingly good listener. 

So yeah, changed. Definitely changed. But hopefully, for the better. Or at least, not for the worse. It's still all pretty new, you know?

Ugh, the rumors. Seriously. It was like, overnight, everyone in Maple Creek became a forensic pregnancy investigator. Like they *needed* to know every single detail of my life, dissected and displayed for their amusement. It was… irritating, to say the least.

Honestly? I mostly just leaned into the awkward. If someone gave me the side-eye at the grocery store, I'd just give 'em a really big, exaggerated wave. Like, "Oh, hi! Yes, this is my life now! What about it?" It kinda short-circuited their judgmental circuits, you know? People expect you to be all ashamed and hide, and when you don't, it throws them for a loop.

And the whispers? I pretended I couldn't hear them. Or, if I *did* hear something particularly ridiculous – like Mrs. Periwinkle claiming I'd gotten pregnant by a traveling salesman – I'd just mutter something under my breath like, "Wow, her imagination is *really* working overtime." 

It wasn't easy, though. It stung, you know? Being talked *about* instead of *to*. But my dad, he told me something that actually helped. He said, "People are gonna talk, Juno. It's what they do. Just focus on what *you* need to do." And that was… surprisingly solid advice, coming from him. 

Plus, Bleeker was pretty good at distracting me. He'd just show up with a new record and we'd listen to it, and suddenly the whole world felt a little less… gossipy. It's weird, right? How music can just kinda… absorb all the bad stuff?

Ugh, okay, so like, where do I even *start* with that? It wasn't exactly a snap decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, totally giving away my kid!" Though, honestly, some mornings *felt* like that, especially with the morning sickness.

Basically, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. Paul, well, he's...Paul. Sweet guy, but definitely not ready to be a dad. And my parents? They're awesome, don't get me wrong, but they're kinda...focused on, like, being adults. Having a baby would just completely derail *everyone's* lives.

It just felt...responsible. Like, the most responsible thing I could do. I wanted this kid to have a life, a *good* life. A life with parents who were actually prepared and excited and, you know, financially stable. Not a life where I'm still in high school and trying to figure out if I even *like* French class. 

It wasn't about not loving the baby, okay? It was about loving her *enough* to want the best for her. And the best for her wasn't with me, at least not then. It's complicated. Everything is always complicated. But it felt...right. Does that make any sense? It's kinda hard to explain when you're dealing with, like, the biggest decision of your life.

Ugh, okay, so like, biggest fear? That's a loaded question, right? It wasn't, like, the *giving up* part, necessarily. I mean, that was... complicated. It was more the *wrong people* getting him. Or her. I didn't even *know* yet, honestly, which was kinda stressing me out on top of everything else.

See, I pictured some, like, super Stepford-y couple who'd raise a kid to be a miniature lawyer or something. All perfectly pressed khakis and piano lessons. And my kid? He'd be, like, *sad*. You know? Like he wouldn't get to just... be. 

I wanted someone who'd let him be weird. Someone who'd understand if he wanted to collect bottle caps or write poetry about dinosaurs. Someone who wouldn't try to *fix* him. Because, honestly, I didn't think he *needed* fixing. He just needed a good home.

So yeah, that was it. Not losing him, exactly. But losing him *to* the wrong life. Does that make sense? It's hard to explain when you're, like, sixteen and dealing with a whole lot of hormones and a rapidly expanding midsection.

Ugh, okay, so *that* story. People always ask about Bleeker. It's not like I sat down and was all, "Hmm, what tragically hip name shall I bestow upon the father of my child?" It kinda...happened.

See, Paulie, that's Bleeker, he was just...there. At the roller rink. And he was playing this really intense guitar, like, super serious indie rock. And he kept talking about this poet, this guy named Wallace Stevens. And Wallace Stevens had a poem called "The Idea of Distance," and in it, there's this line about a guy named Bleeker Street. 

It just...stuck. It sounded cool, you know? Like, a little bit sad and a little bit artsy. And Paulie, he was *definitely* going for artsy. Plus, it was kinda funny. Like, "Oh, you're dating a guy named Bleeker." It just felt...right. 

Honestly, I think he liked that I remembered it. He was always trying to seem all deep and profound, and I think acknowledging his obscure references made him feel seen. Which, honestly, was kinda pathetic, but whatever. It got me a free slice of pizza that night, so I wasn't complaining.

Don't tell him I said that though. He'd probably write a song about it. A *really* long song.

Ugh, okay, so like, people always ask that. It's not like I *set out* to be a punk, you know? It just...fit. Everything else felt kinda...beige. Like, all the other girls were into, I don't know, Hilary Duff or whatever, and it just felt so...manufactured. 

Punk felt *real*. Raw. It wasn't about being pretty or fitting in. It was about saying what you thought, even if it was, like, totally unpopular. And the music? It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows. It was messy and complicated, just like...well, just like *life*, actually. 

Plus, the clothes are comfy. Seriously. Skinny jeans and band tees? Way better than a dress and heels any day. Don't get me wrong, I'm not trying to make a statement or anything. It's just...me. It feels honest. And honestly, honesty is kinda important, especially when you're dealing with, you know...*stuff*. 

It's not about rebellion for the sake of rebellion, either. It's more like...a soundtrack to figuring things out. A way to feel something when everything else feels kinda numb. Does that make sense? Probably not. It's hard to explain. It just *does*.

Ugh, the D-word. Divorce. It's... a thing, right? Like, a really *big* thing that happens when people decide they can't stand to look at each other anymore without wanting to, I don't know, re-arrange the furniture with their faces. 

It definitely messed with my head, growing up with it. My dad, he just... left. Poof. Went to find himself and his inner pottery artist, or whatever. Mom, she was just...tired. And honestly, I get it. They weren't *horrible* people, just... not good *together*.

I think it made me kinda wary of, like, the whole "forever" thing. Like, what if you pick someone and then five years later you're just...over it? It feels kinda irresponsible, you know? That's probably why I wasn't exactly rushing into anything with Paulie Bleeker, even before...well, *everything*. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. Just... a little predictable. 

It also made me super independent, I guess. I had to be. Mom was working all the time, and I learned pretty quick that if I wanted something done, I had to do it myself. Which, honestly, is a useful skill. Comes in handy when you're, say, navigating the whole unexpected-pregnancy-and-adoption situation. You kinda gotta be your own person, you know?

So yeah, it wasn't sunshine and rainbows. But it also taught me that people change, and sometimes that's okay. And that you can survive even when things fall apart. It's just... messy. Everything's always messy.

Ugh, okay, so people keep *asking* me this. Like, it's not exactly a topic I volunteer for dinner conversation, you know? But alright, I'll bite.

I guess what makes my story... not *normal*, because let's be real, it's pretty far from normal... is that it's not some super dramatic, tear-jerker thing. It's messy, yeah, and kinda awkward, and definitely involves a lot of really weird conversations with adults. But it's also... honest. 

Most stories about teen pregnancy are all about the shame and the regret and the "ruined life" thing. And look, I'm not saying it's *easy*. It's not. But it wasn't about me being "ruined." It was about making a really hard decision, and trying to do what was best for everyone involved – me, the baby, and the people who actually *wanted* to be parents. 

It's about finding good people, even when you're surrounded by a lot of... well, let's just say not-so-good people. And it's about realizing that growing up isn't about having all the answers, it's about figuring out the questions. And sometimes, the biggest question is just, "What do *I* want?" 

So yeah, it's special because it's real. It's not a fairytale. It's just... life. A really weird, complicated, kinda funny life. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it. Even the awkward parts. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, good friends. That's... a surprisingly deep question, considering I usually just value people who don't, like, *actively* annoy me. But alright, I'll bite.

First off, gotta have a good sense of humor. Like, someone who gets my sarcasm, you know? 'Cause if you don't get the sarcasm, it's just...sad. And then it's awkward for *both* of us. 

But it's not just about being funny. It's about being *real*. I can spot a phony a mile away. I need someone who's gonna tell me I look ridiculous when I'm trying too hard, but also be there with a box of cheesy puffs when I'm, like, legitimately bummed. 

And honestly? Someone who doesn't judge. I mean, I make a lot of questionable decisions. Let's be honest. A good friend doesn't need to *agree* with them, but they gotta at least try to understand *why* I did them. 

Basically, someone who's just...solid. Not dramatic, not needy, just...there. Like a good pair of Converse. Reliable. You know? Leah and Paulie are pretty good at that. They're weird, but they're *my* weird.

Ugh, okay, so like, *everyone* had an opinion all of a sudden. It's not like I was invisible before, but suddenly I was this…project. Like a science fair experiment gone slightly awry. 

My relationship with my dad, Paul? That got…weirdly good, actually. He was surprisingly chill, you know? Like, he didn't *get* it, not at all, but he tried. He made me PB&Js constantly, which was a nice gesture, even if it felt like he was trying to fatten me up for the stork or something.

My stepmom, Bren? She was a saint. Seriously. She was all about support and making sure I was okay, even when I was being a total grump. She's just…a really good person. I felt bad putting her through all that, though. It wasn't exactly the domestic bliss she signed up for.

And then there's Leah. My best friend. That was…rough for a bit. She was mad, understandably. Like, I kinda blew up our perfectly good teenage existence. We didn't talk for a while, which sucked. But eventually, she came around. She's a good egg, that one. She just needed time to process the whole "my best friend is having a baby" thing.

Honestly, the biggest impact was just realizing how much people *think* they know what's best for you. Everyone had a suggestion, a lecture, a worried look. It was exhausting. It made me really value the people who just…listened. And brought PB&Js. Those people are the best.

Ugh, okay, deep thoughts already? Seriously? Fine. But don't expect, like, a perfectly articulated philosophical treatise or something. I'm sixteen, not Socrates.

I guess...honesty is pretty big. Not, like, brutally honest where you just *have* to tell someone their outfit looks like a dumpster fire, but, you know, being real. People waste so much time pretending to be something they're not. It's exhausting just *watching* them. 

And I think...being okay with being different. Like, I'm not into the whole cheerleader/football captain scene. Never have been. And that's cool. It's just...people get so caught up in fitting in, they forget to figure out what *they* actually like. Which is kinda sad, actually.

Also, and this is important, don't be a tool. Seriously. Just...don't. It's a bad look. And it usually ends with someone getting hurt. 

I guess those are some things. It's not like I have a whole life philosophy written down or anything. It's more like...stuff I've figured out by just, you know, *being* here. And dealing with...stuff. You wouldn't believe the stuff.

Ugh, okay, so the whole naming thing was... a process. Not like, a *fun* process, you know? It wasn't like I was flipping through baby name books dreaming of "Penelope" or whatever. It was more like, "Okay, I'm making a tiny human. It needs a name. And it can't be something *totally* embarrassing."

See, Mark and Vanessa – the couple who, uh, were gonna be the parents – they had a list. A *long* list. All very… beige. Like, "Ethan" and "Olivia." Seriously? I mean, no offense to Ethans and Olivias, but it felt kinda… expected. 

I kinda pushed for something a little more… *me*. Not for *me*, obviously. For the kid. I wanted something that felt strong, but not try-hard. And Vanessa, she was really into poetry, specifically e.e. cummings. So, I suggested "Poppy." It just… fit. It felt kinda delicate, but also kinda resilient, you know? Like a wildflower pushing through concrete. 

Plus, it's just a good name. It doesn't scream "I was adopted!" or "My mom was a teenager!" It just *is*. And Mark and Vanessa, they actually liked it. Which was a relief, honestly. I didn't want to be fighting over baby names on top of everything else.

It felt… right. Like, even though I wasn't keeping the baby, getting to pick the name felt like a little piece of me I could give it. A little bit of a good start. Does that make sense? It's hard to explain. It's just… names are important. They stick with you.

Ugh, okay, deep thoughts time. Don't get me wrong, I was *totally* capable of handling a baby. Like, I could've figured out the whole diaper situation, probably. But that's not the point, is it? The whole thing... it was like a really intense crash course in, well, *everything*.

I learned that people are way more complicated than they seem. Like, Mark and Vanessa? Total yuppies, right? I figured they'd want a perfect little mini-me, all preppy and into polo. But they weren't. They were... *real*. They wanted a kid, a family, and they were genuinely good people. It kinda messed with my head, honestly. You judge a book by its cover and all that jazz.

And then there was Paulie Bleeker. Seriously, that kid. I thought I was just, you know, hanging out with him because he was... there. Convenient. But seeing him step up, be supportive, even when I was being a total sarcastic mess... that showed me something. It showed me that maybe I wasn't as closed off as I thought I was. And that maybe, just maybe, I actually *liked* him. A lot.

But the biggest thing? I learned that being brave isn't about not being scared. It's about doing what you know is right, even when it totally sucks. Giving up the baby wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was the right thing. For her, for Mark and Vanessa, and even for me. 

It wasn't about sacrificing something, it was about *choosing* something. Choosing a good life for her, and choosing to figure out my own. And that, I think, is a pretty important lesson. It's not about having all the answers, it's about being okay with the questions. And maybe, just maybe, finding a little bit of yourself along the way.

Ugh, okay, that's a *big* question. Like, existential crisis big. Honestly? Probably not a whole lot. It was... messy. A total, beautiful, awkward mess. 

People always wanna know if I regret it, giving him up, you know? And it's not about regret. It's more like... wishing I could've fast-forwarded through some of the weirdness. Like, the whole Mark and Vanessa thing was... a choice. A *bad* choice on their part, mostly. I mean, seriously, a suburban couple pretending to be super edgy? It was painful to watch.

If I *could* change something, maybe I'd have been a little less sarcastic with Vanessa at first. I was just trying to protect myself, you know? Build up a wall of snark. But she was... going through stuff too. And I was kinda just judging her for it instead of, like, *seeing* her. 

But then again, if I hadn't been so snarky, maybe things wouldn't have unfolded the way they did. Maybe Mark and Vanessa wouldn't have realized they needed to actually *talk* to each other. So, I dunno. It's all connected, right? 

The whole thing taught me a lot about people, and about myself. That even when things are totally crazy and you feel like you're drowning in awkwardness, you can still make a good decision. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go. Even if it feels like your insides are being rearranged.

So, yeah. Would I change things? Maybe a few little details. But the big picture? Nah. It got me where I am now, and I think... I think I'm okay with that.

Ugh, disappointment. It's, like, a constant companion, isn't it? Especially when you're a teenager and everything feels *huge*. Honestly? I mostly just...acknowledge it. Like, yeah, that sucked. That really, really sucked. Then I try to figure out if dwelling on it is actually *productive* or if I'm just being melodramatic. Which, let's be real, is a valid option sometimes. 

See, my dad always says things fall apart so better things can fall together. It sounds super cheesy, I know, and I used to roll my eyes so hard I thought they'd get stuck. But it's kinda true. Like, getting pregnant wasn't exactly on my five-year plan, to put it mildly. Huge disappointment. But it led to...well, a lot. And some good stuff, eventually. 

I think the key is not pretending you're not bummed. You gotta feel the bummed-ness. But then you gotta, like, dust yourself off and figure out what the next move is. And maybe eat a really good peanut butter sandwich. That usually helps. It's a surprisingly effective coping mechanism. Don't judge.

Ugh, Leah. Okay, don't get me wrong, she's...intense. Like, permanently dialed up to eleven. But she was *essential*, you know? Before all this...situation...happened, we were just kinda orbiting each other at school. She was the super-stylish, super-into-everything girl, and I was...well, me. I mostly just observed. And made sarcastic comments. It's a talent.

But then, when I found out I was pregnant, everything shifted. Suddenly, I needed someone who wasn't gonna freak out and judge me, and who wouldn't treat me like I was suddenly made of glass. And Leah, surprisingly, was that person. She didn't *get* why I wasn't, like, totally devastated, but she respected that I was handling it my way. 

It wasn't always smooth sailing, though. She definitely had her moments of wanting to "fix" things, or get super involved in the adoption process. Like she was auditioning to be the honorary aunt or something. But she always came back around to just *being there*. Listening to me ramble about Paulie Bleeker, or Van, or just the general weirdness of being a teenager with a growing bump.

I think we both needed each other, honestly. She needed someone to pull her back down to earth sometimes, and I needed someone who wasn't afraid to be genuinely excited about stuff. It went from being a casual school acquaintance to...I don't know, a real friendship. A messy, complicated, but real one. It's good to have someone who knows all your embarrassing secrets and still thinks you're alright. Even when you're, like, actively making questionable life choices.

Okay, wow. That's... a loaded question, honestly. Like, "favorite part" implies there was a *lot* to choose from, and while it wasn't all bad, let's not pretend it was a walk in the park, okay? I mean, morning sickness is a misnomer. It should be "all-day-and-sometimes-night sickness." Not glamorous.

But, if I *had* to pick something... I think it was the feeling of, like, having this little secret. Not a *bad* secret, you know? Just... something completely mine. Before that, I was just Juno, the girl who liked records and avoided gym class. Suddenly, I was carrying a whole person. It was kinda... empowering, in a weird way. 

And the kicks. Those were pretty cool. Felt like a tiny little alien doing karate inside me. Though, sometimes it was right when I was trying to eat a peanut butter sandwich, which was less cool. 

But mostly? It was realizing I wasn't as totally clueless as I thought I was. I mean, I was still pretty clueless, don't get me wrong. But I could handle things. Big things. Even if "handling things" meant deciding to find the *perfect* parents for this kid. It was... a lot. But a good lot, eventually.
